speakeroldname: Mr. Brian L. Gardiner (Prince George-Bulkley Valley):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I have the pleasure of tabling a petition signed primarily by the residents of Bums Lake, B.C. in my riding.
The petition expresses the ongoing concern of all Canadians over this government's bringing in "of the goods and services tax.

Madam Speaker, I have the honour of presenting two petitions pursuant to Standing Order 36.
The first petition is signed by residents of the city of Winnipeg. They humbly pray and call upon Parliament to recognize housing as a shared provincial-federal responsibility, and request support for the federal non-profit co-operative housing program and to maintain the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation.

Madam Speaker, I have another petition from residents of the city of Winnipeg. The petitioners request that Parliament consider amending all federal superannuation acts in which inequities exist to allow for the retroactive pension credit splitting for all divorced spouses so that they may receive one-half of the federal pension credits accumulated by both spouses during the years of their marriage.

Madam Speaker, it is an honour to present a petition on behalf of a number of the residents of the North Thompson valley in British Columbia who are concerned now, as they have been for many months, about a proposal to divert the North Thompson River.
They ask that we maintain a very clear position and that the Government of Canada oppose such a venture.

Madam Speaker, I have a second petition regarding financial support for the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. The petitioners, all from Kamloops, are asking that the federal government and the provincial government take whatever steps are necessary to ensure an adequate level of policing.

February 13, 1992
Routine Proceedings DON RIVER

Madam Speaker, I am happy to present petitions duly signed by many constituents of Broadview-Greenwood. The petitioners continue to hope that the government will honour the commitments it made in the green plan and funding statements that it made earlier in attempts to reclaim the Don River which flows through my riding, the most polluted river in all of Canada.
The petitioners hope that by reclaiming the Don River, we can use it as a model of our ability to reclaim all the dirty rivers in this country.

speakeroldname: Mr. Albert Cooper (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext: Madam Speaker, the following questions will be answered today: Nos. 148, 149, 150 and 195.

With respect to the subsection 9(1) of the Immigration Act which requires that immigrants apply for, and obtain a visa before appearing at a Canadian port of entry, what is the average time required to process regulations exempting an individual from this requirement?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Persons applying for landed immigrant status from within Canada must meet statutory requirements which include medical and security checks as well as requiring an Order-in-Council to exempt these applicants from the requirement of subsection 9(1) of the Immigration Act.
The average processing time for Order-in-Council visa waivers has fluctuated over the last two years in response to immigration levels achievement and volume. At this point virtually all visa waiver Order-in-Council requests submitted by applicants prior to January 1991 have been completed, indicating an average processing period of 10 and 12 months.

What is the average time which elapses between the delivery of a completed application form by an individual seeking permanent resident status who is presently in Canada, and the actual landing of a successful applicant?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Persons applying for landed immigrant status from within Canada must meet statutory requirements which include medical and security checks as well as requiring an Order-in-Council to exempt these applicants from the requirement of subsection 9(1) of the Immigration Act.
The average processing time for Order-in-Council visa waivers has fluctuated over the last two years in response to immigration levels achievement and volume. At this point virtually all visa waiver Order-in-Council requests submitted by appliants prior to January 1991 have been completed, indicating an average processing period of 10 to 12 months.

Is the Department of Employment and Immigration contemplating any administrative or legislative changes to facilitate the processing of applications for landed immigrant status received from within Canada?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
There are presently no plans to amend subsection 9(1) of the Immigration Act which requires that immigrants obtain a visa before appearing at a port-of-entry.
Persons applying for landed immigrant status from within Canada must meet statutory requirements which include medical and security checks as well as requiring an Order-in-Council to exempt these applicants from the requirement of subsection 9(1) of the Immigration Act.
Recently, Employment and Immigration introduced administrative measures, namely automated processing and tracking of Govemor-in-Council submissions, to improve the processing of applications for permanent residence by persons in Canada.
Employment and Immigration will continue to develop procedural changes to improve the processing of these applications.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: Shall the remaining questions stand?

Agreed.

February 13, 1992
Government Orders

The House resumed from Tuesday, February 11, consideration of the motion of Mr. Loiselle that Bill C-26, an act to amend the Public Service Employment Act, the Public Service Staff Relations Act and other acts in relation to the Public Service of Canada, be read the second time and referred to Legislative Committee H; and the amendment of Mrs. Catterall (p. 6131).

Madam Speaker, Bill C-26, tabled by the President of the Treasury Board, could have a major impact on Canadians and, more specifically, on the Public Service. I would like to discuss the preliminaries to this legislation which were broadly based on wide-ranging consultations across Canada and, more specifically, throughout the Public Service. I intend to explain how this was done by a government that must be sensitive to public opinion if it is to gain the public's support. And finally, Madam Speaker, I will also indicate how this reform can have a major impact on the Public Service, on federal services as such and on Canadians.
Madam Speaker, as you know, it is not easy to motivate members of an organization the size of the Public Service, which has more than 200,000 employees. It is not easy to get such a group actively involved in a wide-ranging reform program and the implementation of that program. However, when we consider the process and the history of Bill C-26 now before the House, and when we look at the extensive discussions that have taken place, the consultations and the meetings, we are impressed by the tremendous participation shown at all levels, both in the Public Service and among the general public.
Did you know, Madam Speaker, that this vast consultation campaign involved setting up task forces that worked systematically? For example, on 10 occasions, more than 300 people met at one time; in all, 3,000 people made 300 recommendations. Did you know that in addition to these discussion groups, there were innumerable conferences and workshops? There were telephone surveys. There were informal contacts between individuals and even the unions, officials and members alike, participated with the government people. There were also consultations in the private sector. In short, in addition to the 3,000 people whom I just mentioned, 7,600 more were involved in these discussions.
You already see that the consultations were held in a structured but fairly spontaneous way with unexpected developments, reactions and some wonderful recommendations. Throughout this consultation process, letters were sent and more than 1,700 people who would have been unable to take part in these consultation sessions reacted personally by letter to the President of the Treasury Board and his reforms.
All in all, summing it up, 12,000 to 13,000 people had the conviction to participate, and worked on sharing their visions of what the reform should be.
I am therefore pleased to note, that this major reform bill, C-26, was developed in such a systematic, democratic and wide-ranging way. This leads me to say that this bill cannot help reflecting to a great extent the goals of union members, public servants, section heads and each department in their long-term vision of what such a reform should be. But the purpose of having a consultation was not only to come up with a white paper.
Everything that was collected and collated from these
13,000	people was passed on to the Treasury Board, which then produced the white paper. With this document, which was tabled several months ago, we returned to the grass roots, which expressed its comments, expectations and concerns, and moved on to the second phase, raising awareness. Since the recommendations had been accepted in whole or in part, we consolidated them and went back to find out what people thought of it. Here again, more than in phase 1, we gave out 247,000 brochures, 11,000 posters, 19,000 reports and 344,000 copies of the white paper, throughout the Public Service and to the public, because ultimately, the public will benefit from all these reforms.
All in all, 800,000 documents arising from this white paper were distributed, giving all their readers a chance
February 13, 1992

to react or at least to find out about the proposed policies. That's not all. In addition to these written documents, Treasury Board and its president took their concern for the democratic process, information and awareness farther, by involving group leaders. They visited senior managers in various departments; 294 groups were involved in this process. Furthermore, the President of the Treasury Board himself gave several speeches in various places, again to ensure the dissemin-sation of information. Two of them were even given before labour groups. Finally, 13 joint committees were set up.
As you can see from all this, the information and awareness phase was as extensive as the first one, the information gathering phase. Did you know that, in the Correctional Service alone, 3,500 proposals were put forward? Did you know that more than 4,500 came from Health and Welfare Canada? Does this not go to show the level of interest and participation of our civil servants from various departments across the country? Is this not solid, fabulous proof of their beliefs and concerns?
At the same time, it shows the commitment of this government which, throughout its mandate, while it introduced bold and hard changes, it never failed to dig out the facts and then release this information to better inform the public about these reforms. And that is great.
That is what brings me to the conclusion in this first part, that this approach was great. I have to thank the President of the Treasury Board, the hon. minister, for conducting such a fine operation.
Aside from this campaign and process, in closing, I would like to mention the major thrusts of this reform: to increase civil servants involvement, to give them a sense of belonging, to allow them to take part in the assessment of their own work environment. Isn't this great? So, civil servants' participation is essential, since they are the heart and soul of the federal government. What we stand to gain from all this is obvious.
Besides a greater sense of belonging and a more efficient public service, you can easily imagine, Madam
Government Orders
Speaker, how much Canadian citizens and taxpayers will benefit from this increased efficiency and sense of belonging as well as from improved services.

Madam Speaker, I am pleased to speak on the amendment of the hon. member for Ottawa West, seconded by the hon. member for Glengarry-Prescott-Russell, that Bill C-26, an act to amend to the Public Service Employment Act, the Public Service Staff Relations Act and other acts in relation to the Public Service of Canada, be not now read a second time but be read a second time this day six months hence.
I acknowledge that there has been some significant dialogue and important participation. There is still much to be done because if there were not, we would have an acknowledgement on the part of the workers, part of the people that it affects, that this is not so. There are still some concerns out there.
If this bill were adopted, it would permit an indepth study of the legislation.
I wish to say a few words about the Public Service before I attack the substance of the bill. I believe and many of my colleagues also do in the importance of the Public Service. I am a former public servant and I have a great deal of respect for them. Obviously, like any other group, we have people who are more committed, more talented than others. At the same time, the majority are very capable men and women who devoted much of their lives and their talents to our country in order to attempt and respond to the will of politicians in Parliament and to deliver the best services possible. I salute them.
It offends me to see that the Public Service can become a target for political parties of government. We sometimes forget that the salaries they have, the pensions they have acquired over the years, and other benefits as well, are not ones they have granted themselves. They have negotiated them with government that at some point in time has in fact said yes.
My objective, and I hope it is shared by many others, is not to remove some of those benefits or lessen them or somehow diluer the rights they have acquired over time,

Government Orders
but we should be looking at how it is that we can in fact extend that to other Canadians throughout the nation. Surely that is a much preferred way of responding than it is to attempt to diminish-I say it again-the rights and the benefits that they have acquired over time. I want to point out that which they have they were granted by governments and it is too easy for them to become targets of politicians.
I want to say as well that I am offended when they become the scapegoats, often times, for the failures of political people or governments. I think the most flagrant example of that was the Al-Mashat affair where in fact they were used as bouc emissaire si vous voulez.
I want to point out as well that this bill, in my opinion and in the opinion of many others, will not create the right kind of climate or environment for change and growth to meet the needs of Canadians and to meet the needs of a changing Canada. I think that is extremely serious. There is an attempt to streamline. No doubt there is a need to streamline the way resources are managed by the Public Service and to simplify and expedite the collective bargaining process. I think most people would agree, but where we probably disagree is: Is this the best approach? Is there still more to do? What is it that can be done in order to reach those particular objectives?
There is no doubt that the new legislation does make some positive contributions. There has been some dialogue, as I pointed out. There has been some participation, but in our opinion, not sufficiently so. There are still some people who are very anxious, who are angry, who are upset, who do not understand the total agenda of government. Another positive feature, quite apart from some important participation and dialogue, has been employment equity. Equal pay for work of equal value has been addressed, but we claim it is still too vague, that it needs to be more precise.
Let me talk about the reservation quickly. Some of the proposed amendments in the bill, such as those regarding appointments, layoffs and deployments, are highly controversial. We really need to see whether or not that controversy is justified. The proposed changes would serve to give managers greater authority to hire, fire and transfer employees without adequate appeal and redress mechanisms. Surely that is a very important gain that has been made, not only by this group, but many others. We do not want to go back. There is no assurance that the
actions of managers would support the merit principle. That is the fundamental flaw. We need to have assurance that the merit principle will in fact continue to be the very centrepiece of appointments to the civil service.
Deputy heads would be permitted to move employees into jobs without selection boards, without appointments, through deployment. The legislation would also allow the government to contract out work while laying off incumbents in these positions. Some federal Public Service unions contend that the contracting out of work does not save money. In fact, it would cost more. In many instances it could be done more cheaply and more efficiently by the current Public Service employees.
I find it interesting that when I asked on the Order Paper for a response to how many contracts were in fact awarded and what was the total value, I was not given that information. Supposedly it has not been accumulated. I find that shocking. Why do we not get the facts so we can put them on the table and look at them in a rational way?
The bill would make it easier to hire casual employees for limited periods. Continued turnover of employees which would result from this practice could cause a lack of continuity and lead to a decline in service to the people. Surely that has got to be our first priority. It could in fact run counter to the objectives of Public Service 2000.
The public accounts committee of the House of Commons, among others, has pointed out that there has been inadequate consultation. The government says it has been adequate, but the public accounts committee says it has been inadequate, inadequate with the interested parties before the bill was drafted and presented to Parliament.
My party is urging that the government establish a special parliamentary committee to consider the principle of the bill as well as its substance in the context of Public Service 2000.
We are concerned as well that there have been a number of extremely dysfunctional labour disputes. They have disrupted the service that has been rendered to Canadians.
The government has been chastized and will continue to be for its mismanagement of labour relations. It is this government that has caused the first ever massive walkout of public servants in the history of Canada. The

Government Orders
relations were not sufficient to be able to hold them people who have been in the Public Service for a long together to work out a sensitive and sensible agreement, time.
There are many public servants out there who believe passionately and unequivocally that the government cannot be trusted and that it does not listen. That is one of the problems we are in fact experiencing. If there is lack of trust and confidence, the public servants are extremely nervous about what has been happening.
I have another concern. I believe that this is another example of the dismantling of one of our institutions of nationhood. We are weakening the Public Service. It is not unlike the dismantling of VIA Rail, Air Canada, Canada Post, CBC; privatization and contracting out; or the use of short-term employees. All of this will weaken the Public Service as an instrument that serves the public and carries out the will of Parliament in all areas of the country. I am extremely concerned about that.
My party, the Liberal Party of Canada, believes that Canadians deserve acceptable quality service throughout the nation, delivered efficiently by a professional, nonpartisan Public Service which treats all employees with respect and fairness and is responsive to the needs of Canadians.
I am concerned that we may be departing in a significant kind of way from the merit principle and that this may lead to additional patronage and favouritism in the Public Service.

I realize that the legislation before us will not necessarily protect the merit principle, in fact I believe that it will not protect it at all. It will be possible to appoint people, to transfer employees and to do many things that cannot be done now and that I think will truly weaken the Public Service.

There have been court orders and a court case where the actions of the Government of Canada have been struck down. There was the moving of employees without full consultation, without accommodating them, which is another serious flaw.
There will be a new class of casual employees who can be hired or fired within 24 hours. Managers will have a great deal of power to be potentially insensitive to
As I pointed out, the Auditor General has in fact chastized government for mismanagement. My great concern is that over all not only the merit principle may in fact be simply thrown aside but the Public Service Commission, which in fact as my colleagues have said is the watch-dog, can now become very weak and perhaps even the lap-dog of government. That would be unfortunate.

Madam Speaker, it is a pleasure for me to rise today to speak in the debate on Bill C-26 which incorporates in legislation a lot of the principles and ideas included in the PS 2000 review of the Public Service by this government.
There is no question that the Public Service needs modernization, that it needs streamlining, and that it needs a reduction in a number of reclassifications. Most of all, what the Public Service needs in my opinion is a radical decentralization of decision making.
It is my opinion that a lot of the pressures for decentralization of powers to the provinces currently under discussion in the constitutional debate could be accommodated by a decentralization of decision making within the federal Public Service so that decisions made by the federal government and the practices which it carries out in the regions would in fact be subject to decision making at local and regional levels rather than centralized in Ottawa.
However, I believe the number one problem with the Public Service is the problem of morale. Certainly an organization of that size, of that complexity and of that importance cannot function at the level of morale that exists today.
Why does that low level of morale exist? I think it is because of the feudal, backward, 19th century attitudes this government has taken toward its own employees. Certainly that is the kind of attitude the government took during the strike last summer which radicalized a group that never before had contemplated those kinds of actions. It was really despicable to see this fine group of people used for partisan ends, in the case of the prairies to pit farmers against working people for the political ends of the government.

Government Orders
This kind of an approach was further reinforced in the way the government has gone about introducing this whole notion of Bill C-26 and PS 2000. Contrary to every modern management technique which says that employees have to be involved from square one, from day one, in designing the work flow, the work place and the management structures, this government has chosen to ignore the input of its public servants and their organizations and adopt a top down approach wherein a new management structure is to be imposed on the work force. Surely all modern management theories say this is exactly contrary to the way we should go about it.
Before I go on to some of the problems I see in this legislation, I would like to pay tribute to the public servants in my constituency of Prince Albert-Churchill River. These people do a tremendous job on our behalf, on behalf of the taxpayers of Canada and on behalf of the Parliament of Canada as they carry out the duties assigned to them.
In La Ronge and Prince Albert there are manpower offices that are very much understaffed and very much under pressure because of the increasing workloads that fall on them as a result of the very high unemployment rates in that region.
We have an Indian Affairs office in Prince Albert that I think is doing a commendable job in restructuring itself to accommodate the whole movement to self-government by Indian people and their organizations.
We have a Health and Welfare office in Prince Albert that has responsibility for the delivery of health and welfare services throughout half the province of Saskatchewan, a huge geographic area with very difficult circumstances in many cases. It is doing a commendable job while at the same time facilitating the transfer of responsibilities to the Indian people.
We have a Forestry Canada office that has some very creative people in it who are working in partnership with provincial governments and various stakeholders in forestry to implement the model forest program and the federal-provincial agreements. It provides a real stimulus to the forestry industry in our community. A former minister of that department is here feeling good about what I am saying, and I think he should. It is one of the commendable developments we have seen in our community.
As well we have the Saskatchewan penitentiary which employs large numbers of people who are working very hard and in very difficult circumstances. That institution has an awful lot more inmates than it was originally designed to accommodate. There are fewer staff members than there should be. There has been significant contracting out within that institution, which both creates instability and a situation where there are people in the institution who are not as professional, I do not think, as the people who are part of the Public Service. That creates a real security dilemma within that institution and something that the government needs to look closely at.
There is also the Prince Albert National Park, one of Canada's finest parks. The work force there is undermanned but still doing a tremendous job on our behalf protecting one of the unique environments in the boreal forest in an exemplary fashion.
There are outposts of other departments, Immigration and so on, with just a few people in them who often do a very good job in isolation.
However, there are significant problems with this legislation. I think a lot of them stem from the fact that the government is trying to do by legislation things that it cannot win in the courts. This further serves to undermine the morale of public servants. As well it is a fairly despicable way to go about making changes. Some of these problems involve the threat to the merit principle, the danger of patronage and all evils associated with a non-merit type approach to hiring.
In this legislation we contemplate something called deployment. Under the concept of deployment there will be huge classifications created within which managers have the power individually to reclassify people, to move them from one job to another, and to fill positions without competitions.
Recently the government tried to do that under existing legislation. It issued something called the transfer exclusion order which was intended to waive the merit principle for the transfer of individuals from one position to another at the same group and level.
February 13, 1992

The Public Service Alliance challenged this attack on the merit principle and recently received a decision from the Federal Court of Canada which said that the federal government could not do it. This was a mere two weeks ago, and now the government is pushing forward legislation which would permit exactly the kind of practices the Federal Court of Canada said would undermine the merit principle, something that has been at the heart of our Public Service for decades and something I think all members of Parliament would endorse publicly.
We also have a problem within this legislation of condoning and promoting the whole notion of contracting out, which is really just a code word for privatization of the Public Service.
Again we have a situation where the government lost a case in court and therefore is trying to do by legislation what it could not win by normal channels.
The government brought forward a proposal to transfer out work, to contract out work, and in March 1990 the Public Service Staff Relations Board ruled that employees lost their jobs because the employer contracted out for service, a complete reversal of what it was obliged to do under the policy. In other words the Public Service board ruled that the government could not lay off workers because of its contracting out function.
Flowever, within Bill C-26 we now see that where the services of an employee are no longer required by reason of lack of work, the discontinuance of function, the transfer of work or a function outside the Public Service, the deputy head in accordance with the regulations of the commission may lay off the employee.
In other words, the government has the ability to privatize job functions, to privatize jobs on a carte blanche basis. That leads to further patronage, that leads to further undermining of the merit principle, and that leads to a further degradation of the Public Service and its efficient functioning.
The last problem I have with this legislation is the whole question of pay equity. To be brief, the government talks a good line on pay equity, on equal pay for work of equal value, but we see right now before the Human Rights Tribunal government lawyers stonewalling every attempt to bring to bear the principles of equal pay for work of equal value.
Government Orders
This PS 2000 concept envisioned in Bill C-26 will institutionalize and create such confusion in the Public Service that it will take another 10 years to bring in pay equity.
In conclusion, I would like to say that we need a Public Service that is on side. We need a Public Service that is appreciated. We need a Public Service that is involved in the day-to-day design of the work place, and we need a Public Service that is professional and non-partisan. I think all those things will be undermined by the legislation before us.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext:
The hon. President of the Treasury Board would like to say something. I am sorry, but questions and comments are not allowed at this time, only 10-minute speeches. I believe that the hon. minister has already participated in the debate.
Consequently, the hon. member for Dartmouth has the floor.

Madam Speaker, I am going to try to limit my comments today. I think I have 10 minutes on debate.
I will be up a little later on today to talk about some of the other major problems that I have with the government's approach in dealing with the Public Service of Canada. I want to speak specifically at this point in time about the motion that is before us.
It is affectionately known by those in this House as a hoist motion because it effectively takes this piece of legislation and it holds it in limbo, in suspension for a period of time.
The amendment was put forward by the critic of the Liberal Party. One of the reasons that I want to speak about this is because of the process that the government did not go through in arriving at this particular piece of legislation.
It was not that long ago the chairman of the public accounts committee indicated that before anything be done with the white paper, or the discussion paper about the Public Service of Canada, an all-party committee should be struck in a non-partisan fashion.
It would sit down, go through that particular discussion paper and formulate a piece of legislation that would

February 13, 1992
Government Orders
look after all of the various interests put forward by those sitting around the table. Most important, it would have established a principle that before the federal Public Service is fundamentally restructured, there would be an open process by which everybody in this House could contribute.
Unfortunately, the way the House works is that when a bill is presented, no matter how bad the bill is, the government and its people on the other side dig their heels in. Somehow, it is a matter of pride that if there is something wrong with the bill then we are supposed to close our eyes and go full speed ahead.
The chairman and the public accounts committee made this very clear. The process they thought should have been followed was that the discussion paper should have been put forward. The committee should have invited input from those very public servants and other user groups, from Canadians, on what was the best structure and most efficient structure for our Public Service. But the government chose not to do that. The government chose not to have that level of consultation.
So we now have before us a bill, which as you heard from other speakers leading up to this debate, is regressive. It is a bill which is fraught with difficulties. It is a bill that literally thumbs its nose at the contribution and the worth-while efforts of our Public Service.
The hoist motion is one that I am going to support. If the government would agree with us, it would give the government an out. My goodness, when you are at 12 per cent in the polls I think sometimes you might want to do the right thing instead of the stubborn thing. Maybe it would go up a point or two.
If the government would agree to this hoist motion it would give Parliament an opportunity to sit down and to write a proper bill dealing with the restructuring of the federal Public Service, one that could probably be supported by all members, or most members in this House, and a bill that would be supported by the public servants themselves.
The problem is indicative of the treatment this government has levelled at Canada's federal Public Service. What this government has done is it has treated the federal public servants in this country as goats. Everything that this government has done that is wrong it wants to turn around and somehow blame a federal public servant for it.
My colleague from the New Democratic Party just said it a few minutes ago, we saw what it has done. It has caused the first general massive strike in our history of the federal Public Service. That is what it did a few months ago. Those very same individuals, and they are not radical unionists, are people who live on your street, Mr. and Mrs. Canada. That is who they are. All they are trying to do is an honest day's work for an honest day's wage.
This government, because of its crazy economic policies and the deficit that it drives up every second you breathe in this country, its tax policies, all those things have created climate that it has to strike out at somebody. So who does it strike out at? That is right. Those people who the government made goats of, those federal public servants in this country.
If you listen to the government opposite you would think the federal public servants are all getting $60,000 a year, work 25 hours a week and get a 50 per cent Christmas bonus. Well, it is not the case.
I can look around right here and see federal public servants who look after us in the House. There are not many of them who are making what I would call an over-generous allowance for the days that they work in this place, or in federal offices and institutions across Canada.
The government would have us believe that they are all fat cats in the federal Public Service and that somehow they are less deserving of fair treatment by this government than other citizens of Canada would expect from their government.
We forget that the people it forced out on strike with its zero, three and three policy were not $50,000 and $60,000 a year employees. By and large, they were women in lower income groups. They were women who were getting paid $17,000 to $21,000 or $22,000 a year.
They were forced out on strike because the government would not listen to them. It will take some of those women as long as one year or one year and a half to make up for the money that they lost. There was no gain, but they finally said: "Listen, we are not going to take this type of nonsense, even if we are going to lose money".
February 13, 1992

Somebody has to stand up here and say to this government that we demand fair treatment. We do not look for anything that we do not deserve, but we demand fair treatment. But this government has poisoned the atmosphere between those tens of thousands of public servants across this country and their own government, their own employer. It has practised types of labour relations that if they are not illegal they should be made illegal.
The government came in with this bill that we are currently debating. It put things in the bill that certainly, in my view at least, are going to lead not to a Public Service that is the watch-dog on government, but could lead to a Public Service management or senior officials who become the lap-dog of government.
There are more clauses in this particular bill that are offensive than probably in any bill that I have seen since I have been here. If you really look at it, the government had plenty of opportunity to do the right thing. It had plenty of opportunity to sit at the table with the Public Service.
I am not in government; I am in opposition. But somehow I have a sense of proprietorship over the Public Service of Canada because I am one of the people who vote in here on bills and regulations and legislation that affects Canadians. So I feel some collective sense of responsibility before we go in and restructure the Public Service to talk to those people who are going to be affected the most. This government obviously does not think that that should be the case.
The Conservatives have mismanaged their own credibility, these guys on the other side, that is what they have done. They are down to, what is it today, 14 per cent, 10 per cent, whatever it is.
It's 12 per cent.

It is 12 per cent is it, and it is dropping fast I understand, is that right? Dropping like a stone.
This particular bill is not one that I am going to be proud to say was passed through Parliament if indeed it does get passed while I was sitting here. I have a lot of public servants in my riding. They deliver damn good service for the little bit of money they get. They deserve a heck of a lot better treatment from the Government of
Government Orders
Canada, their employer, than what they have received over the last four or five years from this gang opposite.
Madam Speaker, how much time do I have left here? Am I getting close?
You have 20 more minutes.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: One and a half.

One and a half minutes. In conclusion to the members opposite, you have an opportunity here to do the right thing.
I do not like to lecture you, but you have an opportunity to do the right thing. I do not even know if there are
150,000	Canadians left who like the Tory government opposite. But there must be one or two people that the government members might be able to pull back onside by doing the right thing so they will not be embarrassed the next time they have to call up a CEC office.
When you annoy the people who work for you, they do not do the type of work or give that extra special push.
I ask the government to look at this amendment and to see the sense in the amendment, to pull this bill away from Parliament, to give it to a special committee of Parliament, a non-partisan approach to restructuring our Public Service in this country, and to invite all of the interested players in.
In that way this place will work properly and we will have a bill that adequately reflects the needs that we have as a nation in our Public Service and recognizes the great contribution that those people who serve in our Public Service make toward Canada.

Madam Speaker, first of all, let me say that in my experience as a member of Parliament I and my staff have been very pleased with the service we have received from individual public servants working both here in Ottawa and in my riding of Willowdale. They are very conscientious people. They care about their jobs. They care about the service they give; not everyone of course, but then not all members of Parliament are up to scratch. However, by and large we have been extremely well served on a day to day basis by our public servants who are trained, conscientious and caring.
Let us give the government some credit for having recognized that there are problems within our Public Service. A mountain of red tape and a bureaucracy and a

February 13, 1992
Government Orders
methodology have built up which actually hampers and retards the ability of our public servants to do the type of job they are equipped to do and which only they can do and want to do.
For example, staffing procedures are so complicated today in the Public Service that they take three times as long as the private sector. If you are going to switch a person from one job to another, it is estimated that it takes 105 days to staff a position in the Public Service using internal competitions. That is one third of a year. Even in Crown corporations the time taken is about half of that. This is unacceptable.
There are so many classifications of jobs in the Public Service and so much time is spent finding out which little bracket you fit into-who can apply, who is eligible-that about 40 to 50 per cent of all job positions require a complicated classification procedure with hearings, discussions and debate. As a result, more public servants look after hiring public servants in many areas than there are actual people doing the job.
The government has recognized some of these problems and so has the Public Service. So what do we get? We get PS 2000. The procedure was instituted from the top, where the top mandarins planned to give themselves more power. They proposed some laudable procedures to cut red tape but in instituting their reports and bringing them forward, they did not involve the Public Service, the people on the front lines. The civil servants of Willowdale that I have met with were not part of that discussion. It was a streamlined bureaucracy, but if you do not involve all of the people in the decision-making process, you are heading for disaster. That is what happened. The Public Service has balked.
The people in charge of PS 2000 pulled back a bit and what did they do? They brought in their tenth report, introduced by Mr. Rawson, who I think is a very capable public servant, and tried to change their course, gearing it toward public servants; service to the clientele and service to the public. However, this process lacked the involvement of the public servants themselves.
We are reaching a stalemate. The people do not like it. This is why we as the Official Opposition have called on the government to back off. Let us, as parliamentarians, have hearings so that we can get all of the people involved and develop a consensus because without the
co-operation of everyone involved-and you know this, Madam Speaker, in your work with this House and our staff- in the decision-making process they are not going to feel committed to the end result.
Let us look at how this government has treated its own staff. It has questioned the competence of its own public servants to do a number of jobs through contracting out, which is increasing rampantly. Rather than having people who are trained and on the payroll doing a number of jobs, it contracts out without any sense of accountability and without being able to explain to either parliamentarians, the Public Service, its own staff, or even its own labour pool why outsiders are better equipped to do it. Is this just an attempt to get rid of jobs in the Public Service? Until accountability becomes a criterion for contracting out, we have real reason to suspect, and so does the Public Service, that this is not in the best interests of either them or Canadians.
Then there was last summer's strike by public servants. This was when the government said: "Public servants, you get 0, 3 and 3 per cent increases, one, two, three years". At the same time the top tiers of the Public Service obtained reasonable increases or very big increases. What happened? The Public Service went on strike.
I believe the government knew that they would go on strike because that was the only alternative they had as a self-respecting body. I believe the government wanted them to go on strike so that it could legislate them back to work and take the political credit that it thought would be due to it as Ronald Reagan had apparently won the hard right in the United States when he ordered the air controllers back to work. I think the government was that cynical. If it was not that cynical, then it was just plain stupid. It knew its policies would lead to that result.
Then what do we see? The government brings in its prosperity agenda and makes a wonderful declaration: "We are going to work together; governments, business and labour to make Canada prosperous, to make Canada competitive". It asked labour to buy into its concept of what co-operation between management and labour and government is. It said: "Come and sit with us at the table". What do you think labour said? "No way, not the way you are treating your employees. We will have no
February 13, 1992

part of it because we've seen what your concept of co-operation involves".
Looking at the example that this government has set, in terms of its own relationships with its own employees, is it any example for Canada's private sector and dealings between management and labour in our private sector?
I have a dismal record to present to the House today. It comes from the World Competitiveness Report and looks at working days lost per 1,000 inhabitants. The 1986 to 1988 average looked at 33 different countries. Canada is at the bottom of the list in terms of the number of days lost per 1,000 inhabitants. I will be happy to table this if the Speaker wishes.
Let me just go through some of the shocking statistics. Looking at the G-7, Canada's record is by far the worst. We are 403 times worse than Germany, 99 times worse than Japan, 16 times worse than France, 4 time worse than the U.K., 3.4 times worse than the U.S.A., 2.7 times worse than Italy in terms of our record of days lost.
The government is considering a free trade deal with Mexico. Our record vis-a-vis Mexico is 93 times worse. How are we going to compete in this world if our record of days lost, of management-labour strife in the private sector, fueled by the example of the government in dealing with its own employees is the worst in the world? We just cannot afford it.
This is why the government's initiative, in perpetuating its pig-headed view of how it is going to dictate to its own public servants, is a failure. This is why we call on the government to back off.
The importance of all three sectors working together has been recognized by the government. May I just quote two paragraphs from the Liberal Party task force on deindustrialization and economic renewal. At page 25 we said: "In conclusion, the federal government must foster a new spirit of co-operation, collaboration and common purpose among all the partners in our economic future, including business, labour, education, finance, consumers, communities and governments themselves". In order to do that we gave a practical recommendation, recommendation 11, a new approach to industrial policy,
Government Orders
"that the government bring together the representatives of labour, business, education, finance, consumers, communities and governments to find ways to work in a spirit of co-operation and collaboration".
The best thing the government could do at the moment is accept our party's recommendation and send this whole matter of PS 2000 to a committee.

Madam Speaker, it is a pleasure to speak to Bill C-26, an act to amend the Public Service Employment Act, the Public Service Staff Relations Act and other acts in relation to the Public Service of Canada.
I want to say at the outset that I support the suggestion made by my hon. friend from Willowdale that the appropriate way to deal with this right now is to suspend further debate in the House of Commons and examine the implications very clearly in a special committee as to just what this legislation is all about. If anyone actually has read this legislation, has spoken to the people who are directly involved, he or she will realize that this is probably about the last piece of legislation we should proceed with in terms of developing and building the federal Public Service.
I will simply say that in the Kamloops area over the years, the dedication, professionalism and service to the public demonstrated by the federal employees has been nothing short of extraordinary. The people in Health and Welfare, Employment Canada, in the immigration department, Agriculture Canada at our research station, the airport employees, CMHC, the customs people, those working with Environment Canada and income security, those involved with fisheries, public works, to say nothing of the excellent service that we receive from Revenue Canada folks and those related with the Canadian Jobs Strategy out of Kelowna and Penticton are really outstanding, professional public employees.
These are people who have dedicated their lives to serving the public. They take that mandate very seriously. I would say that out of all the thousands of federal employees in our constituency offices, we virtually have never heard a complaint.

February 13, 1992
Government Orders
We have heard from time to time some concerns, but when we have examined and studied the situation, the concerns that people have had have been unfounded and misplaced. I could say that you would not find a more professional, committed group of employees anywhere, in spite of what the government has done.
I say that thinking back to not long ago, a few months back when we were entering into those contract negotiations. I suppose the ultimate in humiliation was when the employer said to the federal employees: "We feel you are not worth any increase in pay for this year. While we have given pay increases to others, and while the settlements generally in contracts being resolved around the country are coming in at somewhere between 3 and 8 per cent, we are going to offer you zero. As a matter of fact, not only are we going to offer you that, we will force that through legislation so that we do not really even have to bargain".
The signal that that sends to people who have dedicated their lives to serve the people of Canada was probably the most serious blow to morale that one could imagine. Read the books on management styles these days, study the manuals and attend the seminars on how to improve productivity in the work place, how to enhance morale and if you listen to all the things you should do. I suspect that this government does none of them.
This legislation allows the government to continue to contract out work. The government now spends in excess of $5 billion on contracting out. There is no accounting of this expenditure and no study of the cost effectiveness of this contracting out process.
This bill also increases the discretion of managers in the deployment of staff. It provides the mechanism for increased devolution of managerial responsibility and accountability and attacks the job security of public sector workers generally.
What it does not do is address the serious problems of low morale within the Public Service. It does not address the deterioration of service to the public that one is experiencing because of employee absenteeism, which my friend from Willowdale has pointed out is one of the highest in the world.
It does not do anything to modernize the collective bargaining process. Still the alliance will not be able to bargain issues of classification and staffing levels. What the workers want is to make staffing classification and deployment of staff a bargaining issue. It wants an adjudication process to hear grievances and an end to the contracting out of work. Yet this legislation goes against all of the concerns that people have registered, all of the wishes they have made clear, and imposes some Draconian form of management that is quite unbelievable.
My colleagues have identified a whole number of concerns that we have identified. Fundamentally I want to direct my concern today to the issue of pay equity. While Bill C-26 does not deal directly with reclassification, we all know that it does allow Treasury Board to define classifications. Treasury Board has made very clear its desire to implement the recommendation of Public Service 2000 to reduce the number of job classifications. While the unions agree with the principle they do not agree with the process. Treasury Board will not negotiate these reclassifications. As a matter of fact, Treasury Board will determine the appropriate bargaining units. This is contrary to other labour legislation including the Canada Labour Code which gives this power to the Labour Relations Board. We all know that Treasury Board has established the classification simplification task force. Its mandate is to develop a universal job evaluation plan capable of addressing pay equity as defined in the Canadian Human Rights Act, and to serve as the model in the development of most future classification standards. A single evaluation process is appropriate. However the last time Treasury Board agreed with the joint union-management initiative it backed off when the associated costs of pay equity were discovered and understood.
Once this classification is implemented, at least this is what PSAC certainly fears, the government will use sleight of hand to say that it has achieved pay equity without costing any money. Salary discrimination would basically disappear because the old female dominated and male dominated groups will have disappeared. The inequities are still there. They are just regrouped. The argument is totally fallacious.
PSAC believes that when it challenges the government's claim of achieving pay equity at the Human
February 13, 1992

Rights Commission it will win. However this will have delayed pay equity for a long time. In fact it will likely delay it for many years.
Here is an example. Part of the reclassification would result in a general administration group which will have approximately 116,000 employees performing a very wide variety of tasks. There would be six levels within that general administration group and each level would have its own salary range. The ranges will result from slotting the old jobs into the new six salary levels based on the old salary levels. This means that the lowest paid groups remain at the lowest levels and that the highest paid at the highest level, with females at the bottom and males at the top.
In other words Treasury Board will provide a new package for the existing out of date and discriminatory job classification system. Treasury Board officials have consistently referred to how the old groups will be slipped into the brand new system. It is this discriminatory system that is currently under view by the Human Rights Tribunal.
If this government were committed to pay equity then it would proceed with the equal pay adjustment guidelines passed back in 1986. As was recommended by the Canadian Human Rights Commission, these ought to be done on existing job classifications. We should not transfer the old wrongs into a whole new structure. We should make it right now that we have the opportunity.
In 1985 the joint union-management initiative on pay equity in the Public Service was established. The government paid an American consultant, Mr. Norman Wills, over $1 million. There were 50 to 60 Treasury Board employees who worked on the initiative and 40 paid persons from the union. The study showed the gross inequities between female and male dominated groups. The government ignored this study and used its own calculations of what the pay adjustments should be. PSAC disagreed totally, and rightly so, and decided to pull out in 1989.
The case went before the Canadian Human Rights Commission in October 1990. The commission decided there was merit to the case because government rates were not high enough and were not consistent with its own guidelines and therefore referred the matter to a tribunal. The tribunal will hear from PSAC and the
Government Orders
Professional Institute of Public Service of Canada, the Canadian Human Rights Commission, and Treasury Board. Although Treasury Board originally agreed with each step of the equal pay process, that agreement is now forgotten. Every step of the study process had to be painstakingly presented and justified before the tribunal in order to substantiate the equal pay complaints.
Each party can and will call witnesses and cross-examine. This will result in an extremely lengthy process and likely will continue into the fall of 1992 and perhaps even into next year.
In conclusion, I will simply say that while women represent half the world's population, provide two-thirds of the world's labour, and produce half the world's food, they receive only one-tenth of its remuneration and they own a mere 1 per cent of its property.
This is a chance to rectify some of these past wrongs. We should be acting on pay equity in a very serious way.

Madam Speaker, this is the first time I am addressing the House in my new role as labour critic for the Official Opposition. I hope my remarks will not be taken in a spirit of condemnation but as trying in my own way to enlighten the ministers who are here and my colleagues.
It is sans dire that over the years there has been a push to have co-operation between management and labour, labour and government, and management and government. A few years ago it was called tripartitism, but it is a recognition that those people in the position of making decisions which affect the welfare of all Canadians should be working together.
Today we are discussing in large part the public servants of Canada. I would like to put into perspective what the government says it is attempting to do and what our views are with regard to its attempt. It is my view at the outset, and my colleagues have pointed this out, that our public servants over the years have done an admirable job under circumstances which were not always the best.
This move the government is making is not designed to boost morale, and much less productivity. As a matter of fact I believe, with all respect to the minister, that it is counterproductive.

February 13, 1992
Government Orders
Let me quote from the backgrounder to Public Service 2000 put out by the government. The Public Service Reform Act, Bill C-26, was introduced in the House on June 18. Today we are debating its particular merits. The government claims that the legislation will streamline outmoded legislative rules which control collective bargaining, staffing in the Public Service which I want to deal more specifically with in my address, human resources management, and the disposal of surplus assets.
The Chair should be aware that I intend to introduce for greater scrutiny at a later time in this debate the third topic which I mentioned. What I want to deal with today is the whole theory of merit pay.
The government has said that the goal of PS 2000 is to eliminate a good part of internal red tape and the cumbersome and far too numerous checks and doublechecks and to reduce the unnecessarily long chain of command to get approval for straightforward transactions. I am in favour of that. My party is in favour of that.
It is incumbent upon us to take obstacles out of the way of the clients whom the public servants are there to deal with.
Changes to the operations of the Public Service have already begun. I agree with that. I do not agree that they have been done under the best of circumstances. While rules and regulations are being examined I am wondering how much input the public itself has had on these changes.
I am now quoting. This is what it says: "The person on the front line at the service counter is going to have more freedom of action and the chance to use common sense and good judgment in helping Canadians to count on the government for services". Well, of course. However haven't our public servants always used good judgment? Haven't they always used common sense? I suggest that they have. I suggest that many times we have not given them the proper tools to carry out the work we ask of them. It also says: "The federal government is the largest employer in Canada". It will probably continue to be. It continues: "The daily work of its employees affects every region and all communities in the country".
I want to put on the record a few of the statistics we have been given by the government. Two-thirds of public servants are based in communities across Canada, which means that they are external to those who are living and working here in Ottawa. Perhaps erroneously it has been said that Ottawa is a fat cat city. This is where the public servants are supposed to be living high on the hog. I would suggest to the minister, to my colleagues in the House and to all Canadians that for the most part our public servants are not overpaid. In my view there could be a great debate to say that they are overworked in many circumstances. We are asking them to do more with less. That is a principle I believe we cannot condone.
Since most public servants are based in cities and towns across the country and are delivering what I call very good services every day, they should be recognized for the work they have done. They have been providing top quality work, and they have been providing cost effective and efficient services to their communities.
I set that up as the basis for my remarks today because I want to put on record the Liberal view of the Public Service. Those in my party believe that Canadians deserve accessible quality services which are delivered efficiently by a professional, non-partisan Public Service which treats all employees with respect and fairness. It must be responsive to the needs of Canadians because their raison d'etre is to help the people of Canada when they are having difficulties vis-a-vis the federal government.
My Liberal Party is committed to the partnership between the public sector and the private sector and to the partnership between the government and its employees on whom it relies for policy advice and to carry out the programs, the services and the regulations mandated by this Parliament.
We support revitalization. We support the renewal of the Public Service to allow it to adapt better to rapid change. Most of all we wish to create an environment in which the employees can be creative, innovative, responsive and adaptable to the changing needs of their clients and to the nation.
It should also be noted that we hope to be able to attract and to retain competent, dedicated employees. When we say "dedicated employees", I know from

February 13, 1992

having visited many of the offices in my riding and in neighbouring ridings that these front-line troops are under a great deal of stress and pressure. Over the years and still today they are performing admirably well in an economic situation which leaves a great deal to be desired.
The Liberal Party believes that change can best be managed in a climate of mutual trust, co-operation and consultation with its employees. That includes respect for basic collective bargaining rights. This was not shown to be so when unilaterally the government imposed a wage freeze for our public servants with some increases, at least it says now, of 3 per cent in the second and third years. I am not as sure and as confident as some members that this will come to fruition.
Perhaps this government, feeling a greater pinch if the economic situation does not improve, will once again be turning to our public servants to use as scapegoats, as people it can put the blame on when all the time what these people are doing is carrying out their responsibilities in a milieu, in an atmosphere which is not always conducive to working as hard as they want to.
We, in the Liberal Party, are committed to accountability to Parliament and to the public for the use of both human and financial resources.
I turn now to the merit principle. The Liberal Party supports the merit principle and will oppose the government's efforts to reintroduce patronage and favouritism to the Public Service.
I notice, Madam Speaker, that you are indicating that my time is running out, but I do give notice to all members of Parliament that I intend to enter this debate again when we continue our deliberations in the House.

Madam Speaker, I would like to respond to some of the comments that some hon. members have made about contracting out.
First of all, I find them to be somewhat misleading and that is indeed very unfortunate. The Government of Canada believes it should deliver its programs and services in the most cost-effective way possible. To do this, it is sometimes advantageous to have work done by able Canadians in the private sector. This has occurred since Confederation.
With restraint and budget cuts to the operating costs of departments, managers are seeking the most cost-effective means of program delivery, using an appropriate mix
Government Orders
of resources, just as they are doing in the business community.
There are many areas in which contract work is clearly both proper and desirable, such as projects of relatively short duration. It makes no sense to hire a plumber on a permanent basis if one visit is all that is needed to fix the problem. Second, perhaps the workload fluctuates throughout the year or from year to year in a given location such as snow removal or where there is a sudden and unforeseen workload generally speaking. These are areas where contracting out is not only desirable, it makes common sense.
The government is also committed to a world-class career Public Service. Are these two imperatives incompatible or mutually exclusive? I think not and I would like to look at the issues surrounding them in some detail.
First of all, what is contracting out? Opposition members and the Public Service Alliance of Canada have said that the government contracts out $5 billion worth of work per year. At least, the Alliance said $4 billion back when the bill was introduced last June. Today it says $5 billion. Neither figure is realistic so it really does not matter.
Assuming the figure quoted is derived from some official source, such as the public accounts, then the figure has to do with contracting, not just contracting out. If it is contracting, the figure would appear to include huge national defence contracts, capital projects and major construction work performed by private sector companies and the costs assessed when one government department contracts with another to perform work; for example, when Transport Canada contracts with Public Works Canada for offices for its employees and other facilities.
Real contracting out, in any meaningful term, is only a fraction of this alleged sum. So while the government does not have the staff necessary to compile and maintain exact figures on all types of contracting and contracting out costs, hon. members can be assured that the government is not attempting to hide figures it does not have.
So why are the unions and some members of the opposition bringing the issue up in the context of Public Service renewal? Contracting out occurs where work formerly done by Public Service employees is performed by the private sector on behalf of the Public Service as the result of a contract. This is what has caused govern-

February 13, 1992
Government Orders
ment unions some concerns in the past. But contracting out does not represent a significant threat to jobs in the federal Public Service. Since 1984 less than 1,500 employees out of a work force of 215,000 people or so have lost their employment in the federal government as a result of their work having been contracted out.
For the last fiscal year, only 154 employees out of the entire Public Service of Canada-that is right across the country-were involuntarily laid off for any reason, including contracting out.
Why does the government have such an enviable record of placing its surplus employees? A comprehensive and highly successful work force adjustment policy has historically provided excellent protection to employees who are declared surplus for any reason, including as a result of contracting out work.
The policy has achieved a 99.5 per cent rate of employment security, one the highest rates in Canada. This is not a job for life, rather it is a recognition that a large employer can usually accommodate most of its surplus staff if those employees are willing to be flexible and take another job elsewhere in the system.
It is the same with responsible employees in the private sector and examples abound. For instance, it should come as no surprise that when General Motors opened its new production plant in Tennessee to assemble the new Saturn automobile, it staffed the plant almost entirely with surplus and laid-off employees from Flint, Michigan operations.
The issue seems to be what kind of protection do current government employees have when their jobs are contacted out and do the provisions of Bill C-26 in some way erode or undermine this protection? The answer is a resounding no.
It has been suggested that somehow Bill C-26 if enacted would become some sort of charter, enabling government to contract out at will and jeopardize the employment of Public Service employees. This is simply not so. It seems most unfortunate that so much heat and confusion has been generated over this issue and debate time wasted when no change of any real significance is occurring through these legislative proposals.
Let us look at the facts. What Bill C-26 does is recognize by amendment to section 29 of the Public Service Employment Act that movement of a function outside of the Public Service can constitute the discontinuance of a function and therefore can legally lead to the possible eventual lay-off of employees whose jobs are so affected.
This change becomes necessary because of the so-called Cantin case concerning the contracting out of the work of data processors in the department of customs and excise that was taken by the Public Service Alliance of Canada first to the Public Service Staff Relations Board and hence to the Federal Court of Canada.
These cases which went against the employer were decided on the technical wording of a section concerning contracting out. However, it is both interesting and important to note that the Federal Court decision contained a strong suggestion that moving jobs outside the Public Service did not constitute a discontinuance of a function within the meaning of the work force adjustment policy and by extrapolation within the meaning of the Public Service Employment Act.
This went contrary to all previous government interpretation, practice and thinking and indeed the Treasury Board has sought and received leave to take the Federal Court of Appeal's decision to the Supreme Court of Canada.
In consultations leading to a renewed National Joint Council work force adjustment directive in December 1991 these issues were fully and frankly discussed. The employer's aim in these consultations was to reach a new agreement with the unions that would ensure the government's right to contract out while at the same time protecting the rights of surplus employees.
In this regard the government announced in the February 26, 1991 budget:
-should agreement not be reached through negotiation, the government is prepared to introduce the necessary legislation to remove barriers to contracting out.
The government was determined that contracting out would remain one option among many available to it to deliver its programs to Canadians.
February 13, 1992

As it turned out, an agreement was reached with all government unions through the National Joint Council. The new directive contains enhanced job security provisions which ensure that no one whose job was contracted will lose their employment security within the Public Service except under the most extreme circumstances or where such people had failed to co-operate with the employer's attempt to place them in alternative positions in their home area.
In short, all that Bill C-26 does is clarify in law what has already been agreed to between the unions and management through the National Joint Council; that is, if and when work is contracted out, such actions cause a bona fide discontinuance of a function within the Public Service of Canada and employees affected are protected.
Another aspect of the work force adjustment directive that is of note is the provision which guarantees that as soon as senior management of a department has decided to examine the viability of a contracting out option with regard to a departmental operation, the relevant bargaining agent or agents will be informed. The directive also guarantees that where departments undertake cost benefit analyses with regard to the consideration of a contracting out option, the analysis shall be done consistent with professional principles and practices and according to standards acceptable to the Treasury Board.
As soon as possible after tenders have been received and analysed, the department shall disclose to the relevant bargaining agents the reason behind the decision to go ahead with contracting out work, including any cost benefit or feasibility studies that may have been undertaken.
If this is not bending over backward to be fair and open with employees and the representatives, I do not know what is. The only caveat on this, and it is a most proper one, is that most departments will not share those parts of such studies that fall under the exemption provisions of the Access to Information Act concerning third party information.
All of these provisions are new. They are in addition to the information in Part III of the Estimates already available to hon. members and the public, including unions, which already provide information on significant changes in financial requirements, type of resources
Government Orders
used and means of program delivery and they are in addition to the considerable information on professional and special services contracting expenditures that is already disclosed in the public accounts.
This disclosure details for each program the total amount spent on professional and special services together with detailed listings concerning individual and aggregate payments of significant size.
To sum up, first, charges made during the second reading debate on this bill to the effect that the government contracts out billions of dollars worth of work that its employees could do just as well are unfounded. So too are charges that the government is unwilling to provide any information it may already have on the subject.
Second, the government's work force adjustment directive continues to provide comprehensive protection for surplus employees whose jobs may be contracted out in the future.
Finally, nothing in Bill C-26 in any way erodes the employment security of current Public Service employees. That is, the change proposed to section 29 of the Public Service Employment Act merely recognizes in law what already has been effected de facto by the mutual agreement between the employers and its union.

Madam Speaker, it is an honour for me to participate in the debate on this very important bill.
Let me reiterate for the sake of the public record that I worked as a broadcaster and journalist at the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation for almost 20 years. I suppose, in the eyes of some people that would have made me a federal public servant. Not so, because as you know, the CBC is a Crown corporation. Moreover, I spent more than half of my time at the CBC on long-term contracts. So I was not a civil servant. However, because of my work as a broadcaster and journalist, I certainly came in contact with public servants almost daily in my long career in broadcasting and I am certainly in contact with them as a politician.
I think I can say, without reservation and without hesitation, that civil servants are committed people, committed to their work. They are loyal and hardworking. Really, when you come right down to it, they are more or less just like all Canadians. Most Canadians are

February 13, 1992
Government Orders
committed to their jobs. Most Canadians are hardworking and federal civil servants are no different.
I know that in the work I am doing now and in my relations with offices like the Canada Employment Centre or the immigration services or Revenue Canada, all the government offices that we have to work with on a daily basis, these are people who are dedicated and provide in the main a pretty good service. I want to put that on the record because if this bill is passed in its current form it would certainly affect their lives.
Public servants are telling us that they do not want this bill in its current form. They want it changed. It is incumbent upon us to take a veiy serious look at this bill and do it in a way that will provide very good results down the road and make it a much better bill. There is strong opinion out there that this bill is in bad shape.
Among other things that is one of the reasons we in the Liberal Party are asking that we get this bill out of the House and turn it over to a special committee. I will have more to say about that in a moment.
Something has gone wrong in the Public Service in the past few years. Something terrible has gone wrong. The morale is very low. In fact the air is virtually poisonous. That is how bad the morale is. The trust has been lost.
I suspect one of the reasons for that is the suspicion of public servants with regard to this government. They are suspicious about government policy. They are suspicious about the government's intentions. They are certainly suspicious about the government's ideology. They are in effect saying: "We have seen what the government has done with respect to free trade. We have seen what the government has done with respect to the GST. We are seeing what the government is doing in the area of the GATT as it pertains to supply management".
What are they seeing? They are seeing a government committed to privatization. They are seeing a government committed to the open market system. Public servants are very suspicious. That is why they want this bill vetted, examined, scrutinized to the nth degree.
One of the things that contributed in a major way to the current low morale, to this poisoned atmosphere, was the strike that occurred last year. Perhaps that was the low point in government-employee relations in many years.
Government more or less announced in its budget earlier last year or in effect told public servants: "Your collective bargaining rights are cancelled. You are going to get zero this year. Sorry about that, but you are not getting any increase". That to me is tantamount to cancellation of collective bargaining rights. In fact some months after that the government's own staff relations board said that the government was bargaining in bad faith.
