All those opposed will please
say nay.
Nay.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext:
In my opinion the nays have it.
And more than five members having risen Madam Deputy Speaker: Call in the members.

AFTER RECESS

The House resumed at 2 p.m.
February 13, 1992

Mr. Speaker, this past weekend Lake Simcoe was the site of the 1992 World Ice Fishing Championships hosted by the town of Georgina.
This is the first time that this championship event has been held in North America and it is very appropriate that Georgina, the ice fishing capital of Canada, hosted this great event.
Over seven countries were involved in these championships taking place on Lake Simcoe at Jacksons Point and at Beaverton. The organizers worked very hard for over a year to make this event very successful. A new attendance record was set. Thousands of spectators were out on the ice this past weekend.
Families, residents and visitors created a winter carnival atmosphere that added to the festivities. The organizers and residents extended a hardy winter welcome to all visitors, demonstrating the warmth and hospitality so prevalent in this country.
Congratulations are in order for the town of Georgina for a job well done.
I have to ask the hon. member for York-Simcoe: Who was on the side of the fish?

speakeroldname: Mr. Brian L. Gardiner (Prince George-Bulkley Valley):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Canadian forest industry is once again threatened by U.S. retaliation against our softwood lumber exports.
The second decision by the Americans on whether we unfairly subsidize our lumber or have caused injury to U.S. markets is now scheduled to be made on March 5. Canada has filed over one million pages of evidence in order to make our case.
The federal government says not to worry, the free trade agreement will save us. Given the failure of the trade deal, Canadians and forest communities across the country should be concerned. Free trade has failed Canada and we must keep pressure on our own
government so that it does not sell out our forests and our forest communities again.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Youth); Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, dear colleagues, many Canadians follow with interest the performance of our athletes at the Olympic Games in Albertville. I believe that it is appropriate to take a few moments to pay tribute to some of our most dd&erving athletes.
Tbesday evening, we watched with great emotion the performance of our figure skating couple, Isabelle Bras-seur and Lloyd Eisler, both from Boucherville, Quebec. They won the bronze medal. They kind of "broke the ice", since it was the first medal for Canada in skating since the Olympic Games in 1964.
Beyond medals, it is appropriate to mention the performances of two of our athletes who have obtained the best results ever by Canadian athletes in the history of the Winter Olympic Games. I am talking about biathlete Steve Cyr of Val-Belair, Quebec, who finished eighth in the 10-kilometre event, and Rob Crossan of Barrie, Ontario, who finished 12th in the alpine combined event.
Before I conclude, Mr. Speaker, let me tell you how pleased I am that our hockey team continues to do very well. Indeed, the Canadian team won its first three games and remains undefeated.
I therefore ask you, Mr. Speaker, as well as my colleagues in the House, to give a big hand to our athletes for their results so far at these games.

Mr. Speaker, tomorrow is the third anniversary of the FATWA, the death sentence put on Salman Rushdie and all those associated with the publication of his novel Satanic
Verses.
Last March the 15 Khordad Foundation doubled the bounty to $2 million U.S. for the killing of Salman Rushdie. This foundation is a non-governmental organization authorized by law to operate in Iran.

February 13, 1992
The Iranian government has not condemned the bounty nor has it suspended authorization for the 15 Khordad Foundation to operate. Implicitly, the Iranian government condones the bounty for the assassination of a British citizen.
In spite of this, not only has our government not suspended trade, but it has increased trade with Iran and is actually normalizing diplomatic relations. The government is in a profoundly hypocritical position. Beyond the Rushdie affair our government continues to trade with and do business with a country whose human rights abuse*are widespread.
Canadians want to know: Has the minister for external affairs called in the Iranian ambassador to condemn the FATWA, the bounty on the head of Salman Rushdie or insisted on its removal conditional to furthering Canadian relations with Iran? Or are we just waiting for Salman Rushdie to die?

Mr. Speaker, last September I stood in this House and spoke on the issue of foetal alcohol syndrome.
This terrible condition attacks the infant children of women who have consumed alcohol during pregnancy. It can leave the infant physically and mentally retarded.
Having talked with many parents and care givers of these children, I am struck by the lifelong devastation on the victims as well as their families. The permanent brain damage that results from FAS produces severe anti-social behaviour.
Those involved are left with the despair of knowing that there is no effective therapy that can help socialize the victims of this condition.
It is tragic that these infants are bom with the effects of FAS, but what is even more tragic is that this can be prevented through simple awareness. Widespread education including mandatory labelling of all Canadian alcohol products would be a significant step in the right direction.

Mr. Speaker, this past September, the government cancelled the memorandum of understanding on exports of our softwood lumber to the U.S. and told us it was on solid footing in doing so.
As we all know, the MOU which was signed in 1986 called for a 15 per cent surtax on our lumber entering the American market. Yet within one month of the decision, the Americans lost the countervailing duty investigation and imposed measures which reinstated the 15 per cent tax for the provinces of Ontario, Saskatchewan and Alberta.
In other words, it took the U.S. one month to negate what it took us five years to do. This tax has devastated many communities in northern Ontario that rely on lumber for their survival.
While the government is spouting its glowing praise for free trade, it is allowing the Americans to dictate to us what our policy should be. Thousands of people find themselves in unemployment lines because of it.
Whatever happened to the secure access we were supposed to get with the free trade agreement? Indeed, if the government felt that it was on a solid footing in cancelling the MOU, why has it not responded in a more forceful manner to yet another attempt of harassment by the United States?
It is time that we started living up to the free trade agreement, the same way the Americans are.

Mr. Speaker, I am shocked by the statistics published recently on alcohol and drug use among teenagers. At the same time, it is comforting to watch a program such as Degrassi Talks. Seventy-four per cent of Canadian teenagers drink alcohol. Year after year, the primary cause of death among teenagers is drunk driving. Some 1,200 Canadians die each year because of drug abuse. In the program Degrassi Talks, you can see a 17-year-old former alcoholic relate her struggle, as well as a 20-year-old paraplegic tell how he was hit by a drunk driver. By discussing topics such as those in an open and frank manner, the actors
February 13, 1992

and production team directly help young Canadians and their parents.
Mr. Speaker, I congratulate them on their good work, and I congratulate Health and Welfare Canada and Minister Benoit Bouchard on sponsoring this useful project.

Mr. Speaker, a Sri Lankan Tamil, Mr. Velluppillai Jeyarahah, is scheduled for deportation today. I am appealing to the Minister of Employment and Immigration and the Secretary of State for External Affairs for clemency in this case. If Mr. Jeyarahah is returned to Sri Lanka, he is destined to die.
Mr. Jeyarahah came to Canada in 1989 and made a claim to be a convention refugee. At the initial inquiry, he was found to have both the eligibility criteria and the credible basis for his claim.
Ultimately, his request was denied and the leave to appeal to the Federal Court of Canada was dismissed. Mr. Jeyarahah has not made claim to the Minister of Employment and Immigration, apparently because he was ignorant of this final avenue for clemency.
Easily attainable human rights information on Sri Lanka states that this man, who is a Tamil male between the ages of 15 and 35, and who professes Hinduism will be considered a potential militant.
Having just returned from a human rights fact-finding mission to Sri Lanka, I can say that Mr. Jeyarahah faces certain death if he is returned.
I ask the minister: Please, on humanitarian grounds, give Mr. Jeyarahah a chance at life. This deportation must be stopped today.

Mr. Speaker, for several years this government has tried to undermine, circumvent and even dismantle the Assembly of First Nations.
During the 1985 constitutional round, the Nielsen report questioned whether the AFN spoke for its members and proposed cutting its funding.
Five years later the Mulroney government cut AFN core funding by 100 per cent.
In my three years in Parliament, I have watched the government refuse to meet with AFN on the budget, on specific claims issues, on post-secondary education, and on land claims issues.
If you recognize an aboriginal right of self-government, you have to deal with aboriginal representatives on a govemment-to-govemment basis. This means accepting the legitimacy of duly elected aboriginal leaders. It means not concluding agreements affecting First Nations without their consent.
Rather than questioning the legitimacy of the AFN leadership or threatening to exclude them from the constitutional process, perhaps the Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs should request an election to see whether he speaks for more than 12 per cent of Canadians.

Mr. Speaker, recent comments by Ovide Mercredi are deeply offensive to Quebec. He misrepresented the facts, both in Ottawa and Quebec City, which is unacceptable on the part of a political leader in the present context. Quebeckers exist as a people and, as such, are not a threat to any other nation or people.
In 1985, under the government of Rene Levesque, the Quebec National Assembly passed a resolution recognizing the existence of aboriginal nations. Experts in international law have all recognized Quebec's territory. The Quebec nation includes everyone living in Quebec, and the rights of aboriginal nations will be recognized under the constitution of a sovereign Quebec.
The ignorance, bad faith and contempt shown by Mr. Mercredi have no place in the current debate.

Mr. Speaker, a number of constituents in my riding sent me a letter in which they deplored the federal Income Tkx Act.

O.	31
According to a study published in 1989 by Statistics Canada, 69 per cent of married couples with children under 18 had an average disposable income that was $1,670 lower than if they had not been married to their spouse.
A committee on the family has been created by the Canadian government. The hon. member for Calgary North has proposed that the Minister of Finance introduce a new federal fiscal strategy for families, a proposal that is highly commendable. In fact, I was involved in the work done by the Conservative caucus on this matter.
Many family and religious organizations have criticized the present tax system as unfair, complex and inconsistent, especially in the way it taxes families.
I hope that in the next federal budget, the Minister of Finance will introduce a new federal fiscal strategy for families.

Mr. Speaker, tobacco is a killer. Each year it takes the lives of 38,000 of our sons, daughters, wives, husbands, and parents. What shameful waste.
This carnage is helped along by the tobacco smugglers who deal in a cut-rate murderous product. For the sake of health, hurrah for yesterday's proposed new $1 per package export tax on Canadian cigarettes. Hurrah, as well, for high fines for smugglers. But as usual, this cash-starved government has dealt with the symptoms and not the cure.
I urge the government to take some of the billions of dollars collected in cigarette taxes and return them to the people who are addicted.
Fund workshops, counselling, toll-free help lines for those trying to break free. Fund nation-wide public education campaigns. Help smokers to quit. I tell this government: Do not just take their money and then turn your back.

Mr. Speaker, I recently conducted a survey in my constituency and received thousands of comments from citizens.
Alexander Burke of Burlington writes: "Like the Japanese and Swedes and Swiss, we need to build a social contract between government, labour and business to form an us-against-the-world team. We are too confrontational and while we all defend our rights and fight among ourselves, there are other nations and groups taking over the economic world".
This is a theme shared by Ian Graham, a business owner in Inglewood, Ontario. His advice is this: "Hang tough on the budget, get your financial house in order and tell the straight goods. Like the Japanese foreign minister said, our workers are lazy and 30 per cent illiterate. Let's not avoid the issue. Canadians have grown soft from decades of living off our natural resources".
My constituents have a great deal of wisdom to impart and it is my honour to bring their words to this House.

Mr. Speaker, it is not often that an opposition member can rise in this place and say that this government has done something that is appropriate and essential. But I am doing so today because the government has announced it will impose an export tax of $8 a carton to stop cigarettes from being smuggled back into Canada.
The smuggling of Canadian cigarettes from the United States has become an international racket which has promoted organized crime, undercut small Canadian retailers and undermined government revenues and anti-smoking campaigns.
A coalition of eight health groups and I have repeatedly called for an export tax of $10 a carton. In November, the minister of privatization said export taxes were not being considered. However, by February 3 the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Finance said our proposal was being reviewed.
February 13, 1992

The government has now imposed an $8 export tax despite strong pressure from the tobacco lobby. It is not the full amount we wanted, but eight out of ten is not bad.
I congratulate the Minister of National Revenue and the government.

Mr. Speaker, a one cent increase in the value of the Canadian dollar results in a $14 million sales decrease for our giant nickel producer Inco and puts the jobs of its 9,800 employees in jeopardy.
Inco, like all Canadian exporters, can to some extent at least to control its productivity and its labour costs, but it has no control whatsoever over the value of the Canadian dollar.
When the free trade agreement was signed, the Canadian dollar was worth 76 cents U.S. Today it is worth 85 cents U.S. When the free trade agreement was signed the spread between the Canadian and U.S. interest rates was less than 2 percentage points. Today it is almost 3 percentage points.
Sure we have problems with labour costs and productivity, but we cannot solve those in the short run. We can, however, lower the value of our dollar by reducing the spread between Canadian and U.S. interest rates.
Canadians can adjust to the free trade agreement. Canadians can compete. But we must have a level playing field as far as the value of the Canadian dollar is concerned. We appear to be our own worst enemy.
['Soon, Madam Speaker. The precise date I am not able to give now, but hopefully the Minister of Finance will be in a position to give the precise time very soon.']

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Deputy Prime Minister.
Everyone knows that Canadian farmers are the sacrificial lambs in an insane trade war between the United States and Europe. Now Canada has become the whip-
Oral Questions
ping boy in an absurd trade war between Japan and the United States.
The United States has decided to hit back at Japan by slapping a duty on Honda cars built in Canada. This is crazy. The government acts as if it was dealing with a technical problem when what we are watching is hardball politics in which Canada is being made the victim.
Does the Deputy Prime Minister even understand what is going on? If he does, can he do a little bit better than yesterday's mealy-mouthed statement that the trade minister was ascertaining the facts?

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, we agree with the hon. member that this is indeed a serious situation. We believe the audit that has been done on Honda was not done according to the rules of the FTA. We have made representations to the United States and will continue to do so.

Mr. Speaker, my question was directed to the Deputy Prime Minister because this is a matter that affects Canada's ability to export its cars to the United States. I am waiting for his answer.
On June 18, in this House, the Leader of the Opposition asked what the government intended to do to prevent Americans from imposing tariffs on Honda cars built in Canada. At the time, the government claimed it had the situation under control and even accused the Leader of the Opposition of scare tactics. Yesterday, eight months later, the Minister of Finance said that he was trying to evaluate the situation. Why didn't the Minister of Finance do his job eight months ago?

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in answer to the hon. member, we made our objections to the United States as recently as February 12. We had a special note delivered to the United States on this particular issue.
As the member knows, we have already launched one panel on mortgage interest and we are considering launching others.

Mr. Speaker, once again the great powers of Canada are falling on deaf ears.

February 13, 1992
Oral Questions
I direct my question to the Deputy Prime Minister because this is an issue that touches the livelihood of every auto worker in Canada.
The American presidential primaries start next week and candidates are falling all over themselves to see who can be the toughest on Japan, but Japan has strong leadership and instead Canada is being caught in the squeeze. While the government tries to get its act together, will the Deputy Prime Minister ensure that similar action is not taken against Canadian made Toyota, Suzuki, Hyundai or even GM products. Will he give us that assurance?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as my hon. colleague has just indicated to the hon. member, we disagree with the interpretation of the U.S. customs audit. We have served notice to that effect. We have done so in the form of a diplomatic note.
The most fortunate part of this is the fact that we do have a dispute resolving mechanism under the free trade agreement. The hon. member's leader wants to tear that agreement up. At least we have a fair and balanced method by which we can sort this out in an objective fashion.
As the minister pointed out, we have already launched an action under the disputes resolving mechanism under the free trade agreement and we will launch others if necessary.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Deputy Prime Minister. Canadian workers should not have to wait for up to three years for a panel to tell Americans that they should not be doing this sort of thing to Canadian exports.
The government said the reason we needed a free trade deal with the Americans in the first place was so that we would not have this kind of harassment.
Now that the Americans have set a precedent with Honda of Canada, what is to stop them from having this same kind of investigation and slapping the same kind of duties on cars made in Canada by the North American big three? For that matter, what is to stop them from doing this to any product of any kind made in Canada and destined for export to the United States?

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, there has never been any way that any country could be stopped from launching these kinds of investigations. The only thing that is different and which hon. members on the other side do not want to acknowledge is that now we have chapter 18 under the free trade agreement where we can launch a legitimate appeal.

Mr. Speaker, chapter 18 is cold comfort to the 1,500 workers at Honda in Alliston. Yesterday the Minister for International Trade assured us he would be approaching the Americans on this Honda issue "once he had ascertained the facts". The facts are clear. One is that the minister should have approached the Americans on this Honda issue eight months ago.
I ask the Deputy Prime Minister this. Has the Minister for International Trade spoken personally to U.S. trade representative Carla Hills about this Honda matter and has he pressed Canada's case vigorously? Why can the Deputy Prime Minister not tell us that the case has been resolved and we have nothing more to be concerned about, instead of the empty words of the Minister of State.

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the answer to the first part of that question is yes, the minister has spoken to the minister from the United States.
In answer to the second part of his question, we continue to press the United States on the issue. We believe it is not of concern because rules of origin should be settled under the free trade agreement.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Finance. There are new signs today of just how grim things are in the Canadian economy.
For the fourth time in four months manufacturing output has dropped sharply. In fact, employment in manufacturing has not been this low since October 1972 and the government's action today in pushing the bank rate up a further 13 basis points is just going to make things worse.
I want to ask the Minister of Finance this. Is the government prepared to let Canada become an indus-
February 13, 1992

trial wasteland or will it stop the ruinous increase in interest rates which keeps our dollar high and puts our people out of work?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I do not know where the hon. member has been over the last number of months. He knows that interest rates have fallen by about 7 percentage points since the high of May 1990. There has been considerable easing in monetary conditions, both on the interest rate side and the exchange rate side.
While there is some volatility in the markets at the present time, I think the hon. member would recognize that interest rates have come down, are staying down, and monetary conditions have moderated substantially.

Mr. Speaker, I am not sure where the Minister of Finance has been. I have been here in this country where there are
1.5	million people out of work, where the interest rate has gone up for the past three weeks consistently, week after week.
We have seen the Bank of Canada raise that interest rate. Yesterday the Economic Council of Canada said that this manufacturing decline will continue unless the government stresses training people, yet government documents show that big cuts are planned for many job training programs.
Will the government take the advice of its own former minister and ambassador for disarmament, Doug Roche, cut the defence budget by 10 per cent and reallocate this money to training programs that will put people back to work and rebuild our manufacturing sector.

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member should be reminded of the fact that Canada has the third lowest interest rates of all the G-7 countries.
The only two countries that have lower interest rates than Canada among the G-7 countries are the United States and Japan. Our intention is to get at the root causes of high interest rates by bringing inflation and inflationary pressures down. We have been somewhat successful, thanks to the efforts of the Canadian people and the workers of Canada. We now have a situation
Oral Questions
where there has been considerable monetary easing which should provide the basic groundwork for recovery.
The hon. member also knows very well that the Conference Board of Canada reported that of all the G-7 countries, Canada will have the best growth rate and the best recovery in 1992. It also pointed out the very serious difficulties that face the economies of all the industrialized world, particularly those of the G-7. It is a world-wide situation but Canada is well positioned.
I might also indicate further to an earlier question that automobile sales in the month of January have shown a 14 per cent increase over the month of December. That should be encouraging.

Mr. Speaker, the minister suggests that we have the third lowest interest rates and then points out that those countries that have lower interest rates are the very countries, the United States and Japan, with which we compete. Those are the countries that are important in this calculation.

I have a supplementary for the minister. The manufacturing sector has been hurting ever since this government came to power. The number of jobs in manufacturing is at its lowest ebb since 1972. When will the minister do something to get us out of the present economic recession that is affecting the entire country?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member indicates that two of the countries that we compete very vigorously against are the United States and Japan. That is quite true.
The Conference Board of Canada is convinced that we are going to compete quite well. The board points out in the growth projections for 1992 that Canada will have a
3.2	per cent real rate of growth, the United States 2.1 per cent, Japan 3 per cent, France 2.3 per cent, Germany 1.5 per cent, Italy 2 per cent and the United Kingdom 1.5 per cent. That is not a real satisfactory rate of growth, but it certainly is much better than the countries with which we compete. I indicate to the hon. member that while we share the concern that he has raised in the House of Commons, this is a world-wide situation. Canada is not alone in this situation. We are looking at a number of initiatives. As I have indicated on previous

February 13, 1992
Oral Questions
occasions, we have addressed the problems in the transportation sector.
I think we should move on.

Mr. Speaker, my question is to the Minister of National Revenue.
Yesterday the minister announced measures to reduce cross-border shopping. These measures only address the symptoms, not the disease. The major reason why Canadians are flooding to the United States is excessive taxation at home. The GST, the "go south tax", is forcing Canadians across the border while jobs and businesses are being lost here.
The minister should abandon his strong arm tactics in trying to get the provinces to harmonize their taxes with the GST. Why will the minister not at least lower the GST immediately with no strings attached?

speakeroldname: Hon. Otto Jelinek (Minister of National Revenue):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I do not know where the hon. member has been but the package that we announced yesterday, if he has read this morning's clippings, will show that shoppers get a tax break from Ottawa. "Duties ditched to fill shops", "Stores hail tariff cuts on imports", "Ottawa cuts import duties", ''Look for bargains", "Duties slashed $60 million", "Ikx cuts will keep shoppers at home". That is what we are doing for the consumers, Mr. Speaker.

Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary for the same minister. Yesterday, when the minister announced his program to crack down on cross-border shopping, he said that he would not introduce any additional taxes. Cross-border shopping is a symptom, a reaction-I would even say a Canadian revolt-against the tax burden imposed by this government. To stop this exodus, will the minister lower the disastrous goods and services tax?

speakeroldname: Hon. Otto Jelinek (Minister of National Revenue):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the point I made yesterday, which I confirmed today, is that there are no new or additional taxes for Canadian consumers shopping in Canada. In fact, we have reduced taxes by the elimination of tariffs on some 25 popular products, from VCRs to cameras and sporting goods. In fact, we have moved in a direction which has levelled the playing field and which has prompted business people from coast to coast, such as Steve Kahler, General Manager of Bleeker Stereo & TV Ltd. who said yesterday as a result of the announcement:
This means we could end up selling goods cheaper than in the United States. This is really good news. Maybe the tables will turn and we will have Americans coming to Canada to shop in Canada.

Mr. Speaker, today the bank rate went up 13 basis points. This is taking place at the same time as our unemployment is increasing to 10.4 per cent. It is taking place at the same time that we are losing thousands upon thousands of manufacturing jobs. As a matter of fact, over the past three years Canada has lost 325,000, or 15 per cent, of all its manufacturing jobs.
Will the Minister of Finance tell us this: Why is he deliberately increasing the interest rates to keep the dollar up, to keep it artificially high, because it is driving jobs south?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as I indicated earlier, the exchange markets have been volatile over the last week or so. It has put upward pressure on the domestic money market rates. The hon. member knows very well that there has been considerable monetary easing, both on the interest rate side and on the exchange rate side. The hon. member knows very well that the Bank of Canada intervenes only to smooth out any erratic fluctuations.
What we are seeing here are the forces of the market at play. The hon. member is quite familiar with that.

Mr. Speaker, my supplementary is to the Minister of National Revenue.
The U.S. charges Canadian companies $10 on mail order sales to U.S. customers. Under its new measures announced yesterday, this government charges American companies only $5 for mail order sales to Canadians. Why is this government giving a 100 per cent cost advantage to American companies?
The minister may have a family firm in Buffalo but he has no right to drive more and more Canadian jobs-
The hon. minister.

speakeroldname: Hon. Otto Jelinek (Minister of National Revenue):
speechtext:
My
hon. friend never ceases to surprise me. He is talking about the service fee imposed by the post office on a cost recovery basis. Because of the business plan that has been imposed by this government and the post office in this country, the post office in Canada is far more efficient than in the United States. Therefore we can charge a lower fee for Canadians.
Mr. Speaker, I wish to address this question through the Speaker who will be receiving a much deserved honour in Vancouver on Friday night.
I thank the hon. member, but the question had better be in order.

Last week and earlier this week I had several occasions to rise in this House to ask specific questions of the minister of trade relative to information access for members of this House and for the media to the draft bracketed treaty of the U.S.-Mexico free trade agreement pending.
Is the Acting Prime Minister willing to give this House and the press in Canada exactly the same access that the U.S. Congress has had to these documents? The Mexican Senate and the Mexican press have had two briefings and access to the documents. Is the government prepared to give exactly the same information briefings and
Oral Questions
access that both the senators in Mexico and the Congress members in the United States have had?

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the Minister for International Trade has stated in this House on many occasions that he is quite prepared to give a confidential briefing to members of the committee any time they ask for it.

Mr. Speaker, that is not the question that I asked. I am aware of the minister's offer.
The Mexican Senate and the Mexican press have access to this information. I have a letter from a Mexican senator detailing exactly what the Mexican Senate was briefed on and what the Mexican press was briefed on. We also have a note from a U.S. committee determining that there is no absolute confidentiality on the briefings in the United States.
I repeat: Is this government prepared to give exactly the same access to these documents that was given to the Mexican senators, the Mexican press and the U.S. Congress as the documents I have show?

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I would think that the reasonable thing for the hon. member to do is to first accept the minister's offer of the briefing and then take it from there. So far that offer has not been accepted.
Yes or no?

subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Deputy Prime Minister. Last Friday the Minister for International Trade told the House that he had not received any request from farm organizations for an impact study on the Dunkel proposals in the GATT negotiations.
Can the Deputy Prime explain why the minister told the House that when he knows full well that the president of the Canadian Federation of Agriculture, Ralph Jespersen, wrote to the minister on January 10 to ask on an urgent basis for an impact analysis on the Dunkel proposals, and what impact that would have on Canadian agriculture.

February 13, 1992
Oral Questions
Why did the minister tell the House that he had not received a request when he full well had?

subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is my understanding that the question that was answered by the Minister for International Trade was a question relating to the supply management agencies.
The agencies, as the hon. member knows, are not the Canadian Federation of Agriculture.

subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Canadian Federation of Agriculture is a massive umbrella organization.
In his letter, Mr. Jespersen said: "We are urgently requesting that your department make available to us its analysis of the potential impacts of the proposal on Canadian agricultural industry".
Thousands and thousands of farmers are fearful today that they are going to lose their farms, their livelihood, everything. I wonder why the minister and why the government are hamming around. Why is the government not making available immediately this impact analysis that the Canadian Federation of Agriculture has asked for.

subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member has to understand, and I know he does, that agencies which represent the supply managed industries have had a great deal of difficulty in coming to grips with efforts to stay united in presenting their front and their common cause. As you know, Mr. Speaker, as I am sure the hon. member does, agencies which have asked the government if it could provide information and we have agreed, provided they would work with us co-operatively, have said that they will only be able to make a decision after February 18.
Those agencies are having a difficult time arriving at a conclusion among themselves.

Mr. Speaker, I have a question for my good friend, the Deputy Prime Minister, about the Hibernia project.
He will probably know that one of the remaining Hibernia partners, Chevron, indicated yesterday that pulling out of the development altogether is an option for Chevron.
His colleague, the minister of energy, will be in Newfoundland tomorrow to deal with this Hibernia issue. I want to ask the minister what the government hopes to achieve by tomorrow's meetings in St. John's. Is it to keep the project intact? Is it to delay the project, or is it to back away from the project altogether?

speakeroldname: Mr. John A. MacDougall (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, as the hon. member knows, the minister of energy is in the province of Newfoundland today meeting with the premier of the province and the minister of energy. All companies involved in the project will be meeting tomorrow and at that time, discussions will be held.

Mr. Speaker, I thank the parliamentary secretary for repeating essentially what I said in the question. I want to put a supplementary to the Deputy Prime Minister.
He will know that his colleague, the minister of energy, said he foresees some delay in the project. He will also know that his other colleague from Newfoundland, the minister of fisheries, has said: "No. Business as usual. The minister of energy does not know what he is talking about". Now his colleague in the back benches there adds further to the confusion.
Does the Deputy Prime Minister not feel some obligation, given the great concern in Newfoundland over this issue, to send a clear signal on this issue? I will give him the opportunity to send this signal. More to the point, is the government still firmly committed to this project? What is it prepared to do to see it through to its completion?

speakeroldname: Mr. John A. MacDougall (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this government has been committed from day one in this project. The involvement of the companies and then-meetings tomorrow are critical to the future of this project.
February 13, 1992

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Minister of Finance. The present tax system is unfair, complex and inconsistent, especially in the way it taxes families. A number of constituents in my riding sent me a letter in which they indicated that 69 per cent of married couples with children under 18 had an average disposable income that was $1,670 lower than if they had not been married to their spouse. Is the minister prepared to say whether his officials are examining a new federal strategy for family taxation and whether we can expect the details in the next federal budget?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to thank the hon. member and other hon. members who have been working on this committee headed by the hon. member for Calgary North looking into the taxation of families for the veiy good work that they have done.
We have had the opportunity of meeting with the committee and officials have been examining a number of their recommendations.
I can assure the hon. member that we are taking their recommendations seriously, as we have taken other recommendations seriously in the context of the prebudget consultation. The answer to the hon. member is yes.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Acting Prime Minister.
Mexico's bad record on human rights has not improved in the past year according to this week's report of the Inter-Church Committee on Human Rights in Latin America. They point to fraud and violence in elections and against democratic union movements and institutional torture by the police of Mexico.
Will the Acting Prime Minister assure this House that Canada will not sign a North American free trade agreement until such time as there is international verified progress in respect for human rights in Mexico,
Oral Questions
including free and fair elections, in keeping with the headlines that the Prime Minister won for supporting democracy and human rights in Paris?

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, we are aware of the hon. member's concern in this area. Other members are concerned about environment and other such things.
As he probably knows, discussions are going on among the three countries about all of these issues.

A supplementary, Mr. Speaker.
In order to encourage better practice of human rights,
I would like to ask the Acting Prime Minister if this government will invite Mexican and U.S. governments to send electoral and human rights observers to Canada before and during our elections in return for a matching invitation to the Canadian government to send electoral observers to their elections?

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister responsible for Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I am certain the Secretary of State for External Affairs would be pleased to take the member's suggestion under advisement. I will be sure that she is informed of his views in this matter.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of National Health and Welfare.
A few moments ago the Speaker of the Senate ruled that a private member's bill which had been passed unanimously by this House on a recorded vote and which-

Just a moment. I am having some difficulty with the question. It refers to matters in the other place. Perhaps the hon. member can put the question on a substantive basis and leave out the references to which he has been alluding.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker.
A short time ago this House passed unanimously a private member's bill which provided that late applicants be allowed to receive Canada Pension Plan disability pensions.

February 13, 1992
Oral Questions
That matter is now in question as a result of developments in other places. I would like to ask the Minister of National Health and Welfare if the government would immediately move to introduce a government bill similar to the private member's bill so that some 4,000 disabled Canadians can receive the disability pensions that they have already paid for?
Before the minister answers, I just want to observe that, with the co-operation of the Chair, genius will out.

speakeroldname: Hon. Monique Vezina (Minister of State (Employment and Immigration) and Minister of State (Seniors)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Seniors); Minister of State (Employment and Immigration)
speechtext:
You
will allow me, Mr. Speaker, to pay tribute to my colleague on the right for his great compassion and tireless dedication to protecting those in need. That being said, I was with the Minister of National Health and Welfare at the latest federal-provincial meeting and at that time he received the authorization and approval of the provinces. He will correct that anomaly and to this end an important amendment should be introduced as early as the beginning of next week.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, my question is for the government House leader. What does he propose to do with the recommendations of the Royal Commission on Electoral Reform and Party Financing that were tabled this morning in the House?

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext: As the hon. member I am sure is aware, on matters like this which affect all of us equally as elected representatives, we would want to have the views of members from all sides of the House. Therefore, we will be referring the royal commission report to a committee of this House as soon as we get the committee established. We anxiously look forward to their recommendations.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my supplementary is to the same minister.
Will the minister advise the House what schedule he is planning to ensure that the committee reports in time for the next election? Will he undertake to provide support for the bill should the committee propose a unanimous report to this House?

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the one thing that students of this institution know very well is that delays in proceeding with legislation seldom occur from this side of the House.
Oh, oh.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext: I am appreciative of what I hope is a commitment from the other side that on this piece of legislation that at least they will be interested in assisting the government.

Mr. Speaker, my question is to the Minister of Communications. Citing selected figures which he called staggering and devastating, John Crispo, a member of the CBC board of directors, implied that official bilingualism is working against unilingual English Canadians in their hope and wish of getting high level federal jobs.
Nonsense.

That is not true. We know that. Will the government explain how it can tolerate having an outspoken critic on important government policy affecting national unity as a member of a board of directors of a Canadian corporation as important as the CBC.

Mr. Speaker, the government's position with regard to bilingualism is abundantly clear. We support bilingualism. We support equity within the Public Service to ensure that all peoples have a fair opportunity of having employment in the Public Service.
Mr. Crispo's comments were made not as a representative of the CBC, but as a private individual on a private broadcasting outlet.
Oh, oh.

Just a moment. This matter has been raised before in the House. As a consequence, with the co-operation of all hon. members, there was some
February 13, 1992

Oral Questions
indication that if properly pursued, the question could be put. The hon. minister is trying to answer the question. I think that after all we have put into this, hon. members owe it to the minister to listen to the answer.

Mr. Speaker, I would underscore the fact that in this instance, Mr. Crispo was speaking as a private individual on a private broadcasting outlet. It would be a remarkable change from the traditions of this Parliament and of government if we were required to censor the personal views of appointees to Crown corporations, government boards and commissions.
One of the things that makes Canada such a wonderful place to live in is that we have freedom of speech, including the freedom of speech of individual citizens to disagree with the position of the Government of Canada.

Mr. Speaker, since the minister says that the government does not endorse John Crispo's divisive statements on official languages, an important government policy, will he ask John Crispo to resign from his position as a director of the CBC?

Mr. Speaker, the implications of doing what the hon. member would suggest would be of interrogating members of all boards, commissions and Crown corporations with regard to their points of view. If they disagreed with the position of the Government of Canada, they would be rendered ineligible to serve as members of boards of Crown corporations. That obviously would be a form of censorship which would not be acceptable to Canadians.
The government's position is clear. We have consistently supported bilingualism in Canada. We have consistently taken the position that all Canadians must be treated with equity and we have consistently taken a position in favour of freedom of speech in Canada.

subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Minister of State for Agriculture. Some time ago, Canadian farmers and milk producers received a message from the government, signed by the minister and some of his colleagues, which said that Canada's supply management system was not for sale and would not be bartered. The government would not abandon a system that was recognized and respected by all its trading partners abroad, because it was an essential part of its long-term agricultural policy.
Are the signatures of the minister and his colleagues still worth something? Are their signatures worth more than the paper they are written on?

speakeroldname: Hon. Pierre Blais (Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Minister of State (Agriculture)):
speakerposition: Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Minister of State (Agriculture)
subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, we spent most of the time yesterday discussing this matter, and I believe that last night, parliamentarians on all sides of the House decided to firmly support the government's position at the GATT talks. I believe I am not being partisan if I say that for the past two years the federal government has fielded a position that was developed jointly with Canadian farmers. We supported that position, we defended it, and we continue to do so. I think that deserves to be said, and I am convinced that even people who have a different vision of Canada should fully support what we are doing at GATT.

subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, farmers don't want to hear about the position that has been discussed for the past two years. They all know it by heart. What they want to know about is the results and whether you stand by your commitment. Do you intend to abide by that commitment, and when the time comes to sign the final agreement, will you refuse to sign any agreement at GATT that threatens supply management? Yes or no?

speakeroldname: Hon. Pierre Blais (Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Minister of State (Agriculture)):
speakerposition: Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Minister of State (Agriculture)
subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I don't need any lessons from the associate of a former minister who, when he was minister in 1984, was unable to come up with a long-term dairy policy for

February 13, 1992
Oral Questions
Canadian farmers. We put that policy in place as soon as we were elected, and we maintained the supply management system. Furthermore, I think our position is quite clear, and Canadian farmers know our position. We will continue to defend it, bearing in mind, and this is important, that because of the present wording of article XI, our yogurt and ice cream are threatened as a result of a GATT ruling. That is why the status quo is unacceptable and why we must seek a new version of article XI. So that is what we are doing, Mr. Speaker, and I would urge the hon. member to support us in that endeavour.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Employment and Immigration. As the minister knows, a review is taking place within his department at the moment of immigration rules and, indeed, beyond that. The minister will know the medical and scientific community opposes mandatory testing of potential immigrants for AIDS and HIV and that the Department of National Health and Welfare opposes mandatory testing as well.
There is some concern that the review might lead to a recommendation that mandatory testing should be introduced. Will the minister confirm today that no matter what the review process says, he will not permit mandatory testing for HIV and AIDS of potential new immigrants to Canada.

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the hon. member is referring to a purely hypothetical question. If there ever becomes a need to consider that question, the government will do it in consultation with all concerned.

Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary question relating to the question from the hon. member for Kingston and The Islands on the report today on electoral reform. I
understand from the minister's answer it is going to be referred to committee. I have not read the report, therefore I want to hold my rights about a point of privilege. I understand in a general way that the report confirms my position, about which I wrote to the minister. I have had the courtesy of replies from several ministers that there is a very fundamental discrimination against independents collecting money because they cannot give receipts until the writ is issued.
I really hope that the House leader can confer with the other House leaders to remedy that problem before we get involved in the other issues so that we will not have to try to prevent the raising of all money for all parties.

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
The hon. member has written to me on this issue and I generally agree with him. He should not be embarrassed about not having read the report. It was just tabled at ten o'clock and is a thousand pages. There is a lot of material there.
I hear the hon. member's representation. I certainly will pass it on to the committee.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the Minister of Agriculture. A few moments ago the minister said in reply to a question by the member for Algoma in regard to the impact study of the Dunkel proposal that none had been requested by the five agencies in question.
How then can the minister explain the letter that I have in hand, written to him or to the minister of international trade, asking the very thing, signed by Louis Balcaen, president of the Dairy Farmers of Canada? The letter states:
I am writing to you on behalf of Daily Fanners of Canada, the
Canadian Broiler Hatching Egg Marketing Agency, the Canadian
Chicken Marketing Agency, the Canadian Egg Marketing Agency-
Is this not slightly at odds with what the minister said, to put it kindly?
February 13, 1992

subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
It may
be, Mr. Speaker, that the hon. member will not believe this, but occasionally people change their position.
A meeting was held on January 22 with representatives of the Canadian Chicken Marketing Agency, the Canadian Turkey Marketing Agency, Canadian Egg Marketing Agency, Canadian Broiler Hatching Marketing Agency, at which time they were provided with the revised tariff equivalents.
These were discussed on a preliminary basis with the intention of a meeting to follow on January 28 or 29. The dairy farmers of Canada were also to be present at that time. However, the agencies decided not to discuss this issue any further with government officials until after February 18.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of National Revenue. Yesterday the minister unveiled a number of weapons in his war against cross-border shopping. One of them was the potential harmonization of the GST with provincial sales taxes. The federal government now wants to collect both at the border.
Can the minister tell us what possible benefit there would be to Canadian consumers and how does he address charges that this is a tax increase in disguise?

speakeroldname: Hon. Otto Jelinek (Minister of National Revenue):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I repeat and emphasize that there is no tax increase for Canadian consumers in the package that was announced yesterday. As far as the specific question is concerned regarding harmonization, obviously harmonization makes common sense. It will eliminate duplication of services, duplication and overlap of programs. One tax, one system is the way to go. The Ontario fiscal outlook tabled a couple of weeks ago by the Ontario NDP government confirms it. It says: "A key difference is the taxation of business. The GST by providing business input tax credits has basically exempted businesses from federal sales tax while Ontario taxes businesses. Broadening the sales tax base or harmonizing could improve economic efficiency for Ontario".
Business of the House
I urge the province of Ontario and other provinces to harmonize as quickly as possible for the benefit of all Canadians.
I draw the attention of hon. members to the presence in the gallery of the Hon. Harold Gille-shammer, Minister of Family Services of the Manitoba Legislative Assembly.
Hear, hear.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the government House leader pertaining to the business of the House for tomorrow, Monday, Tuesday, and the remaining part of next week.
Perhaps, Madam Speaker, while the hon. member is on his feet he might indicate to the House in reference to a question that was put to him by the hon. member for Don Valley East concerning the bill in the other place as to when we might see a tabling of complementary legislation in this House for adjudication by members here.

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, in terms of business, I trust we will complete second reading of Bill C-26 this afternoon. After that we will be able to commence and hopefully complete second reading of Bill C-41, the energy efficiency act.
I would like to at this point designate tomorrow an allotted day for supply. It is my intention, but I would like to confirm tomorrow, to designate Monday an allotted day as well.
On Tuesday we will begin second reading on an act respecting spending control of government expenditures which will be given first reading tomorrow. In terms of the bill on the amendments to the Canada Pension Plan affecting the disabled, I will put down a notice for that this afternoon.
I believe the bill would be in a position to be brought forward tomorrow but in view of the notice provisions of

Government Orders
our Standing Orders, I would require unanimous consent to have it introduced tomorrow. If that were the disposition of the House, I believe we would be in a position to do that. I will have to confirm that with the ministry of health.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext: Madam Speaker, with regard to the tabling of the bill concerning the disabled, I would like to indicate that he can expect and anticipate full co-operation from the Official Opposition to have this particular matter moved expeditiously within this Chamber after it is tabled in the House.
Madam Speaker, to my hon. colleague, the government House leader. I wonder if he is able today to indicate when the budget will be introduced.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext: Soon, Madam Speaker. The precise date I am not able to give now, but hopefully the Minister of Finance will be in a position to give the precise time very soon.

The House resumed consideration of the motion of Mr. Loiselle that Bill C-26, an act to amend the Public Service Employment Act, the Public Service Staff Relations Act and other acts in relation to the Public Service of Canada, be read the second time and referred to Legislative Committee H.

Madam Speaker, when speaking to the bill, the minister responsible for this bill, the President of the Treasury Board, said and I quote from page 6777 of Hansard for February 11, 1992:
Seldom in our history has a program of organizational change been undertaken of the scope and magnitude of PS 2000.
Further in his speech he said, as reported at page 6778:
I would urge that the committee report back to the House by the end of March. There will be ample opportunity to consider improvements to the bill and I am confident that members will put
aside differences and take full advantage of this window of
opportunity.
Again this morning we had the parliamentary secretary to the minister stand up in the House and say that he was hoping that in committee the Official Opposition would bring amendments to this bill for discussion. We intend to do that. I just hope the government is in a good mood, a positive mood, an understanding mood because there are amendments needed to this bill and we intend to bring them forward.
We would have preferred that the government do the right thing in looking at this white paper dealing with PS 2000. It was our preferred choice that to avoid partisanship, to avoid misunderstanding, to avoid conflict, that the white paper be referred a special committee of the House or to a standing committee of the House of the government's own choosing for an all-party review of the white paper.
We could have a discussion on the principle as well as the substance of the bill. We could have come forth with an agreement in committee and brought to this House a piece of legislation that would have been more comprehensive, possibly better organized, and possibly better accepted than the present legislation before us, Bill C-26.
This bill, as the minister himself admitted in the House, is a very important undertaking. When we restructured the Public Service of Canada 25 or 35 years ago, the job was not taken up by the government itself. It invited all the opposition members to participate in the committee and a consensus was built up. Ever since then, whenever there were amendments to either the Public Service Employment Act or the Public Service Staff Relations Act, at least in my 19 years in the House, a committee of the House was struck before the legislation was put to the House. We examined the white paper and reported to the House with legislation to follow.
The last time there were amendments to the Public Service Staff Relations Act, the Finkelman report was referred to a special committee. I served on this committee. The Speaker and a lot of members also served. We had long and arduous meetings with Treasury Board, other interested people and the unions to try to bring about better employee-employer relations in the Public Service.
February 13, 1992



Here is a quote from page 90 in the white paper that we have before us regarding accountability: "Mechanical accountability based on simplistic, quantified objectives is not what is needed. Fundamental to effective accountability is the exercise of judgment".
Madam Speaker, I ask you: We, from the Opposition have not been involved in the development of the proposal before us, the preparation of the document. We are told that civil servants were involved, as well as unions. In the last two years, civil servants from departments such as Treasury Board and, I imagine, the Privy Council and even the Public Service Commission, have been involved in an important examination of the changes required.
And now the minister tells us: We are in a hurry; it has taken us, the government, two years to come up with a document that we consider useful but you, the Official Opposition, barely have two months to go through the stages of first reading, second reading, committee review of each section, and third reading. Those are the veiy words of the minister, who said at pages 6-7 and 7-8:

I would urge the committee to report back to the House by the end of March. It is my earnest desire that the bill receive third reading as soon as possible ".

We cannot accept the fact that the Opposition and the civil servants in general are faced with more or less a blunt refusal as regards the important issues that we wish to raise.
As we know, civil servants are worried right now. Their morale is rather low. Is this the right time to bulldoze this legislation through the House of Commons in two months, to go through committee and the whole parliamentary process in two months? Madam Speaker, I tell you that this is not possible; it is not right. We want to be
Government Orders
heard, we want to hear the unions, we want to hear those who are affected, namely the civil servants.
The amendments included in Bill C-26 affect important institutions of the Parliament of Canada. How, for instance, can the Public Service Commission, which is an agent of this Parliament and which regularly reports to Parliament on its activities, remain impartial-I ask you that question-and free from any government interfering when its hands are tied with the principal adviser to the minister who, as we know, becomes the head of the Public Service?
We think that this appointment violates the autonomy of the Public Service Commission, which is to report only to Parliament, and thus casts doubt on its ability to defend the merit principle.
The public accounts committee, which I chair, has already taken a position on it. It has seriously proposed that a special all-party committee study the issue and not rush it by using the government majority to force its way. The public accounts committee, as I said, recommended a serious study before legislation is tabled.
I support some clauses of the bill which are meant to strengthen the Public Service; I support the ability of the Public Service to serve the general public and I support improved labour relations in it. We agree with that. However, I oppose the clauses of the bill that affect the merit principle. I think that they are not well explained and it is extremely difficult for us to accept them without clear and precise explanations. Madam Speaker, it will destabilize the public service, I tell you. It will probably cause us serious problems of public perception if the commission makes appointments that are not based solely on merit but on some other criterion.
I am disappointed with regard to certain barriers, including the political rights of public servants. God knows, we have talked about it in this House, and before every election, someone here sees some political advantages and raises the question. Why did the government not amend this bill so as to clearly indicate its policy on public servants' political rights? Nothing in the bill deals with that issue and I for one am disappointed.
The Auditor General of Canada said on page 25 of his annual report: "The reform and renewal of the federal Public Service in a time of global competitiveness, a time of change, is essential to enable it to meet the challenges that lie ahead". I agree with that. I see you indicating to me that my time is almost up.

February 13, 1992
Government Orders
I cannot support the bill in question. Therefore I move the following motion, seconded by the hon. member for Carleton-Gloucester:
That the motion be amended by deleting all the words after the
word "That" and substituting the following therefor:
Bill C-26 be not now read a second time but that the Order be discharged, the Bill withdrawn and the subject matter referred to the Standing Committee on Public Accounts.

Madam Speaker, I want to thank my colleague for moving his amendment. It is a good idea.
This is something that really should be looked at by a committee of the House and reported back. Then the government will have a better idea what should and should not be in legislation that so drastically affects the Public Service.
Maybe it is naive, but I have a wish, some experience and some knowledge that the most desirable kind of Public Service that can serve any government of any political stripe, no matter how often governments change, will conscientiously, diligently work in accordance with the policies of the government of the day.
I attended my first national convention of my party in Winnipeg in 1956 when we passed the Winnipeg declaration. I will remind my colleague from the Fraser Valley that the opening sentence in the declaration was that any society motivated only by a desire for profit is basically immoral. I hope he will keep that in mind in the future.
The guest speaker at that convention was the Hon. Richard Crossman of some fame and note in the Atlee government from 1945 to 1952. He was in government again the next time the Labour Party was elected.
I presume he has passed away now, but I recall him telling us that when they took office most of the cabinet ministers and MPs were first-timers. There were a few holdovers from the days of the Ramsay MacDonald government in the late 1920s and early 1930s. All the rest were relative newcomers.
He was appointed to cabinet and said he hardly knew where the washrooms were. He was frantically trying to set up a staff for his office and figure out the make-up of his department.
After he had been in cabinet four or five days, his senior deputy minister phoned and asked for an appointment for himself and two other senior officials of the department. They agreed on a time and day for them to meet. Of course the first thing that went through his mind was that they were going to resign.
When they met a day or two later the deputy minister laid two sets of documents on the minister's desk. He said that the first one contained the policy resolutions and statements of his party that affected his department. The other set of documents contained several options that he suggested be considered in implementing his policy on each of the issues. That is what I think anyone would call a responsible, disciplined, conscientious Public Service. Within a matter of 10 days of taking office, the new cabinet minister had senior people in his department outlining what the policy of his party was, because they kept track of those things in senior levels in their Public Service, and outlining one or more options for each of the policy matters which affected his department.
If only we could have that now and not this governing by the seat of your pants. Any political party that does not have policies which may or may not work-only experience will tell-or does not have a platform that it runs on and if it wins is expected to implement it, is not worthy of being in office.
Similarly, any senior levels of the Public Service that cannot conduct themselves in that manner are not worthy of being in the senior civil service. That is why I do not get excited when there is a change of government.
I think it would be stupid if the new government fired all the deputy ministers and assistant deputies. You would be losing a wealth of experience and dedicated public servants for many years in most instances.
I have no problem with the firing of the people who are brought in on a contract to work on a minister's personal staff. I would not want anybody working for me who was not going to be helpful. If he cannot support the policies of my party and my government or if he cannot be helpful in implementing those policies then I would expect him to resign.
February 13, 1992

In the case of those on contract, serving on a minister's staff or appointed to a board or something or a commission, I can understand them being canned. You would not want anyone working for you who is going to work against you. I do not blame any new government for getting rid of those kinds of people, but to go around with a meat axe picking on the permanent, dedicated, competent Public Service is not only stupid but it is terribly unfair and unnecessary.
I would like to mention one of the things that we are proud of in Saskatchewan. Back in the 1950s it was felt necessary to establish a new university campus in our province, the University of Regina. The university at Saskatoon was getting too full, we needed more space and we obviously needed another campus. To begin with it was one campus under the University of Saskatoon and later it was divided into two separate campuses.
We are most proud of this university, thanks to a man who was minister of education for better than 16 years in our province. He was the architect of establishing, on the University of Regina campus, a faculty of public administration. It recruited former public servants not just from Saskatchewan, but found some public servants who were willing to leave the Public Service to teach at the Regina campus. The person responsible for that was Woodrow S. Lloyd. We started the beginnings of what was a truly professional Public Service and we were proud of it. When we were defeated in 1964, the new Liberal premier, Mr. Ross Thatcher said in the initial days of his government that they were going to go after the CCF appointees with a meat axe. However, wiser and saner heads prevailed because mainly he left the Public Service alone. He put some new ones in of his choice, which he had the right to do, but mainly he left the Public Service alone.
That is the sort of thing that should be in legislation regarding the federal Public Service. We do not need the Treasury Board deciding what a bargaining unit should or should not be. That is something to be decided between the Public Service unions and each department and then collectively report to the Treasury Board with a total package of what bargaining units there should be.
Government Orders
The bill can do nothing but harm to our present Public Service. It could be changed to bring about an even stronger, better and more professional Public Service rather than the government, through the back door, trying to accomplish things it would not dare do through the front door.

Madam Speaker, it is a pleasure for me to speak on this bill, particularly when one considers the number of public servants who work in the riding of Moncton. A very large component of our economy is made up of public servants. For that reason it is important that I speak against the bill because it will have very serious consequences for all those who work for the government and ultimately for all Canadians who deal with the government in the future.
We on this side are of the House are of the opinion that it is necessary to go back to square one and start over again, that we cannot deal with this matter on the basis of Bill C-26. Obviously a special committee of Parliament should go back and take another firm look at the suggestions that have flowed from both the private sector and from the public sector. We could work out a better arrangement which would create a better Public Service in which those who are working within the system could feel that they are making a contribution rather than being cogs in a giant wheel.
I am sure my concerns are shared by this House. The government is dismantling the fabric of this country. We see the attack against things like VIA Rail, the CBC, the postal service and now we see an attack against the Public Service. We wonder what is going to be left when this government is finished with this vicious attack against the institutions which have held us together. My concern is that there may be nothing left if we allow this to continue.
The Public Service linkages between all parts of this country are absolutely essential. They go further than just providing essential services. It is essential that there is an efficient, hard working, dedicated Public Service that provides service equally to all Canadians in all parts of Canada. This bill will contribute nothing toward establishing that goal or that mission for the Public Service.
That is not to suggest that we are not interested in seeing change. There is no question that, as we embark on this new global economy and as we embark on the future, we on this side are not opposed to embracing

February 13, 1992
Government Orders
change that is necessary. We must look at the fundamental shifts that are taking place in our economy, some of them not all that great as far as the shifts are concerned and are caused in large measure by government policy. At the same time we still must be responsive to a new, revitalized Public Service.
That is why we would like to take a new approach and to see a parliamentary committee really respond to the issues of the day.
There is no question in my mind that the present system in the Public Service does not work. The hierarchical system with everybody feeding into the top is an old system. It goes back to the smokestack-type industries.
For that reason, the Public Service does have to change and we do have to look at new ways of managing the Public Service. We have to make the Public Service responsive and also adaptive. There is going to be rapid change over the next 10 or 15 years and we cannot have a stiff, unresponsive type of system in place or else we will develop a system in which the Public Service will be an impediment to change and an impediment to development. In fact, in the long term it will create a veiy poor situation for our country.
How do you achieve that type of system? You do not do it through Bill C-26. You do it by working out a new partnership. It is really two partnerships and they overlap.
It is a partnership between the Public Service and the private sector. There are areas in which the private sector can do the job better. Then there are other areas in which the Public Service can do the task better. So we have to work out that partnership.
The second partnership we have to take a look at and work out is in the area of government and the employees, the actual individuals who are working for the Public Service.
I know in talking to a number of public servants that this government and its policies, the strike and all of those things have left a very demoralized Public Service. The Public Service is wondering what its role is and whether it is independent and not subject to the whims and fancies of different governments that happen to be in power at the time.
We have to go back and reforge that alliance between government and the Public Service so that confidence is built up, so those employees see that there is an opportunity to make a contribution to Canada and to provide the essential services that government must provide in an atmosphere in which the government, Canadians, and the employees benefit. That is not the situation now.
We saw the anger and we saw the frustration during the strike. No matter which side of the fence one sits on, one knows after a strike has occurred there is a lot of rebuilding that has to be done.
