We on this side feel that a special committee that could take a look at this situation could reforge that new alliance between government and the Public Service and make for a better Public Service and a better relationship.
We look at the future and note that as industry is trying to adapt and change its philosophies and its directions, so must government.
We in this place talk of reform and the things that are necessary in order to make us more responsive and to make us more efficient.
By like measure, so must the people who actually deliver the things we create here. Like it or not, they must deliver what Parliament orders and in those circumstances we have to create the type of Public Service that can adapt to that very rapid change.
I am sure that there are those among the Public Service who are worried and reluctant to change and reluctant to look at the new measures and new methodologies as far as management is concerned in providing services. Deep down, I think that most in the Public Service are looking for the challenge and the opportunity which can be afforded them by a new revitalized partnership between the private sector, government and the Public Service.
In conclusion I should say that we cannot support this bill. There are some good aspects to it. There are some aspects that maybe would do the job.
But we feel, as a general statement and as a general point of view, that we have to go back to square one and take what is good in this legislation and work with the new arrangements and with a new understanding.
What would really do the trick, and I am sure all would agree with me, is if we had a new government which had credibility and could provide leadership, then I think you
February 13, 1992

Government Orders
would see the Public Service respond in the proper fashion.

Thank you, Madam Speaker, for allowing me to speak a second time on Bill C-26, An act to amend the Public Service Employment Act and the Public Service Staff Relations Act.
Government has released this wonderful white paper on the Public Service entitled: The Renewal of the Public Service of Canada. Allow me to read the first few words of the very first page, and I quote:

"The Public Service of Canada is fundamental to the successful functioning of our democratic institution and our country. It serves Canada ably and has contributed immeasurably to our stable economic and social environment, to our achievements of a modem industrial nation and to our values and indemnity as a people." Je saute quelques paragraphes et j'arrive a "Public Service 2000 is the government's initiative to ensure that these expectations are satisfied. We believe that the policy for renewal set out in the white paper will equip the Public Service to serve Canada and Canadians into the 21st century."

And it is signed by Brian Mulroney, the Prime Minister of Canada.
This is a fine white paper, fine words indeed. It should certainly be scrutinized by all interested parties, i.e. civil servants, unions, members of Parliament, government services' users in general. Everyone should have a chance to comment on the advisability of improving the legislation governing the Public Service.
The government has introduced a bill.

The law does not reflect the good mission that we see in the white paper. Compare both and all of this in the wake of what has been happening to the Public Service.

The fact is that the legislation governing the public service is almost 25 years old. It dates back to 1964 or 1967, and it is time we update it. I agree, but I think that the climate is not right, given the negative sentiment towards the Public Service at the present time. Picture this, an employer who prides himself on having reduced its workforce by 15,000 since 1985, an employer who contracts out instead of giving the work to his own employees, in a place-some government members refer to the headquarters of the Public Service as fat cat city-where all you hear about is deployment, an employer who gave zero per cent increase to his employees this year, a unique year that has seen the biggest strike in the history of the Public Service. There is a lot of uncertainty among the civil servants right now.

Managers have prepared the white paper for Public Service 2000 and obviously the government prepared Bill C-26 to change the law.
It did not seem to care to have the input in a non-partisan fashion by all members of Parliament in a committee that would make recommendations prior to having the second reading of this bill.
Concerning the mission of the Public Service, according to the white paper Public Service 2000 this bill goes against some of these very admirable principles. For example, it says in the mission: "-through members who are appointed and promoted on the basis of merit".
In Bill C-26 the merit principle is effectively gone. As seen in section 10(2), no longer will there be competition in the Public Service. Managers will now write job descriptions to suit the candidate of their choice. There are no safeguards against political and administrative patronage.
Again from the mission statement: "Representatives of the public and the regions of Canada". If the government was really interested in fully representing the Canadian public, as employees of the Public Service it would have made stronger its article on employment equity.
In Bill C-26 clause 5 states that Treasury Board may, I repeat, may provide for the administration of programs for the employment and career opportunities of the

February 13, 1992
Government Orders
disadvantaged and groups that are disadvantaged by reason of race, sex, colour and so on. Why only may? Why do we use may provide?
A government that is serious about rectifying the situation which women, who by the way as every one knows represent well over 50 per cent of the population, the handicapped and our minorities find themselves today when it comes to obtaining employment and advancement in the Public Service would have put some teeth into this part of the bill.
From the mission statement: "-professionally manage and develop in accordance with the highest ethical standards". Does deployment, which means transfers- transfers by command, you are ordered transferred, you do not have a choice-and the constant threat of a position being transferred at the whim of a manager lend itself to a professionally managed Public Service?
This is not what employees are telling me in my riding of Carleton-Gloucester. They are worried and their morale is at an all-time low. They look forward to a totally management-driven Public Service.
None of these facts will help in attaining the very lofty goal of Public Service 2000, that of providing the best possible service to the Canadian people, while at the same time attracting Canada's best individuals to offer themselves for service to the public.
My constituents are very nervous. Most of my constituents are public servants or rely on the services of public servants. They feel extremely insecure. They feel annoyed by the way they are being treated by their employer. They feel afraid of their managers. They are becoming desperate. They are unsure of any future.
They used to be absolutely dedicated, happy in participating in the delivery of government programs, happy to assist the communities. They were happy to do inspection work, for example making sure that people fly airplanes safely, that medical products are safe and the list goes on and on.
While many of the initiatives in Public Service 2000 are worth while, the proposed Bill C-26 does not reflect the views of Public Service 2000.
I will definitely be voting against Bill C-26 because of the many inclusions and exclusions which I and my fellow caucus members have highlighted during these debates.

Madam Speaker, I had a first impulse when I read the description of Bill C-26, an act to amend the Public Service Employment Act, the Public Service Staff Relations Act and other acts in relation to the Public Service of Canada.
It catches the imagination. One would think that we are progressing. It is a wonderful thing that the government has decided to address the problems of the Public Service. We certainly have known for a long time that there are problems.
I have talked to representatives of the Public Service unions. I have known many of them for a long while. I dealt with many of these people before I was even elected to Parliament. They certainly do have problems.
The first impulse was one of gratitude and looking forward to something positive. One does not have to go very far into the legislation, though, to realize that certainly is not the case. I should not have been surprised, because if this government were anything it certainly was consistent. If it has been anything in relation to its employees over the last number of years, not to mention the people of Canada, it has certainly demonstrated disdain and contempt for both its employees and the Canadian public. It has been consistent in that sense.
This piece of legislation popularly known as PS 2000 is no exception. When we look at almost any particular reference in it, as far as the major classifications are concerned we see under certification that it intends to have a very dominant role in deciding who shall be in a bargaining unit and who shall constitute a group within any particular part of the Public Service. This is without consultation with the unions involved and without consultation with any employees involved.
That really flies in the face of long established employer-employee regulatory bodies in so far as labour relations are concerned over many years in Canada and in all jurisdictions.
February 13, 1992

For the employer to take a unilateral stand on what shall constitute part of a bargaining unit or not is really a very arrogant stand for the government to take. It is pre-emptory and does not go any distance at all toward solving the problem we have within the Public Service.
The major problem is that over the years there have been changes. There is a need within the Public Service for what in many cases could most commonly be described as reclassification. At least there should be a study of the classifications that are there. That is certainly needed.
The government has described it as classification simplification. On the other hand it has really spent an awful lot of time in making it more complicated. It is certainly not simplifying anything at all.
I do not mean to suggest a reclassification of jobs or a study of jobs for any number of reasons but to make sure that the people within the classifications are properly paid for what they do. That certainly includes the matter of pay equity. There is a whole body of evidence, including cases which have been taken to court by the union representing the Public Service and before the Human Rights Commission.
Invariably the courts and the commission have found that the government has not been treating its employees fairly in so far as many of these matters are concerned. In spite of that the government seems to be hell-bent on a course of unilaterally making these changes in the face of decisions brought against them. The philosophy seems to be if one has not been able to succeed in accomplishing what one wants and has been told that one should change one's ways then the thing to do is to change the law in order to make the situation conform to one's biases.
I mentioned this was predicated on a disdain and a contempt for government employees. I cannot understand why this would be the case. In a fairly short period of time we have had many examples. Since I have been in the House we have had the case where the government has been perpetrating strikes by hospital employees in which the major issue was pay equity. Most of those employees were women. In spite of the fact that the government had received judgments saying it should be paying these people differently, it did not do so.
Government Orders
The same thing happened to the Coast Guard. These strikes happened almost concurrently. Just last summer we had the general strike where one of the major causes was the discontent among the employees caused by the government's disdainful attitude toward them. One of the previous speakers mentioned that in the province of Saskatchewan we had developed an exemplary Public Service. I do not wish to indicate that our present Public Service is not exemplary either. Since becoming a member of Parliament and having dealt with public servants, I must say that we have received nothing but the greatest of co-operation in a most professional way in spite of the fact that they have had such hard working conditions under their present employer, the present government of our country.
The major problem is that there has been a need for a reclassification for a long time. I do not mean to imply that rectifying the problems in the Public Service is going to be simple. In so far as reclassification is concerned, nothing that is worth while is simple. Certainly one of the major issues in the country today and one of the major tasks of the government to make sure that our public servants are well trained. It should make sure they are well qualified and that the Canadian public gets the best service possible from them.
In some cases that may not be the case now, the problem being the structure more than the classifications themselves. There have to be some classifications. This government is proposing to bring in a classification system based on what we have now. Instead of bringing in a thorough, follow-through program based on fairness, it is going to bring in one based on animosity, denigration or antiquity.
PS 2000 is a catch phrase for something sounding good. In the long run it will not be a benefit to the Canadian public and will not address the negative responses of the Human Rights Commission toward the government in relation to its employees.
I urge this government to rethink. I certainly hope it will listen to the committee and its representatives.

Madam Speaker, my friend, the distinguished member for Ottawa-Vanier, has moved an amendment to this motion which would allow the Chamber to do what

February 13, 1992
Government Orders
needs to be done, that is to have a committee of this House look long and hard at this restructuring of the Public Service.
Speakers on all sides of this Chamber have admitted that what is proposed in this bill is fairly sweeping. I certainly will not stand here and say that everything in the bill is bad. None of our speakers have said that. There are certain things about it that are very good because some of the elements would contribute to the strengthening of the Public Service in its ability to serve the public, and that is a good objective. I am very much in favour of that.
At the same time there are aspects of Bill C-26 which would undermine very drastically the merit principle that says one gets hired by what one is and not who one knows. One gets hired on one's qualifications, not on whether one is prepared to kowtow to some of the senior mandarins in a particular department of government.
That is a sound principle but that principle is being undermined here. That is one of the reasons we in the Official Opposition are saying that this legislation should be sent to committee before rushing to judgment on this one. We should do what the Standing Committee on Public Accounts, a committee of all parties of this House, said last May needs to be done. This legislation and these ideas for reform need to be adjudicated and gone over with a fine tooth comb by members of all parties. Members should be sitting down, not in the partisan atmosphere of the Chamber but rather in a committee where so much good work gets done and can be done in this particular instance as well.
What is so earth shattering about that kind of a suggestion? Why is the government balking on that particular one? It would improve the legislation. If the government means what it says, that it wants to improve the Public Service, let it put its money where its mouth is. The minister of multiculturalism is in the Chamber. Maybe he would want to indicate that the government is prepared to do that. If so, we are prepared to stop talking now and let this bill go forward. That would be the desirable solution. That would allow the committee to come up with some improvements to make the bill not only palatable to all sides of the House but, more to the point, make it better serve the interests it is supposed to serve.
We have in this country from coast to coast what must be one of the best, most professional public services in the world. There are 250,000 men and women who serve this country very well. When I say 250,000,1 have in mind direct employees of the government itself. If one includes the Crown corporations, I suppose one would add
just about that number again and it would be close to
500,000	people. Whatever category we are talking about, in total we are talking about many hundreds of thousands of people who are on the front line daily in terms of the programs of our government. This is the case for whatever administration happens to be in power.
This is not a reflection on the people who are in the Public Service but their immediate political taskmasters. Unfortunately there has been a real over-effort to politicize the senior levels of the Public Service, and we have seen some unfortunate results of that. We have seen senior mandarins on the TV channels mouthing the government's political line and being apologists and lap-dogs for the government.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext: You are talking through your hat.

If my friend from Fraser Valley East, B.C., wants some specific examples, I can give him very specific examples. If he wants me to name names on this one, I can name names. Mr. Paul Tellier holds an office that is the most senior in this country in terms of the Public Service. It is an office that has been occupied by many people over the years who have always remained above the fray. To his credit, Mr. Tellier for the most part has remained above the fray. I say for the most part.
I regret to say that on occasion I have seen him being an apologist for our government, and that is shameful. I hope he has learned his lesson because he does neither himself nor the Public Service credit when he does that.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext: Roger, you have a poor memory. You have a very selective memory.

Perhaps the gentleman from Fraser Valley East wants to help my memory. He suggests my memory is selective. He asked me for examples and I gave him one. Now it is his turn. Does he want to give me one? If he suggests that my memory is selective, I now give him the opportunity. I am listening.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
You have the floor.
February 13, 1992

As he says, I have the floor. Decoded, the member means that his bluff has been called.
This government has very badly managed the Public Service by downgrading, contracting out, replacing permanent employees and so on. It has badly mismanaged the Public Service.
Before I go on to that, let me not leave the previous item I was mentioning as a loose end. I was terribly distracted by my good friend from Fraser Valley East who is too much an apologist for a government that he does not support very enthusiastically any more, but a congenial fellow nevertheless.
I was making a point when he asked for examples, and of course I gave an example. I could give him several more, but this is not intended to be an opportunity to parade out people's names. The one I did parade out had already, by his very act, paraded his own name out in the public anyway. I did not exactly tell any state secrets when I referred to the actions of Mr. Tellier.
I used that example in response to the invitation from the gentleman for Fraser Valley East to make an appeal to those who are under the thumb of this administration not to yield to the pressure to become apologists or lap-dogs for an administration. That will only tear away at the quality of what I have said is one of the best public services in the world. Almost everyone in that Public Service understands the line of demarcation between the bureaucracy and the political taskmasters. Once in a while somebody gets sucked across that line, but that should not be a reflection on the great army of men and women who always understand where the line is and stay on the right side of it. They not only stay there in the passive sense but do their jobs extremely well. Whether they are in Port au Basques, one of the communities in my riding or in the fisheries or manpower office, the fisheries office in Grand Bank or the employment office in Marystown, or anywhere else in this country, they are people who are serving this country very well.
That is all the more reason why we ought to take our time on this fairly sweeping bit of legislation. I recommend the solution of my friend from Ottawa-Vanier. It is very simple. Just vote for his amendment. Send it to a committee and let members from all sides of this House
Government Orders
scrutinize this fairly sweeping legislation so we can come back with better, much improved legislation.
What does the member for Fraser Valley East have against that eminently good idea? Is it because it is a good idea? Why does he not embrace a good idea for a change? I invite him to do so.

Madam Speaker, I want to compliment my hon. friend and colleague, the member for Burin-St. George's, on the remarks he just completed. He was unduly harassed by the hon. member for Fraser Valley East somewhat earlier in his remarks, when he suggested that the hon. member for Burin-St. George's was talking through his hat. I can only say that it is a wonder, after the things this government has done to Atlantic Canada, that anyone from Burin-St. George's or anywhere in Atlantic Canada can afford a hat.
At any rate, it gives me great pleasure to rise again in this debate and speak as the member of Parliament for Halifax, the city which has the third largest Public Service contingent in the country.
When I spoke at another stage in this debate some days ago I spent my time talking mainly about the problems relating to regional rates of pay. I also mentioned pay equity. Both of these problems are singularly unaddressed by this legislation. I do not wish for a moment to suggest, when I go on to different matters in my remarks today, that I think the two areas of pay equity and most particularly regional rates are any less important, but there are other problems with this legislation.
I would like to say at this point as well that I too support most strongly the amendment of my learned colleague from Ottawa-Vanier. I think this would be a most excellent way to deal with this legislation.
The Government of Canada is the largest single employer in the country and should be in the vanguard of progressive employment practices. It should be a model of fair practice and implement equal pay for work of equal value. It should eliminate regional rates of pay and resolve employee-employer disputes in a manner that shows the private sector and the provincial, municipal and territorial governments of this country how it should be done.

February 13, 1992
Government Orders
In the long and excellent history of the Public Service in this country that has been the way things were done. But things have changed and unfortunately they have not changed in any way for the better.
For example, rather than resolving long-standing pay equity disputes, this government tries to strip the Canadian Human Rights Commission's tribunal of its powers to arbitrate pay equity disputes by taking it to court. Rather than allow for the right to strike and bargain collectively, the government engaged in a fruitless, lengthy and acrimonious strike with the Public Service, further demoralizing and leaving it with a very low level of morale.
The infamous zero-three-three, read my lips, was the pronouncement of a government unwilling to bargain in good faith. It was unwilling to compromise, negotiate, discuss or even listen. Even before bargaining began the government had already decided it would legislate the workers back to work and impose the zero-three-three formula on the Public Service.
The possibility of reaching a compromise via arbitration and conciliation was therefore thrown out. It was an exercise in futility because the government said it would override any settlement that did not conform to this formula.
That is terrific. What a tremendous example to set in the area of labour relations. What a tremendous way to inculcate in the people of Canada some feeling of trust in their government. Sadly the words trust and government have become mutually exclusive. Sadly for all of us who sit in legislatures across this country, it is going to be a long time before those words mean anything to Canadians again, at least in the political sense.
Given this government's track record it is not surprising that Bill C-26 is found wanting in several areas, most notably in the realm of merit and fair staffing practices. The following are just a few examples of the attempt to do away with the merit principle.
It evaluates candidates according to a set of standards rather than employing a ranking system in which one candidate is compared to another. This could translate into the best candidate not necessarily being chosen for the job.
The principle of hiring the most qualified person is replaced by the principle of hiring a qualified person. It gives deputy heads the exclusive right to deploy staff permanently, i.e. to hire and move staff around within the deputy head's jurisdiction without competition. Theoretically deployment is voluntary but acceptance of deployment may be included in terms of employment any time an employee is hired or moved to a new position or level. In such cases an employee would have no choice and would either take it or leave it. These changes are referred to as appointment to level as opposed to appointment to a position through competition.
What is wrong with competition? Why is the government eliminating this aspect of fairness in its Public Service?
Another example is that a 90-day casual employee clause creates a new sub-class of employee with no rights or benefits. Casuals may be hired without regard to qualifications. The 90 days can be extended to 125 days, but there are no safeguards against them becoming full-time continuing casuals if they are working for more than one department. And guess who are likely to be the major victims of this kind of legislation? Can anyone guess? I bet the minister can. Who does the minister think I am referring to?
What class of people do we think? I bet my colleague from Ottawa-Vanier knows which class of people are most likely to be injured by this. We all know. The minister is nodding; he knows. It is women, that is who. That is the group of casuals with no benefits or job security. Terrific. This is from a government allegedly committed to pay equity. Well, we shall see.
Another example is increased contracting out. Contracting out is probably the single most devastating morale breaker in the Public Service of Canada. People see their jobs disappearing. They see themselves being replaced, and they see a government that wants to downsize to the point where the standards they have worked hard-many of them for many years-to establish in government departments no longer mean anything. Again who are the most likely people to lose, as jobs are contracted out? The lower levels. Who are in the lower levels, in numbers that far exceed their
February 13, 1992

percentage of the Canadian population? Women. But this government is committed to equity and justice and fair play and all of those wonderful buzzwords. A little action rather than buzzwords would be a major relief, particularly for public servants.
What do we have with contracting out? What comes with it? Do the words patronage, favouritism and punitive measures, as well as based upon a manager's personal likes and dislikes or the whim of the government of the day, come with it? But of course this government does not have whims. We can all remember years ago when a Prime Minister, who came to office supposedly on a rising tide against patronage, mentioned the fact that he certainly would appoint non-political people to positions as soon as the very last living member of his party had been taken care of. I guess, although there have been some changes in that manner, one cannot teach too many old dogs too many new tricks.
This legislation undermines the merit principle, leaving all but the original hiring and limited promotions to a discretionary group, with no backup in policy in the Public Service at large. It is very sad. It deals a terrible blow to a superb Public Service that deserves better, but has received nothing but hard knocks and disillusionment at the hands of its own government.
The much recognized need for increased flexibility for management is not adequately offset by the arbitrary exercise of staffing authority and the loss of the merit principle. This appears to be something that the government does not understand.
I only have a moment or two left and I would like to conclude briefly by going back to the issue that is of primary concern in Atlantic Canada, the issue of regional rates of pay.
At present Atlantic Canadians have the lowest rates of pay for designated occupational categories such as the general labour and trades group and the general service group. These differences in pay reinforce the already glaring disparities between the standard of living in Atlantic Canada and that in the rest of the country. These differences in pay contribute to the unequal development of Atlantic Canada as compared to the development of the rest of Canada. These regional rates of pay cannot be justified on the basis of a lower cost of living.
Government Orders
It is simply an illusion to think that the cost of living is lower in our part of the country than in central Canada. Equal work must enjoy equal rates of pay. This is a hallmark of an equal society. The government should listen for once.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext:
It is my duty, pursuant to Standing Order 38, to inform the House that the questions to be raised tonight at the time of adjournment are as follows: the hon. member for Willowdale- The Economy; the hon. member for Malpeque-Education; the hon. member for Okanagan-Shuswap-General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade; the hon. member for Nepean-Breast Implants; and the hon. member for Mackenzie-Agriculture.
The hon. member for Saanich-Gulf Islands has given me written notice that she is unable to present her motion during the time reserved for private members' business on Friday, February 14, 1992.

It has not been possible to arrange an exchange of positions in the order of precedence, pursuant to Standing Order 94(2)(a). Accordingly, I am directing the table officers to drop that item of business to the bottom of the order of precedence.

Pursuant to Standing Order 94(2)(b), Private Members' Hour will therefore be suspended and the House will proceed with the business at hand.

Madam Speaker, I too wish to enter into the debate on Bill C-26. I will not be long. My friend, the former chairman of the finance committee, wants to enter into this discussion as well. We are all anxious to hear what little gems of wisdom our colleague and friend can contribute to this debate.
I want to join with all of the speakers I have heard this afternoon in condemning aspects of Bill C-26. That is not to say that we entirely condemn everything that is in the bill. Common sense would tell us that there are things in this bill that require a parliamentary process of going through committee, preferably in a non-partisan way, to work on this bill and to bring out some changes in it. In many ways Bill C-26 reflects a government that is driven more by ideology than by experience or common sense.

February 13, 1992
Government Orders
It is an ideology that attempts to portray the Public Service as lazy, bloated, inefficient. It tries to score political points from the Public Service. We can all find examples of ineffective public servants just as we can find examples of ineffective clerks in stores or ineffective executives in the high-rise office towers. We have human beings throughout, whether it is in the Public Service or the private sector, who are good and who are not good.
Unfortunately this government has tried to gain quite a bit of political mileage by sort of stomping on the Public Service.
The unfortunate part is that the government seems to believe its own rhetoric. We have in Bill C-26 a reflection of that. It is a reflection of a government that is at war with its own workers. That is unfortunate. It is not just unfortunate for the government, but it is unfortunate for the country.
In a more enlightened day and age, enlightened people recognize that workers and management have to work together. Management cannot do it on its own. Workers cannot do it on their own. We need a co-operative environment in which people are working together, sharing a common goal, and then attempting to deliver the services in such a way that they are the most efficient, most cost effective, et cetera.
If a government were serious about saving money, the best people who could save money are its own employees. They know when too much paper is being used or whether a trip is really necessary, if you are at war with your own employees then you are going to have those employees fighting back and sabotaging you. It means waste, inefficiencies, and increased costs, and it is the Canadian people who suffer.
What are some of the main aspects that we find unacceptable in Bill C-26? First, it gives the Treasury Board the authority to determine bargaining units unilaterally. An important point to workers is who determines what bargaining units they are in.
Bill C-26 gives that power unilaterally and totally to the employer. This goes against what is included in all other labour legislation, including the Canada Labour Code which gives this power to a labour relations board.
The government in many ways is exempting itself from the Canada Labour Code, from its own legislation. If the
Government of Canada can claim to be able to do that, why should many of the other private companies not try to claim the same type of right? It underlines existing labour legislation in the Canada Labour Code.
The second thing we find objectionable is that the bill gives managers the right to deploy or to transfer at their discretion within the levels. To give this power to the Treasury Board rather than to the Public Service Commission where it should belong goes against rulings of the Federal Court of Appeal which said that removing the right to compete for or to appeal a transfer within a level seriously undermined the merit principle.
We have the Federal Court of Appeal making a decision. This government, rather than complying with the decision of the court, goes around and changes the legislation. So much for the sense of the rule of justice.
The third aspect that we find objectionable about Bill C-26 is that it gives the government the power to eliminate jobs in the public sector through contracting out. The government now, we understand, spends some $5 billion a year in contracting out, but there is no accounting for this expenditure.
The Auditor General, in the Standing Committee on Public Accounts, has asked for some accountability of the cost effectiveness of this practice. The government refuses to supply that information. Again, I go back to my original comment that Bill C-26 is more politically driven, ideologically driven, than by a sense of good legislation and what is good for the country and the people of Canada.
Take the case of contracting out. The government wants to be able to claim politically how many jobs it has eliminated, that it has cut the fat out of the bureaucracy in Ottawa.
The people back home know that the people who are being laid off by this government are the people who supply the services, the people who do the actual work. The top echelons generally remain untouched. The government then lays workers off and it contracts out. It claims to be saving money, because it does not have to make any pension contributions, et cetera, to workers who come in under contract.
February 13, 1992

The government is incapable of showing to the Auditor General and the public accounts committee how effective this practice is. Is it really saving us money? I suspect it is not, but what it has done is alienate many of the employees of the government.
In this day and age, if we are to survive economically as a country, I believe we have to move very strongly to where there is almost a social contract between the various productive elements of our society.
There must be mutual understandings and agreements between the private and the public sector and between employers and employees. Look at some of the examples and models. Look at many of the European countries and we find models that allow for increased efficiency and effectiveness through a co-operative process in which the employees and the employers are working together toward common goals.
What we have, especially with this government, is the opposite. We have an adversarial system in which the employers and employees are at war with each other, and it is the public that suffers. This government is to be blamed for that. It has deliberately created this war, very often for political purposes. Quite often it thought it would win political points by pouncing on public servants. It thought it would be great for its standing in the polls.
Not really.

Exactly, not really. It has not worked that way. It is the opposite that has worked that way. As with so many things of this government, it thought one thing would happen when exactly the opposite has happened. It thought it would win political points by stomping over the public servants, but the opposite has happened.
In closing, I would like to mention that for a while I worked in the Public Service in Saskatchewan and there were two ways of describing ourselves. We could either look at ourselves as government employees or we could look at ourselves as public servants. I always liked the notion of a public servant. Part of the reason I entered into the Public Service in Saskatchewan was my sense of public service.
Many of the government employees are saying: "We are not being treated as public servants. We are being treated just as employees with management trying to get the most out of us, and therefore we would rather see ourselves being called and termed as government em-
Govemment Orders
ployees". I am afraid that is what has happened. The sense of service is being destroyed, not because people do not want to serve but because they are being treated badly by their employers and they have to do everything they can just to protect their dignity and their rights.
The legislation is poor legislation. This government is not going to be here two years from now. I suggest it should quietly sit on it, not introduce and proceed with Bill C-26 if it cannot come up with something better. At least the new government that will replace it will come up with proper legislation and the proper reform needed.

Madam Speaker, I was distracted by the member for Ottawa South. I was actually sitting here in anticipation of his participating in the debate because he is a member who has had a lot of experience in motivating people in the private sector. This bill is fundamentally about how to motivate and mobilize the largest work force in Canada to work for the people of Canada.
What we have right now is a situation in which the morale of the Public Service is so low that, as the hon. member for the New Democratic Party said earlier, the real loser in this friction between the political culture, namely the government and the bureaucratic culture, is the population of Canada.
The biggest crisis we are facing is unemployment. I have been saying that repeatedly for the last two weeks. One area in our country that could really do a lot to put people back to work is the sector in our economy under the umbrella of entrepreneurship. There are close to one million entrepreneurs in this country and if each one of those entrepreneurs were to take the chance and hire someone, put someone back to work, then the spirit and the morale of this country would be a lot better off.
One of the reasons the entrepreneurs of this country right now are taking such a conservative approach, an approach which is basically hesitant, is that they are getting signals from all parts of the economy, all members of the government and even public servants. They are getting signals that the institutions of this country are not working correctly.
Right now our business people are coming into contact almost constantly with public servants. I hear repeatedly from businessmen their feelings on the attitude of public servants toward their particular frustration. Whether it be the GST situation and forms that have to be filled out, whether it is assistance from the Federal Business Development Bank and how to get their eligibility for a loan processed, whether they are eligible in various

February 13, 1992
Government Orders
regions of this country for small business loans or grants or whatever, whether it is people who are looking for retraining programs and companies that are trying to keep people employed, they go into employment offices and get a sense that the will of the Public Service, the will of the bureaucrats, is not really there to serve the people of Canada.
I do not want to make a blanket statement on all public servants because I spoke on this bill earlier and I happen to think that one of the great treasures of this country is the Public Service. I have been working around this city since 1978 and some of the finest people I have ever met in my life are employed with the Government of Canada. I say that with all sincerity.
We can take an institution that employs close to
300,000	people and see the number of people it touches day in and day out in a 10-hour to 12-hour day. If the morale of that organization is not strong, there is no debating the fact that it can affect the attitude of all the people it touches. In Canada we have a Public Service which touches every aspect of our daily lives.
The specific area that I am concerned about is the Public Service and how it interacts with the business community in this country. This includes small, medium and large businesses.
I want to give a positive example. About five months ago there was a company named Amertek that manufactured fire trucks in Canada. It was going through a particularly tough period in terms of its cash flow, and the Canadian Commercial Corporation was managing its contract. The officials at Amertek were appealing to the government agency for financial assistance because they needed help in order to meet the demands their bankers were putting on them.
The officials at the Canadian Commercial Corporation came in and did an audit on the company. They saw that it was eligible for the bill it submitted which was due and owing. They literally went to the bank in Ottawa and wired the money to the account of this small business. It is an example of where a public servant went beyond the
call of duty and served not only the employer of that company but indirectly served everyone working in that factory. It gave that company added cash flow and a burst of security. It has kept the company going. Now it has rebounded and is doing better than ever. It is that kind of attitude of going the extra mile that is so critical when times are tough.
There are also many examples where we are not getting the quality service that has always been part and parcel of this great institution, namely the Public Service of Canada, because its morale is so bad.
I support the approach of my colleague, the member for Ottawa-Vanier, that this bill be given a much more thorough analysis. I have said repeatedly that public servants are used as scapegoats or battering rams if all of a sudden things are not going well in government. We always say: "Look at those public servants. They just are not doing their jobs".
What we have to realize is that we are as politicians inextricably intertwined with the Public Service. If the Public Service is not serving well then it is a mirror of those of us in this room. So often we forget that. If people are complaining about the Public Service, ultimately they are complaining about us. We are the people responsible for the caring, approachable, action oriented Public Service that must be a part of the community service in this country.

Madam Speaker, as chairman of the Standing Committee on Public Accounts back in 1989, 1990 and 1991 let me say that our committee held several hearings on the PS 2000 document that the government tabled.
We did so because the Auditor General, with whom the committee works day after day, suggested that there were problems in the Public Service of Canada that needed to be ironed out for the sake of efficiency within government itself. The thing that came through loud and clear in our hearings as a committee was that Public Service 2000 was not being given enough attention. Employees were not being consulted. The consultation was from the top down, not with the regular front line
February 13, 1992

employees who have to face the public day in and day out in their jobs.
A considerable amount of disagreement was pointed out by the people who appeared before the Standing Committee on Public Accounts at that time. It proved that a real open discussion on the government's Public Service 2000 document was absolutely essential.
After we had those hearings we brought in a report to this House of Commons with several very important recommendations in it on several meetings we had. At this time I would like to repeat, for the benefit of the House and for the record, recommendation 18(a). We recommended in our seventh report that the government table a discussion paper prior to proceeding with the introduction of legislative amendments and/or administrative changes and that this discussion paper set out the principal conclusions and recommendations arising from Public Service 2000.
Part (b) referred the aforementioned discussion paper to a special committee of the House of Commons.
The Standing Committee on Public Accounts, as you well know Madam Speaker, must have hearings on practically every government department and agency. The Auditor General's report is very thick. There is a lot of work in there. It means a very heavy job for members of this committee. We did not have time to carry out this total report on our own. We recommended that a special committee of the House of Commons on the Public Service conduct a consultation process involving employees, Public Service unions and other interested parties, and report back to the House within a reasonable period of time.
If I remember correctly I tabled this report in the House on November 8, 1990. We wanted a report back from the government by November 30. The Standing Committee on Public Accounts has the right to put a timeframe on its demands of the government and it is up to the government to meet those demands.
That special committee became the subject of several pieces of correspondence between me and the President of the Treasury Board. He committed himself to set up such a committee for hearings and then proceeded to fail to do so. He did not live up to his own commitments to the Standing Committee on Public Accounts. This com-
Govemment Orders
mittee brings people before it from all levels of the Public Service of Canada including senior officials from the Treasury Board and senior officials from the Privy Council. How can a parliamentary system work if we get commitments from them and those commitments are not lived up to?
The bottom line is that the government did not bring in a paper we wanted for discussion, laying out its main objectives. The committee was never established. There were no such hearings. Therefore there was no open, broad discussion before a committee on the Public Service 2000 document of the government. As a result, what did the government do? It handled it in its usual high-handed manner. It ended up bringing the legislation into the House.
Let us make the comparison with what has happened in the past on these issues dealing with the Public Service of Canada. The Public Service is supposed to be non-political in its everyday operations. Therefore it is important that there be fairness and independence from politics in the way it works from day to day.
In the late 1960s we had the Finkelman report. There were many meetings on that paper. That is why the Standing Committee on Public Accounts recommended that a similar procedure take place this time. First there were many committee meetings on the paper itself, as well as many on the legislation. Then the legislation came into the House and was referred to a special committee. Something like 118 recommendations were brought in with that bill in the late 1960s. The bill had the most amendments of any bill returned to this House of Commons. I remember the chairperson of that committee was Mr. Jean-Thomas Richard, the long-time member for Ottawa East. Presently this is the territory held by the hon. member for Ottawa-Vanier.
He did an excellent job then. Members of all parties worked so effectively and so well together on that committee that when that bill was brought back before the House of Commons for final reading and passage there was very little debate on it. Instead members were thanking and congratulating each other on the co-operation that existed in committee. As a result the bill passed

February 13, 1992
Government Orders
through the House very smoothly, simply because the proper groundwork had been done in advance.
For the reason that very little discussion has taken place with regard to the legislation brought forward right now on Public Service 2000,1 totally agree with my hon. friend, the member for Ottawa-Vanier, that the motion of the government should be amended. All the words after the word "that" should be deleted and the following substituted therefor: "That Bill C-26 dealing with Public Service 2000 be not now read the second time but that the order for second reading be discharged, the bill withdrawn, and the subject matter thereof referred to the Standing Committee on Public Accounts, and that the public accounts committee bring a report back to this House as to how the bill should be handled from thereon".
No doubt one of the recommendations would be a special committee to have those hearings.
I mentioned the commitment of the President of the Treasury Board to the Standing Committee on Public Accounts. That commitment was not met. This is not surprising, because the government does not know how to deal with its own employees. It does not know how to go about reforming the framework of the Public Service. It does not know how to work with opposition parties in this House. It dictates to them also.
The reason is very simple. This government is anything but reform minded in the sense of reforming legislation and reforming everyday operations of government. It is a reactionary government. It is a dictatorial government. It is a government that directs the country's business from on high and has little or no relationship with everyday Canadians.
The departments of government are staffed by some excellent public servants.
I have had the privilege over the years of dealing with excellent public servants from many government departments, whether it be Energy, Mines and Resources, whether it be Public Works, whether it be Industry, Science and Technology, whether it be National Defence where we have a large number of very dedicated public servants, External Affairs and so on.
These people put themselves out to come to meetings that we have. They will come to our offices and discuss
matters. I just want to pay them a tribute. They deserve better. If we are going to have a professional Public Service in this country they deserve better treatment than they are getting from this government now.
I ask the government to open up the discussions. Free up the discussions on this bill. Take it back, submit it to a special committee of this House and let the discussions go on. It will be an improved bill when it comes back to the House that will be acceptable, probably not only to the opposition but to all public servants. Do them that favour.

Madam Speaker, like my colleagues who spoke before me on Bill C-26,1 also want to support the amendment of the hon. member for Ottawa West, which reads as follows: That Bill C-26, an act to amend the Public Service Employment Act, the Public Service Staff Relations Act and other acts in relation to the public service of Canada, be not now read a second time but be read a second time this day six months hence.
I believe it is important to revise the Public Service Act so that all Canadians can benefit from quality services, wherever they may live. To provide these quality services, it is essential that the Public Service treat every one of its employees with respect, without favouritism and, above all, without intimidation.
The Liberal Party knows that partnership between the public and private sectors is the only way to build our country. Everyone must be aware that they are part of the Canadian economy, from non-governmental organizations to the public sector, and including unions as well as ordinary Canadians.
The Liberal Party does not want to pass a law that could in any way adversely affect the quality of services provided by the Public Service. We must all be able to study these changes thoroughly.

This bill is of fundamental importance to all Canadians because it deals with the very people who are there to deliver the services of the federal government to the citizens of this country. I am dismayed that the Conservative government has decided to pursue this particular course of action.
February 13, 1992

Members on this side of the House support clauses in this bill that contribute to strengthening the Public Service. We support any and all initiatives that will increase the accessibility of services to all Canadians. We agree with any move on the part of the federal government that will improve relationships with its employees.
Canadians are tired of confrontation. They do not want to see the government and its employees bickering. Whereas the Conservatives are more inclined toward confrontation and enforcement, we in the Liberal Party believe in dialogue and fairness. If members of-the Public Service are not treated with dignity, then the entire workings of the federal government are compromised.
The Liberal Party has urged the government to establish a special committee of Parliament to consider the principle of the bill as well as its substance in the total context of PS 2000 as recommended by the public accounts committee.
It is important for us as parliamentarians to take our time on the renewal of the Public Service. Mistakes that we make today could affect the performance of the federal government for many years to come.
It is particularly important to deal with this matter at this time because we are in a serious national unity debate.
I can only speculate on the effects that a demoralized bureaucracy has on services and how this might impact on Canada's unity debate. We must establish the special committee so that we can truly work together to find a formula that will give Canada a Public Service that it truly deserves.
This government simply cannot manage the affairs of this country. Because of this ineptitude, service to all Canadians is suffering. Its inability to deal fairly with public servants has had a devastating effect-

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext:
Unfortunately, I have to interrupt the hon. member.
It being 5 p.m., the House will now proceed to the consideration of Private Members' Business as listed on today's Order Paper.
Private Members' Business

that Bill C-240, an act to amend the Canada Labour Code (unjust dismissal), be read the second time and referred to Legislative Committee B.
He said: Madam Speaker, in addressing Bill C-240 for probably the second or third time in the last number of years there are just a few comments I want to make. Whether I will take the full 20 minutes I am not quite certain.
The substance of the bill, as stated within the bill itself, is:
Subsection 94(3) of the Canada Labour Code be amended by striking out the word "or" at the end of paragraph (f) thereof, by adding the word "or" at the end of paragraph (g) thereof and by adding thereto the following paragraph: (h)-
To put it in context it would say that no employer may
(h) suspend, discharge or impose any financial or other penalty on a person employed by him, or take any other disciplinary action against such a person, by reason of that person having refused to perform an act that he has reasonable cause to believe is prohibited by law.
It is a simple bill and the idea behind it is very straightforward. There is nothing hidden or very complex about it.
It ought to be in the public interest for this Parliament to pass an amendment to the Canada Labour Code that would help all employees under federal jurisdiction in assisting the government in enforcing the laws of Canada. That seems to be a reasonably noble objective to almost anyone.
This bill in itself probably would not do enough in some circumstances to cause employees to take the risk involved in losing their employment by refusing to carry out a direct order, which normally in industry is a cause for dismissal.
But this bill, together with other types of law enforcement mechanisms, together with the processes of grievances and arbitration and the courts, and with other types of amendments to other pieces of legislation, commonly called whistleblowing legislation, may assist many employees across Canada in having the gumption to take the risk involved. They might then refuse to cany out certain instructions from their employers that could

February 13, 1992
Private Members' Business
place both their employers and themselves in contravention of the law if those instructions were carried out.
To give a couple of examples of areas in which this might happen, it may be a necessary tool or a worthwhile tool in terms of the protection of the environment.
It is not uncommon across Canada today to find many employees who are required on a regular basis to discharge toxic substances into waterways or into areas that the law forbids. This is even despite the limits of pollution control permits and other legislation and regulations that are designed to prevent a company from making those kinds of discharges.
In many industrial towns, in a number of industries- and these are not necessarily under federal jurisdiction, but some of them will be-it is a standing joke among employees in a particular industrial operation and among the citizens in the community that as soon as it gets dark, just shine a spotlight.
It would be very obvious that a lot of discharges are taking place into a river that ought not to take place, not only from a moral or ethical or environmental judgment, but also according to the laws of that province or the laws of this nation.
It has become such a common occurrence for that kind of practice to take place that it is necessary for this Parliament and other legislatures to send some kind of signal out to people in the working community that they do have the right to say no. They should have this right without putting their livelihoods and the livelihoods of their families at risk.
Surely, that is the least they should expect from Parliament whose job it is, presumably, to pass laws for the protection of the public and to create mechanisms to enforce those laws.
The appeal that I am making is to allow employees to assist in the enforcement of the laws of the land. I know in previous debates in this place and in many private discussions, there were many who objected saying: "There is obvious opportunity if someone refuses to carry out an order that would obviously be illegal. Surely,
the grievance procedures and the arbitration procedures and the courts will come to their assistance".
That is not always the case. Even more so, a lot of working people do not believe that is the case. If they do not believe that is the case, they are not going to place their livelihoods at risk and sometimes 10, 15, 20 years of seniority in order to enforce a law or in order not to place themselves in the position of violating the law.
It is again a matter of making them feel comfortable in the role of helping us to enforce the laws that we pass.
Another example is we have had many, many media reports when it comes to the collection of fees and duties, et cetera, at border crossings. For many customs officers, there is a large amount of moneys that ought to be public revenues escaping across those borders when goods are shipped without proper manifests and proper bills of lading being filled out and supplied.
Goods are smuggled across and I suggest sometimes that it likely happens on the direction of someone other than the truck driver involved. It becomes a matter of practice over the years.
When that kind of activity is carried on, especially with the cutbacks there have been in the Public Service, an awful lot of revenue that ought to be collected is not being collected. One reason would be because employees do not feel that they can put a halt to it themselves and have any guarantee that their jobs and their livelihoods will be protected.
We all like to believe that people would say: "You are asking me to do something that is against the law. There is no way I am going to do it". In the real world when you have years and years of earning capacity at stake, people just do not take those chances.
There was another private members' bill just a week ago, I think it was on Februaiy 4. It was submitted by my colleague, the member for Mission-Coquitlam, and was legislation concerning whistleblowing. Again, part of the purpose of that bill coincides with the bill that is presently before us. It would approach it from a different angle. It encompassed amendments to several pieces of legislation in order to accomplish its task, but it stated it in a more positive way that employees would have the
February 13, 1992

right to blow their whistle on an employer if they felt that they were doing something wrong. This goes the other step and attempts to protect their livelihood.
It is also somewhat similar to the provision within the Canada Labour Code. I believe it is section 128 of part II of the Canada Labour Code where an employee has the right to refuse work when that employee has reasonable grounds to believe that the performance of such a task would place his life in jeopardy or may cause injury to himself or to others. The same kind of principles are involved.
For years and years and years, until 1984, we had similar kinds of objections in this House to that kind of legislation, which was cast in the dying days of the Parliament that ended in 1984, as are made against this legislation and against the bill that was submitted by my colleague for Mission-Coquitlam just a week or so ago.
People at that time also believed that if the matter went to grievance through arbitration or through the courts that surely the laws of the land, the courts and the judicial system would serve to protect the right of someone to protect their own life by refusing direct orders, but that did not happen then until we had those kind of laws. It is still sometimes difficult to get employees to take the kind of risks that are necessary to protect themselves. If they are being asked to take risks of their own livelihood in order to help enforce the law, it is even farther fetched to think they are going to take that kind of gamble. People simply do not do that. Anyone who thinks they will, except on the odd occasion where somebody is really so conscientious that they think: "God, this is against the law and even if I am going to lose my job and my livelihood and my pension rights and everything else, I am going to help enforce that law because I am a good citizen", has got to be dreaming if they think that ordinary employees out in the labour force are going to behave like that. They simply do not.
There are, regardless of party, philosophy and ideology, a lot of members of Parliament and a lot of members of provincial legislatures whom I still think are very much liberal idealists. It does not matter if they are Liberals, Tories or socialists or what they are. There is a tendency for a lot of people to think, as they come out of
Private Members' Business
the school system, that just because the law says something, it is so, or because we say that people have these rights and those rights that they have those rights. They do not in many cases.
Even with this kind of legislation, if it were passed, and I hope that at some stage it is, along with the kind of companion whistleblowing legislation I referred to and others, we are still going to have severe difficulties. It is hard to even enforce this kind of very clear legislation unless you have a unionized workplace with a very strong militant committee that will ensure that its members understand what their rights are and are willing to fight along with those members to ensure that their rights are protected and the rights that are protected under the law will in fact exist.
I have no illusions that even if we have all of these kinds of protections that everybody in society is still going to be protected if they want to be good citizens. It will help to give them at least a feeling of security that Parliament has said very clearly that they do have these rights. The law makers of the land will assist them if that employee chooses to assist Parliament and law enforcement agencies in the courts in upholding and enforcing the laws that we have deemed it suitable to pass.
I really do not want to say much more. It is a simple concept. I think it is a worth-while and an important concept, but again, I do not have any kind of illusions that this would wave any kind of magic wand to make it an ideal society.
Again, if it helps to give employees under the federal jurisdiction some sense of security, it is our intent to protect their livelihoods. If they assist us in enforcing the laws that we pass, we will have done something worth while. I hope other members agree. I know it needs additional improvements. There are probably companion pieces of legislation and amendments that may be worth while to make to the bill before us, hopefully within a committee, to give it teeth and provide safeguards against abuse or misuse by employees. That is also a possibility. I do not deny that.
I think the concept and the goal is worth while. I hope other members will agree and we will refer it to Legislative Committee B as stipulated and find it possible to proceed.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ross Belsher (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I appreciate having the opportunity speak on Bill

February 13, 1992
Private Members' Business
C-240 introduced for the consideration of this House by the hon. member for Kootenay West-Revelstoke, one of my fellow B.C.ers.
In the brief remarks I will be making on the bill, I want to indicate to hon. members of this House that I shall take a short review of the Canada Labour Code which makes it readily apparent that the code contains already several measures in which the protection of workers under its jurisdiction is already provided for.
Consequently, I am doubtful that the bill's recommendations for change are necessary. Yet, I understand the feelings of the hon. member opposite and his deep concern, because he has come from a trade union background, as I recall in meeting with him in various committees.
In fact, the bill might have some undesirable consequences that we should be aware of when considering its clauses. One of my colleagues will be outlining these in a few minutes.
It may be useful to provide members with a general overview of what Bill C-240 proposes and what currently exists in federal labour legislation. The bill suggests an amendment to the Canada Labour Code which applies to employees in federal jurisdiction. The spectrum of industries under the jurisdiction of the code is very broad in scope and covers a wide range of economic and industrial activity.
The range of industries covered by the code's jurisdiction encompasses the different modes of interprovincial and international transport, including railways, airlines, trucking and bus transport. Encompassed as well are the telephone, telegraph and cable systems, shipping, long-shoring, broadcasting, banking, pipelines, ferries, tunnels and bridges, primary fishing and most Crown corporations.
Also included are certain undertakings that have been declared by Parliament to be for the general advantage of Canada, including grain elevators, uranium mining and processing, flour and feed mills. These are the industries to which the code applies and which would be affected by the hon. member's proposals in Bill C-240.
To be clear on what is being suggested by this bill, the hon. member for Kootenay-Revelstoke recommends an addition to the unfair labour practices section of the code, section 94(3), a paragraph that would prohibit an employer from discriminating against an employee who
refuses to do an act required by the employer but which in the employee's estimation is believed to be unlawful.
The words of the proposals are:
No employer or person acting on behalf of the employer shall:
(h) suspend, discharge or impose any financial or other penalty on a person employed by him or take any other disciplinary action against such a person by reason of that person having refused to perform an act that he has reasonable cause to believe is prohibited by law.
A brief reading of section 94 of part I of the code will indicate the numerous prohibitions against unfair practices by an employer against an employee that are related to industrial relations. For example, under section 94(3)(f) an employer cannot discriminate against an employee because the employee refuses to do something that would be prohibited by the labour code. In other words, if something is prohibited by the code and an employee refuses to do it, an employer cannot penalize him or her. There are protections in the code to support the employee in this regard.
Another example of the protection afforded to employees can be found in part II of the code which deals with the right to refuse to do dangerous work. If an employee has reasonable cause to believe that conditions exist that pose a danger, he or she may refuse to do the work. The employee may not exercise the right to refuse work if the refusal puts the life, health or safety of another person directly in danger or if the danger is inherent in the employee's work or is a normal condition of employment.
An example of such a situation might be where a flight attendant discovers threatening conditions of an aircraft and reports them to the flight captain for repair. The unsafe conditions constitute a legitimate grounds for a refusal to work. However, the flight attendant does not have the right to refuse to work once the deficiencies have been corrected.
The procedure under part II of the code requires that an employee must report a dangerous situation to his or her employer and to a member of a safety and health committee if one is established or to the appointed safety and health representative, if any. On receipt of the report the employer must investigate the report in the presence of the employee and one member of the safety and health committee where one exists. If this results in an employer's or committee's decision that no condition or danger exists but the employee continues to reason-
February 13, 1992

ably believe in the existence of a situation of danger, he or she may continue to refuse to work but both the employee and the employer must then seek an investigation by a Labour Canada safety officer. If the safety officer decides that a situation of danger does not exist, the employee can no longer refuse to work.
The employee may nevertheless require the safety officer to refer his or her decision to the Canada Labour Relations Board. A determination of the matter by the board is final.
These procedures establish safeguards that serve to protect the employees rights to refuse to do work that would endanger his or her person without fear of reprisal or retaliation by an employer, including dismissal. An employee dismissed or exercising this right under this section of the code has the right of appeal in this case to the Canada Labour Relations Board.
These provisions were reviewed and improved upon during the last round of major amendments to the Canada Labour Code in 1984. The hon. member for Kootenay West-Revelstoke undoubtedly feels that the amendments proposed in his bill would bring about a further improvement in the rights of a worker to refuse to do work he or she considers contrary to the law. No member of the House, I am sure, is likely to be against improving the rights of Canadians. However, I would suggest that Bill C-240 does not break any new ground. It does not add anything new to the Labour Code.
I have cited examples of protection to aggrieved employees under the Canada Labour Code to various forms of redress against wrongful dismissal resulting from an order by an employer to violate certain provisions of the code. The protection afforded to employees through the Canada Labour Code in this regard is comprehensive. Clearly an act in violation of the Canada Labour Code is subject to punitive provisions of the code itself, as it should be.
I would also suggest that in cases in which an employee is ordered to carry out an act which contravenes the law other than the code then recourse for the application of the appropriate penalties exist under the Criminal Code.
Private Members' Business
Therefore I respectfully submit that the existing provisions of the Canada Labour Code provide the necessary coverage that workers need in the matter of their right to protection against arbitraiy retaliations by an employer. The proposed amendment while well intentioned, and I can understand the hon. member's concern, should at this time not be adopted. We should continue with the code as it now is.

Madam Speaker, I thank you once again for recognizing me. It was mentioned by the members who spoke earlier that the Canada Labour Code came about in 1984.1 am happy to say that at the time I was involved in clearing up the wording of the labour code. I have very carefully read the amendment that is put forward by this Bill C-240. I would tend to agree that the thrust of the amendments to be made are surely made in good faith. For that, I commend my colleague from British Columbia.
On the other hand, I am inclined to believe that the labour code, as it is set out covering the federal jurisdiction, has given ample clout to the employee to refuse work he or she believes to be illegal or dangerous.
There is no question in my mind that if an employer asks an employee to do something illegal, this clearly contravenes not only the Canada Labour Code, but the criminal law. The hon. member for Kootenay West suggests that criminal law would not or might not cover an employee who refuses to work under these circumstances. I suggest the hon. member must lack confidence in the laws of our land.
I do not have a background as a labour union person. However, I have worked in situations where I did belong to a union. While the overwhelming majority of employees in unions are good, conscientious workers, I think under some circumstances employees might use this in a mischievous way.
I read the interview that the hon. member went through when he appeared on December 4, 1991, to more or less defend his bill to be brought into the House. The hon. member stated at that time it is not always credible to believe that a citizen is going to say that he will not do something illegal because he fears he will lose his job. I submit to you that many of our citizens do have the courage of their convictions. I would grant them the

February 13, 1992
Private Members' Business
benefit of the doubt to say they would speaking up if they were asked to do something illegal.
One of the questioners at the time, the member for Kingston and TTie Islands, asked if this would include refusing work which would be hazardous to a person's health. Here I find myself squarely on the side of the member for Kootenay West. I believe that if an act is illegal, it is going to be covered by the Criminal Code and definitely by the Canada labour laws.
When you come into the area as to whether an act or a job will be dangerous to a person's health, it brings me back to situations which have occurred in our history before. The asbestos strike in Quebec was because of health hazards for the people who were working there. The people were right at that time to strike because of the general work conditions and conditions that were injurious to their health.
Today, we hear more and more about the environment. We hear for example about the dumping of chemicals into our rivers and lakes. This should definitely be stopped. Is the hon. member, in putting forth his private member's bill, suggesting that workers, unionized or not, across Canada do not have a stake in our environment? Is he suggesting they will not tell the authorities if something is being done that they believe to be injurious, not only to their health, but to the health of their fellow citizens? If that is so, I suggest to you with all respect, Madam Speaker, that these people are doing a disservice to our nation.
I would encourage anyone who is engaged in this type of activity to surely tell the authorities so we can act on it properly.
The environment is something that belongs to all of us. Unless we as Canadian citizens are prepared to defend it by whistleblowing if necessary, I think we are in jeopardy as a nation.
I read over the labour code this afternoon and have virtually immersed myself in it over the past two or three weeks since I became the labour portfolio critic. I am reasonably secure in my knowledge that the labour code
will indeed cover just such a case as this amendment proposes to stop.
I believe that the labour code, federally, is perhaps much stronger than those of the provinces. With all respect to my hon. colleague, I believe that all provinces should have labour codes as strong as the federal code with regard to the matters of protection for the employee if he or she is doing something illegal or injurious to their health. Perhaps this should be addressed in the provincial legislatures.
