My party believes it is always necessary to review whatever legislation we have, and I include here the Canada Labour Code, to see how we can strengthen it and make it better for our citizens.
Although Bill C-240 tends to bring our attention to the Canada code, I am not sure it will bring about the desired effect the hon. member believes it will.
At this point, I believe this legislation needs further modification to change the labour code to make it beneficial to all of our citizens. I think it needs a little more work, but I compliment the member for bringing it to the attention of this particular section in the House, so we can once again make sure the legislation serves our people.

Madam Speaker, I am pleased to rise today to take part in this debate on Bill C-240 introduced by the hon. member for Kootenay West-Revelstoke. Hon. members will appreciate the importance of ensuring that our labour laws are current and relevant in addressing the circumstances we find in federal industries under the jurisdiction of the Canada Labour Code.
This bill seems to have been introduced in response to the hon. member's assessment of an isolated event described by him when a similar proposal was debated in this House in 1983. The proposed amendment is being introduced in the Parliament of Canada to address the actions of a handful of employers.
When amendments to the Canada Labour Code have been made in the past, they have been introduced in response to changing circumstances in federally-regulated industries. Actually, legislative amendments should be contemplated in the context of a requirement for such
February 13, 1992

inervention by Parliament. It is incumbent upon the sponsor of a bill to demonstrate that new or improved legislation is needed to protect and promote the rights of Canadian workers in the workplace.
The presentation of such evidence during the honourable member's introductory remarks might have persuaded us that the proposed amendments are required and should be adopted. We have already heard of the way in which an employee is protected against acts of discriminatory behaviour by an employer who might, for instance, counsel an employee to carry out an act which would breach the law under the unfair labour practices section of part I of the Canada Labour Code. We have also been apprised of the right of an employee to refuse to do dangerous work. The avenues of appeal available to employees and the safeguards in place to protect employees exercising such rights against discrimination by the employer have been explained. These latter procedures are contained under part II of the Canada Labour Code.
Part III of the code contains yet another separate section under labour standards dealing with unjust dismissal and I want to comment briefly on these provisions because they are yet another important example of the way in which the employee is protected against unjust treatment by an employer. The unjust dismissal provisions of part III of the code provide an employee with the right to make a complaint in writing within 90 days of his or her dismissal to a federal inspector if the employee considers the dismissal to be unjust. This part of the act applies to employees in federal jurisdiction who have completed 12 consecutive months of continuous employment with an employer and who are not members of a group of employees covered by a collective agreement.
Under this provision, the employee or the inspector may make a request to the employer for a written statement giving reasons for the dismissal. Any employer who receives such a request is obliged to provide the person who made the request with such information within 15 days. An inspector, on receipt of a complaint, shall endeavour to assist the parties to the complaint to settle the complaint or will appoint another inspector to do so. A complaint that is not settled at this stage can be
Private Members' Business
referred to adjudication. In fact, where a complaint is not settled, the inspector, within a period of time that he or she considers reasonable, can refer a written request for further action on the complaint to the next stage, which is adjudication.
The Minister of Labour may then appoint an adjudicator to hear the complaint. The adjudicator is to give full opportunity to the parties to the complaint to present evidence and make submissions. The adjudicator shall consider whether the dismissal of the person who made the complaint was unjust and render a final decision thereon. Where an adjudicator decides that a person has been unjustly dismissed, he or she may order the employer who dismissed the person to pay compensation, reinstate the person in his employ, and do whatever is equitable to require the employer to counteract any consequence of the dismissal.
In reflecting upon these legislative clauses and the attention to detail contained therein, I am impressed by their comprehensiveness. These provisions, in conjunction with similar protections in parts I and II of the Canada Labour Code, comprise a thorough legal foundation, a foundation that has been constructed with the rights of workers in mind. In this case, this legal foundation serves to protect the right of the worker from dicriminatory actions by an employer.
In closing, my remarks have covered what I believe to be two important considerations relating to bill C-240. First, several legislative safeguards are currently in place to protect employees from discriminatory treatment at the hands of their employers. Indeed, I see no evidence to change my view that the present industrial relations climate does not warrant such legislation.
Second, if this bill were to be adopted, I believe it would be rendered redundant by the fact that the existing provisions of parts I, II, and III of the Canada Labour Code are comprehensive in the protection afforded to the rights of Canadian workers.

Madam Speaker, I am very pleased to be able to participate in the debate today on this private member's bill.
What the private member is attempting to do is introduce legislation which would toughen up the Canada Labour Code. The effort is very laudable. He

Private Members' Business
believes that there is a perception out there that workers feel that if they report or if they are asked to do an illegal activity and they report it, they would be punished for doing so.
I would argue that this protection already exists in the Canada Labour Code. It exists through grievance procedures, it exists through the unjust dismissal procedures, and so on. There is a fine in the Canada Labour Code which is the result of a lot of consultation and refinements over the years. There are a lot of fine checks and balances which do provide that protection, especially to those under federal jurisdiction.
From the intent of this bill people might believe that management asks its employees to break the law and do illegal or dangerous activities. I do not believe this to be the case so much any more. Management today is quite responsible about that sort of thing. We have provincial labour practices and the Canada Labour Code.
Employers and firms coming under the jurisdiction of the Canada Labour Code, such as companies operating in the transportation, communication and other major industries of national importance, play a key role in the Canadian economy.
The hon. member for Kootenay West-Revelstoke introduced this bill in response to a specific isolated incident which occurred in his riding many years ago. I believe it had to do with pulp mills. The proposed amendment does not accurately portray the current state of employer-employee relations in industries under federal jurisdiction.
There are many penalties which can be imposed on an employer by the Canada Labour Relations Board, and the board plays an important role in these aspects. When an employee has been disciplined for refusing to perform an act that he or she had reason to believe was prohibited by the law, the board may order specific action to be taken against that employer.
One example of such a penalty is that under section 99 of the Canada Labour Code, the Canada Labour Relations Board may order an employer to reinstate an employee who has been laid off or otherwise discriminated against. It may order the employer to pay to an employee compensation that he or she was forced to forgo as a result of this discrimination.
We have two examples. The employer can be required to reinstate the employee and pay that employee compensation. Also, the board may ask the employer to rescind any disciplinary action that may be taken against that employee. Those are strong regulations in the Canada Labour Code.
What this member is doing is introducing a bill which if passed would supplant the penalties in the Canada Labour Code and impose others. I do not believe this might be appropriate. Is it appropriate for the Canada Labour Relations Board to become involved in disciplinary matters resulting from attempts by employees to enforce legislation other than the Canada Labour Code? The Canada Environmental Protection Act, for example, sets out specific protection for persons who have attempted to enforce that act.
Section 58(4) of the Canada Environmental Protection Act states: "Notwithstanding any other act of Parliament no employee of a department, board or agency of the Government of Canada or of a corporation to which any regulation made under 54 applied shall be disciplined, dismissed or harassed for making a report".
Each law of Parliament has its own disciplinary provisions. The Canada Labour Code has its own, and each is applied to each jurisdiction.
I would like to emphasize that Parliament is in the best position to determine the seriousness of the obligations any given situation might impose and the remedies that are likely to be most appropriate to the circumstance.
In the case of labour relations, the prohibitions and penalties or method of redress established for labour relations purposes under the Canada Labour Code are not likely to be commensurate with the requirements of other pieces of legislation. The prohibitions and remedial measures in the code were established to give meanings to the rights granted to employees and employers under the code. They should not be expected to perform a function different than their original purpose.
Workers who have been subject to discriminatory treatment by employers, because they have attempted to enforce the provisions of legislation, already have recourse to numerous protections that have been described by other hon. members in this debate.
February 13, 1992

I would like to comment briefly on a course of action open to employees that has not yet been mentioned. We have already heard a number of examples of the protections that are available to employees directly in the provisions of parts I, II and III of the Canada Labour Code. I mentioned those before. The Labour Relations Board may be able to step in. It would rescind any disciplinary action. It would ask to reinstate the employee and the employer could be made to give a payment to an employee. There are others.
One that has not been mentioned is the grievance procedure. There is a grievance procedure because if you are in a period of collective bargaining, let us say there is an agreement for two years, during that period there are to be no strikes by the union or lock-outs by the company. During that two year period, for example, there has to be a method of solving disputes and that is the grievance procedure. We have a grievance procedure to which employees can avail themselves.
The grievance procedure provides an avenue of appeal for employees covered by collective agreements. For those not covered, there is the unjust dismissal provisions of part III of the code. These address the rights of the unorganized, non-union employees who are not covered by collective agreement. The grievance procedure provides an appeal procedure for other employees.
I would like to indicate that when our labour laws were constructed, they were constructed with enforcement penalties appropriate to the Labour Relations Act and consistent with the spirit of the intent of labour legislation. For this reason, and because of the numerous methods of appeal available to employees in support of their rights, I would respectively submit that Bill C-240 should not proceed any further.
I would very much like to compliment the member for Kootenay West-Revelstoke for bringing it to our attention. It is a laudable bill. The spirit of the bill can be admired, but I believe that employees have many recourses of action to which they may avail themselves. They have full protection under the law. This has worked out to be quite a strong protection and has worked well up until now. Therefore, I do not believe that we should proceed further with this bill.
Private Members' Business

speakeroldname: Mr. Ken James (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Labour):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I have listened with great interest to the debate on private members' Bill C-240. Those who have taken part in the debate have presented for the consideration of hon. members the results of their reflections on the content of the bill introduced by the hon. member for Kootenay West-Revelstoke.
Over the course of the debate today on this bill, we have heard much about the intended purpose of the bill. We have also heard about some of the practical difficulties or legislative conflicts which might arise in implementing its provisions.
Hon. members who have spoken in the debate have made a number of useful and constructive observations, and some of these remarks stand out as particularly relevant. We should keep these in mind as we consider the acceptability of the proposed amendment.
One such line of debate has been to the effect that several legislative avenues currently exist to protect employees against unfair treatment by employers in situations in which they refuse to carry out an act that is contrary to the law. Because of these protections found in the existing legislation, Bill C-240's recommendations for change have been described by some as being redundant.
Part I of the Canada Labour Code, for example, protects the rights of workers to refuse to carry out an act that is prohibited under the code. These protections would prevent an employer from discriminating against or treating an employee unfairly by an alteration in pay, a suspension or dismissal where the employee refused to carry out an employer's directive that is specifically forbidden by the code.
Another example is found in the health and safety provisions of part II of the code. These procedures establish safeguards which serve to protect the employee's right to refuse to do work that would endanger his or her person without fear of reprisals or retaliation by an employer, including dismissal. An employee dismissed for exercising this right, under this section of the code, has the right for appeal and, in this case, to the Canada Labour Relations Board.

February 13, 1992
Private Members' Business
Part III of the code, under labour standards, contains a section dealing with unjust dismissal. It provides an employee who is not represented by a trade union with the right to make a complaint in writing to a federal inspector if the employee feels that he or she has been unjustly dismissed.
There are provisions for written statements by the employer outlining the reasons for the dismissal as well as for further stages of appeal, including involvement by the federal inspector and the appointment of an adjudicator by the Minister of Labour.
At the adjudication stage there is a full opportunity for the parties in the complaint to present evidence and make submissions prior to a final decision.
Reference has also been made to the fact that unionized workers under the code are covered by collective agreements which generally contain grievance procedure mechanisms. The grievance procedure provides an appeal procedure for employees covered by the contract who feel that their rights have been abridged along the way. The unjust dismissal provisions of part III of the code address the rights of the non-unionized employees who are not covered by a collective agreement. The grievance procedure provides an appeal procedure for organized employees covered by the collective bargaining regime.
In addition, it should be noted that provisions found within the Human Rights Act give prominence to the role of the citizen in society and mandate the Human Rights Commission to hear complaints by the individual.
If there is an alternative review procedure available to the complainant that ought to be exhausted, or if there is another act of Parliament with a more appropriate procedure for dealing with the complaint, the commission, that being the Human Rights Commission, will direct the complainant in the most effective course of action.
It was pointed out by a previous speaker that labour relations issues often border on subjects within the purview of the human rights legislation. Given this fact, the Human Rights Commission can clearly be a practical alternative avenue of appeal for employees who might be the victim of the discriminatory treatment contemplated by Bill C-240. It is a treatment and a concern that
certainly the member who has proposed this bill has been concerned about.
I found it especially interesting to note the concept of progressive discipline and its importance before adjudicators in appeal proceedings in federal jurisdiction industries. It is clearly a process that encourages fairness in the treatment of employees in disciplinary matters.
The practice of issuing warning letters to employees in writing not only documents the disciplinary process but also provides an encouragement to employers to treat their workers with fairness.
In the context of Bill C-240, the process implied in this concept would also encourage employers to refrain from counselling workers to act in ways that would be contrary to the law.
An important comment was made earlier in the debate in the reference to the provisions of the Canada Environmental Protection Act. The act explicitly protects individuals from discriminatory measures or ultimate dismissal because the individual seeks to enforce the provisions of the act.
This protection is specific to the Environmental Protection Act just as the current provision, section 94(3) of the Canada Labour Code is specific to the code and not to some other act.
I agree with the earlier speaker in questioning the appropriateness of having the Canada Labour Relations Board, as provided in Bill C-240, involved in disciplinary matters related to attempts by employees to enforce legislation other than the Canada Labour Code.
This illustrates the point that each type of legislation should have its own enforcement mechanisms and penalties appropriate to the nature of the particular legislation and Parliament is best equipped to make such a determination.
In the case of labour relations, the prohibitions and penalties for a method of redress established under the Canada Labour Code were established to reinforce the rights granted to employees and employers under its jurisdiction.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: I believe the hon. member's time has expired. The hon. member for Bramalea-Gore-Malton has another couple of minutes before six o'clock.

Mr. Speaker, previous speakers have outlined a number of major objections to the bill under consideration today, Bill C-240.
They have argued that measures already exist to protect workers who might be forced by an employer to carry out an act that contravenes a particular law. As detailed in their remarks, there are several ways in which an individual worker is protected against the form of discrimination described in the bill.
In my opinion, the adoption of this bill would only serve to confuse the functioning of our current legal structure since it would subject certain matters that are dealt with in other legislation to labour law, as found in the Canada Labour Code.
In my remarks today, I would like to briefly comment on the Canadian Human Rights Act. When we consider the alternatives available to individuals, including workers who feel they are being discriminated against or treated unjustly by employers, the human rights act is particularly relevant. It spells out its purpose very clearly in the preamble to the act. The purpose of the act is:
To extend the laws of Canada to give effect to the principle that every individual should have an equal opportunity with other individuals to make for himself or herself the life that he or she is able and wishes to have, consistent with his or her duties and obligations as a member of society.

Mr. Speaker, when I raised this question originally in the House in October, I
Adjournment Debate
was asking the minister what he would do about the government's high interest rate, high dollar, high tax policies that were driving thousands of Canadian shoppers south of the border and thousands of Canadian jobs to the United States. At that time, the unemployment rate in Canada was 10.2 per cent and the minister said his policies were working. He told us that: "The unemployment rate is going down, not going up".
Today we find ourselves with an unemployment rate of 10.4 per cent. Unemployment is going up. It is not just the unemployment rate but it is the thousands of people who have dropped out of the work force in addition to those who are not getting recorded. On top of that there are a record number of Canadian welfare cases. This government's high interest rate, high dollar, high tax policies still continue to plague Canadians.
The minister is unrelenting. We have had three interest rate increases in the last three weeks. The interest rate has gone up 47 basis points. This is an attempt by the government to keep the dollar up, but the high dollar is what is costing us jobs. Our interest rate in Canada is more than twice the U.S. rate. The U.S. rate is 3.50 per cent. In Canada, the rate is now up to 7.46 per cent. This is away beyond the historical spreads with the American rates.
Who is this helping? It is not helping Canadian producers or Canadian exporters; Canadian businesses that want to create jobs here. This is the difficulty with this policy. Today we saw one response. Rather than dealing with some of the fundamentals such as our tax structure, high interest rates, high dollar structure which is driving these jobs south and Canadian consumers south, the government brought in some band-aid measures to stop cross-border shopping from decimating communities along our entire frontier.
What did we see? There was no tax measure in respect of gasoline. They did not deal with the question of gasoline pricing in Canada vis-a-vis the United States, yet our Liberal Party task force on deindustrialization and economic renewal found in our hearings that this was the single biggest reason why Canadians went to the United States to shop, cheaper gas prices. We met truckers who had not bought fuel in Canada in six months; they bought it all in the States.

Adjournment Debate
What else did this government do? It attempted to blackmail the provinces into harmonizing their provincial sales taxes with the GST. It said: "We will collect provincial sales taxes on cross-border shoppers who are returning to Canada but only if you harmonize your provincial sales taxes with our GST". In other words, you impose your provincial sales taxes on things you are not taxing already such as clothes, food, shoes, books and many other items. We say to the government tonight that the provinces will not be blackmailed into introducing the GST.
Finally, the government is decimating the mail order industry. What does it do? It does not give us a level playing field. The Americans put a $10 charge on Canadians doing business there. We put on a $5 charge. For whom is this government working? Let it get its act together.

speakeroldname: Mr. Murray Cardiff (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Agriculture):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Agriculture
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to have the opportunity to respond to my hon. colleague's remarks. I want to remind members of this House that we are working and considering the people of this country in the policies we have put in place and the policies we are continuing to bring forward.
We have to be prudent. We have to be careful where we spend our money and we have to make sure that when we do harmonize measures we are saving money. The government believes that the economy is on the road to recovery. To do this we had to bring inflation under control. Inflation pressures had to be reduced, there is no question about it. I am sure the hon. member would agree. As well, it is essential for sustainable lower interest rates if we follow that program.
We believe our policies are working. Inflation pressures are easing. Over the second half of 1991, CPI inflation was 1.7 per cent. Interest rates had declined in step and are almost 7 per cent lower than their peak in May 1990. The prime interest rate is 7.5 per cent, the lowest rate since May 1973.
The economic recovery began in the second quarter of 1991 and is continuing. UDP, a factor cost, grew at an annual rate of 3.3 per cent in the second and third quarters of 1991. The pace of the recovery weakened in the fourth quarter due in large part to a weak international economy, particularly the unexpected weakness in the United States. As growth picks up in the United States, Canadians will benefit from an expanding market for their exports and a stronger over-all economy.

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity to speak in more depth on a question which I previously asked the Minister of Employment and Immigration regarding the government's lack of commitment to students.
I would like to share with this House some of the feedback that has been received from students in Prince Edward Island. In today's Guardian, a report indicates that students are questioning the federal government's sincerity when it comes to student needs. A delegation of Island students report that skyrocketing tuition fees, federal funding cuts for post-secondary education, taxes on student loans and books make it difficult to believe that the federal government is serious about a prosperous future for Canadians.
According to Andrew Hughes, a representative of the P.E.I. branch of the Canadian Federation of Students: "The student delegation wants the Mulroney government to start living up to its word as stated in the prosperity agenda. It is hard right now to take the government at its word. Instead of providing a clear path for students to further their education, they are constantly creating barriers".
I have quoted Mr. Hughes to demonstrate that this is not a partisan argument, it is a legitimate argument. Certainly we have been trying to make the same argument on this side of the House for some time.
The consequences of this government's education policies become increasingly apparent in the Canadian labour market and the Productivity Centre quarterly report.
Despite the fact that the unemployment rate across the country is at 10.4 per cent, despite the fact that in my province the unemployment rate is at 16.9 per cent, the second highest in the country, there are approximately
300,000	jobs available in Canada that cannot be filled.
This is an unacceptable situation. There are almost 1.5 million Canadians out of work so there are enough jobs available to accommodate approximately 20 per cent of the unemployed Canadians. Many of these positions require skills that unemployed people do not have. This is also affecting our productivity as a nation. The same quarterly report, 1989, indicated that Canadian busi-

nesses were having production difficulties because they could not find enough skilled employees and they expected the problem to get worse unless education and training policies were changed.
While the recession may have lessened the current impact of this problem, the need to improve our labour force skills still exists. The need for greater skills and education requirements is obvious. Yet, there is not a decline in the number of graduates from post-secondary institutions. It is obvious that if the country is to prosper, if our work force is to be competitive, if we are to ensure that the current level of unemployment is reduced, we must make sure that our education system is accessible and affordable.
I repeat my question to the minister. Will this government remove the 3 per cent surtax on student loans? Will it remove the 7 per cent GST on textbooks? Will the government stop cutting back on funding to post-secondary education which is causing tuition fees to sky-rocket? Will this government finally recognize that students in our education system are the most important block upon which our future competitiveness must be built? Will this minister agree to take action today?

speakeroldname: Mr. Murray Cardiff (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Agriculture):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Agriculture
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the prosperity initiative is an opportunity for all Canadians to contribute to the development of a plan of action for our future economic and social well-being.
In launching this initiative, the Minister of Employment and Immigration tabled a discussion paper "Learning Well, Living Well". This paper identifies a number of the learning challenges facing Canadians and Canada in this decade.
To meet the challenges of the future, Canada will have to improve upon its learning system. High skills jobs, a competitive economy, economic prosperity and a good quality of life are interdependent. To maintain them all Canadians must build a learning system which boosts basic skills and encourages a much higher level of advanced skills.
The government acting alone cannot create a learning culture. On the contrary. There is little government, any government, can do on its own to develop a learning
Adjournment Debate
culture. It will require partnerships among all interested groups and for this reason the government invites all Canadians, parents, students, teachers, labour and management, to participate in the prosperity initiative.

subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the other day in the House I stood to declare that across this country, Canada's 38,000 dairy, egg and poultry producers are preparing to storm Parliament Hill to protest this government's wavering position on the future of marketing boards and supply management. They are holding this government directly accountable for the future of supply management and for the future of the agricultural industry in Canada.
They want the Prime Minister to declare that his government will settle for nothing less than the clarification of article XI in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, nothing less than an unequivocal commitment to supply management.
The proposals that were tabled December 11, 1991, by GATT director Arthur Dunkel would effectively destroy article XI and with it destroy the economic underpinnings that Canada has developed for its dairy, egg and poultry industries. The Dunkel proposals I think are proof positive that the United States is about to get its way with supply management in Canada. It has been bullying its way toward the elimination of quotas as a means of penetrating the Canadian market.
Tariffication will not work. It is incompatible with the principle of supply management. It will knock out the pillars and once supply management is dead, it is simply a matter of reducing the tariffs and then they have got us. That will open the entire Canadian market to excess U.S. agricultural production and will kill the Canadian dairy, poultry and egg producing industries.
When I asked the Prime Minister on February 5 whether he would get tough with the Americans and declare his unequivocal support of supply management, he replied that this government had maintained a vigorous defence of Canada's marketing board structure and will continue to do so. Those kinds of statements are why nobody believes the Prime Minister anymore. While he was waxing philosophic about the virtues of supply management, we find that his Minister for International

February 13, 1992
Adjournment Debate
Trade has been providing all government MPs with briefing notes on how to get out of supply management and sell the concept of tariffication. If you do not believe me, Mr. Speaker, just ask the head of the B.C. Lower Mainland Dairymen's Association.
While the government talks a good line about how it is fighting hard for the principles of supply management, all the while it is quietly preparing to dump marketing boards and sacrifice the future of Canadian farmers.
The other day the Prime Minister chided me for suggesting that we play tough with the Americans. He trivialized the issue by suggesting that we also declare war on them. The Prime Minister knows full well that Canada has been a saint when it comes to the observance of the rules of GATT. He knows full well that we have always abided by its rulings while most other countries I might add, including the United States, have transgressed those recommendations and rulings at will.
I say to the Prime Minister that now is the time to stand up and be counted. Now is the time to get tough and to defend the future of our Canadian farming community, to defend our Canadian way of life because if we lose marketing boards we are going to lose the industry. We are going to jeopardize 38,000 poultry, egg, and dairy operations in all regions of Canada which provide over 60,000 jobs in the production sector and
36.000	jobs in processing.
Tariffication puts a $10 billion industry in grave danger. If the government rolls over on this one, we will dismantle the system which directly provides more than
97.000	Canadian jobs.
That is why Canadian farmers have taken their gloves off. They are not prepared to stand by and watch everything they have worked so darned hard for go down the tubes.
They are angry. They are worried. They want action. From B.C., Ontario, Quebec, and elsewhere across Canada our dairy, egg, and poultry producers are preparing to take a stand. They are preparing to storm Parliament Hill if this Prime Minister and this government fail to keep their promise to maintain our supply management systems and to preserve our Canadian way of life.

speakeroldname: Mr. Murray Cardiff (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Agriculture):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Agriculture
subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it would be very easy to get into a very intense debate on this issue, but we will leave that for another day.
To say that farmers are going to storm Parliament Hill I believe is exaggerating. The farmers I spoke to representing the farm communities, the farm leaders, said they want to come here to show their support for the government's position, their position, in respect to article XI and the furthering and clarifying of article XI, not to come here to create problems with great anger and great fight. To say they are going to storm the Hill is exaggerating a situation, especially with the farm leaders I have spoken with as recently as four o'clock this afternoon.
To say that MPs on the government side have a document indicating how to get rid of supply management is utterly ridiculous. That is not the case. I would love to see a copy of it if the member is so certain there is something like that. I do not believe any member of Parliament does have that.
Canada's position to support article XI has not changed. It is no wonder the producers are confused in this country from the statements that were made here tonight and during other times in Question Period because this government has never wavered in its support. It continues to support the position that was taken over a year ago that was developed by the farm leaders, the federal government, and the provincial government. We had strong supporters that balanced good position and we will maintain that.
I want to assure all members of the House that we are not about to abandon our supply management industries as the negotiations on programs progress. We believe it is a good program. It is a time to be solid, not divided. It is unfortunate that very often comments made in this House indicate that we are divided on the issue. That is not the case.

Mr. Speaker, each year over one million Canadian women are diagnosed with breast cancer. Over 150,000 of these women have resorted to implants to try to ease the trauma of a painful and humiliating surgery and disfigurement that results from this terrible disease. Their fears were eased
February 13, 1992

because Health and Welfare Canada has assured women again and again that there is not sufficient evidence that these products are dangerous.
Today I had the opportunity to speak to a remarkably wonderful woman whom I have had the privilege of getting to know over the past few months. This woman had cancer and subsequent surgery, followed by silicone implants. That was only the beginning. She soon found out that these implants are not safe. Despite Health and Welfare Canada's approval, these products cause even greater pain and suffering. Thousands of women across Canada have suffered major complications from these devices. Dow Coming, a major American producer, has had doubts about their safety since 1971 but it has continued to sell these products anyway. That is 21 years ago, over two decades.
Health and Welfare Canada too has had reason to doubt the safety of the implants. In fact, in 1986, which is over five years ago, a senior scientist at Health and Welfare was fired for questioning the safety of these products, and yet they continue to be sold.
Earlier this week I asked the Minister of National Health and Welfare what he was doing to ensure an effective and safe product review process. He responded that there already is a serious review process. He even had the gall to boast that silicone gel implants are no longer available on the market.
Manufacturers of these implants were requested to stop distributing these products only last month, yet we know that most of the doctors have them in their offices and will continue to use them as long as they are there.
Mr. Speaker, you will note that I did not mention the name of this woman, the reason being that she has received death threats, not one but several, on her answering machine. When she gets home at night from work, she takes her messages off her machine and the message is: "You will die for promoting what you are doing with regard to these implants". This woman has organized a group of women, probably 800 women, in her area. They meet regularly. In fact, they have a conference coming up very, very shortly.
Despite what the minister said here in the House yesterday, she has filed conclusive evidence with the
Adjournment Debate
minister that these implants are defective and that they are cancer causing. Yet the minister continues to deny, deny, deny.
I too would like to mention that I have also received a threat. My threat was by letter. My threat was by the distributor of this product, where he challenged me to dare to say the things that I say in the House of Commons on this product outside the House. I consider that a threat and a harassment of the worst kind.
Shame.

I suggest to the minister once again that it is becoming increasingly clear to me that there is a major cover-up. Who is hiding what at women's expense? I believe the issue is so serious that the RCMP should be called in to investigate. I ask the minister this: What will he do to ensure the product review process is improved so that an atrocity like this will never happen again, and that this one must cease immediately?

speakeroldname: Mr. Murray Cardiff (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Agriculture):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Agriculture
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the government would like to use the opportunity following several weeks of media claims and statements in the House to bring hon. members up to date on the department's actions concerning silicone gel-filled breast implants.
First, let me say that Health and Welfare is very concerned about the comments expressed over the fear of cancer following breast implant surgery. Let me put a stop to speculations right now. Dr. Hans Berkel and his colleagues in Alberta demonstrated clearly that women who have breast augmentation do not have an increased risk of breast cancer. He also found that breast implants do not decrease the survival of breast cancer patients.
This is a very powerful study. More than 11,000 breast implant patients were followed for an average of 10 years. Where 49 cases of breast cancer were expected in the normal population, 23 developed breast cancer after breast implants.
Rarely in the field of science can a better demonstration be made about the low risk of using a medical device. This work which was done in Canada by reputable epidemiologists is confirmed by a similar study done in the United States.

Adjournment Debate
I wish then to reassure the women in Canada who have silicone breast implants that at this time there is no evidence to support the scare tactics used by media and others.
Let us go on now to the basis of this whole discussion. This basis centres on the fact that the Department of National Health and Welfare makes its decisions on safety and effectiveness based on science, not on media reports, not on innuendo and not on testimony of unusual events.

Mr. Speaker, on November 21, just after the announcement of a $700 million package of aid to grain and oilseed producers, I stood in my place and raised a question with the Minister of Agriculture about the methods being used in implementing that program. There had been an announcement that about $7 an acre would be paid for crop land, a quarter of that payment for lands that were seeded to summer fallow, and lands seeded to forage crops would also get one-quarter of that amount.
I wish to respond further to that answer tonight, because it seemed to me that the Minister of Agriculture in his response was pretending ignorance of his own government's policies and his own department's stated objectives.
Among the stated objectives of that department are to encourage diversification and market responsiveness.
Because of the market conditions, a great number of farmers, particularly in the northern prairies in western Canada, have seeded good two, three and four class farming land to forage crops, alfalfa and other grasses. Some of those crops are being processed into cubes and pellets for shipment to the Japanese and South Korean markets and elsewhere. These are export commodities. They depend on export prices. Their market was ruined just as thoroughly by the U.S.-European trade war as any other market.
In his response the minister seemed to ignore that hay prices respond to those same market influences and they are also low. He also seemed to think that his government was doing a good job of looking after forage crops because he talked about having paid something like $50 million in the prairie region to promote forage production and $22 million in the rest of Canada to promote forage production, making a total of $72 million to forage producers.
What he ignored was the sense of my question. I pointed out that I was talking about forage seeded on classes one to four farm land, the very best farm land in Canada. He should have known as the Minister of Agriculture that the program he was talking about only applies to classes five, six and lower classes of farm land. In other words, the program applies to lands that probably should not be growing grains and oilseeds to begin with.
He has totally missed the point and is not addressing the very real problem that the countryside is going to be faced with, now that we have GRIP and this program here. Both of those programs have ignored forage production as an integral part of agricultural production in the northern prairies. He is encouraging those lands to be worked up again and planted into cereals and oil seeds which the system does not need.
I think he has to recognize that forage production is a legitimate crop and pay it on the same basis as cereals and oilseeds.

speakeroldname: Mr. Murray Cardiff (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Agriculture):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Agriculture
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to reinforce and say again that the government came through, as it always has before, and supported farmers with a program of $800 million assistance under the FSAM II. That was in November 1991.
The way the payments were delivered to producers grew out of extensive consultations between this government and members of the Third Line of Defence Committee. This committee is made up of industry, producers, academics and provincial representatives.
The payments were made on the recommendations of producers, academics and provincial representatives. That was how it was made up. It was not totally a minister's decision.
This committee recommended we deliver the assistance based on seeded acreage and pay 25 per cent on summer fallow and 25 per cent on forage.
This serves as another example of how the federal government continues to consult with those affected before making any decisions. It is a process the opposition parties should be supporting.
February 13, 1992

Hon. members should realize that of the three options delivered to the government by the Third Line of Defence Committee, the government selected the one that included the highest level of payments for forage and summer fallow.
The government, under the provisions of FSAM I, delivered $50 million to promote forage production in the prairie region and an additional $22 million to promote forage production in the rest of Canada.
That could hardly be interpreted as the government penalizing farmers with forage crops.
The $700 million is being delivered to compensate that sector for the level of hurt it has sustained as well. The low commodity prices, caused by the international trade war, have been why we have had to stand there and support a program in this country that has been caused by the devastating things that the U.S. and the EEC have been doing.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext:
Pursuant to order made on Wednesday, February 5, 1992, the House will continue the debate on the adjournment motion for the sole purpose of allowing members to make presentations on the results of discussions they have had with their constituents on the constitutional issue.
The hon. member for Levis.

speakerposition: Chief Government Whip's assistant; Deputy Whip of the Progressive Conservative Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, during the past few days we have heard members report to the House on the results of their discussions with Canadians on the constitutional process. During 1991, I also consulted with Canadians, including my own constituents. My questions focused on the economy and a number of items that could be included in the Constitution. Together, these could be defined as an anti-deficit clause.
I think we should take advantage of the fact that Canadians generally disapprove of deficits. Perhaps this would be a good time to include in the Constitution a clause that would put elected representatives in a better position to administer the governments of this country.
The Constitution
The clause would contain certain parameters according to which our elected representatives would be obliged to bring their spending in time wiht the resources of the community, without mortgaging the lives of future generations.
It is time we stopped using deficits as a substitute for taxes. It is easy to say yes to the demands of taxpayers and voters during an election campaign. However, if the Constitution provided for maintaining a balance between what the community pays and earns and what governments can give that community, I think this would make for a fairer and franker political debate during election campaigns. It would mean that candidates, irrespective of their political stripe, would have to explain to voters that the program they are offering or the program voters want would cost a certain amount of money, and that this amount would be raised through the tax system. Today, party candidates are far less forthcoming and are inclined to advertise programs without mentioning the cost involved to the taxpayers because as politicians, they know they will always be able to borrow to fill their orders.
I think that if they face certain restrictions, this may be the best way to reduce the deficits incurred by federal, provincial and municipal governments. Granted, people will say this is technical, that it may create certain problems when definning expenditures. We are used to describing government expenditures in terms of envelopes for the various departments. I would say that if we included an anti-deficit clause, expenditures would also have to include what we call tax expenditures, such as tax rebates enjoyed by taxpayers in certain cases and also the constraints governments impose on certain companies, including environmental or social constraints.
Those are part of the expenses incurred by the community and they should be included in the context of an anti-deficit clause. Some will refer to the famous theory of Keynes, an economist who lived from 1883 until 1946, to oppose an anti-deficit clause in the Constitution. A lot of people refer to that theory these days, but I say that it is obsolete. For one thing, it applied at a time when there was no unemployment. According to that theory, it is in a period of economic difficulties that important public projects should be undertaken. Nowadays, unemployment is always high, it is a chronic problem. The conditions are not what they were in 1950 or 1960.

February 13, 1992
The Constitution
Also, if governments decide during a period of recession or economic crisis to announce important public projects, whether it is the building of roads, houses, et cetera, once the decision is made, these programs must go through the hands of many technocrats and it often takes from 18 to 24 months before they become reality. At that point, economic recovery is under way and the programs that were announced during the economic crisis become inflationary programs that create an artificial demand on money. That is the reason why Keynes theory must not be taken into consideration.
Some will also say that we must provide implementation mechanisms. We will not be able to achieve that in 365 days. But I believe that if there is a consensus to adopt such a clause, we could allow a period of a few years to absorb the accumulated deficit and then, inevitably, there will be no more deficit in the budget.
Some will also mention emergency situations, such as a war or an environmental disaster. In such instances we could for all intents and purposes have a form of agreement or a vote requiring the approval of 75 per cent of the members of the House, or some other mechanism that would have to be discussed and developed further.
After having tried to sell this anti-deficit clause, I received comments and I will end on that note. I received a letter from the Business Council on National Issues which says that this organization would approve the inclusion of an anti-deficit clause in the Constitution. The letter is dated January 8 1992 and it is addressed to me.
I also have a letter dated December 17, 1991 from the Conseil du patronat du Quebec which says that it agrees in principle with including such a clause. Last fall, the Conseil du patronat appeared before the caucuses of members of the Quebec government, the Parti Quebecois caucus and the Liberal Party caucus, to suggest that they include a no-deficit clause in their legislative process. Also, the Quebec Chamber of Commerce, when it appeared before the federal Committee on the Constitution, said that the Chamber-the Quebec Chamber of Commerce-reiterates its support for the idea of putting in the Constitution the principle that the federal and provincial governments must balance
their budgets, as municipal governments are already legislated to do.
That is serious support. Also, I have very important support from a local source, the South Shore Chamber of Commerce, which for all practical purposes covers the federal riding of Levis. They officially supported my plan for a no-deficit clause in the Constitution. I have two more major supporters, the Canadian Chamber of Commerce and Timothy Rae, who said that the deficit problem should be included when the constitutional issue is settled. I refer to an article in the Financial Post of July 4, 1991.
I will conclude, Mr. Speaker. I also received 432 resolutions from municipal councils throughout Canada. I have excerpts from the resolutions of those councils, all 432 of which are in favour of having a no-deficit clause in the Constitution. These resolutions come from all the provinces of Canada.
For these reasons, Mr. Speaker, I ask those who are responsible for presenting the federal government's position and even all federal members of Parliament to take account of what many Canadians who pay and generate wealth want. They have a right to say how this wealth will be spent.

Mr. Speaker, I do not know a great deal about constitutional law, but I do know that I am living in a great countiy and that it has the potential to become even greater.
As Canadians we sometimes forget how good we have it. Canada is one of the most peaceful and prosperous nations on this earth. You just have to ask those outside of Canada. There are thousands of people lined up at embassies all over the world trying to emigrate to our country.
We cannot afford to let constitutional issues divide us and ruin our great land. We need to build a climate where consensus can be reached. It is time to focus.
We need to concentrate on what we want. We also need to concentrate on what we have. We must examine the things we have in common and build on our strengths by looking toward the future.
February 13, 1992

We must establish a Canadian vision, a blueprint for the next generation. We must address the things all Canadians would like to preserve and achieve, instead of the things that divide us.
Then we can begin to agree. Once we begin to agree, we can develop a climate favourable for negotiation. Then we can reach consensus.
It has been my pleasure during the last few months to help residents of Ottawa Centre participate in a constitutional discussion. Many of my constituents have strong opinions and interesting ideas on the Constitution.
In December I distributed a referendum form on the constitutional proposals throughout my riding. The referendum summarized the proposals and divided them into three broad sections, keeping with the government format. Constituents were asked to mark whether they agreed, disagreed or were undecided about each proposal. They were also asked to write down specific comments if they wished.
So far, my office has received in excess of 200 responses. It is obvious to me that Canadians, at least in my riding, like to be directly consulted. We have received a high number of replies in a short time and many forms with written comments. When asked to help, the people feel empowered to set the direction for the country.
Our methods were not scientific and our statistics are not necessarily accurate. However, we have noticed some strong general convictions. Ottawa Centre residents who responded are most concerned about parliamentary reform, economic union and a strong central government.
Respondents expressed overwhelming approval of the proposals that allow more free votes in the House of Commons and called for an elected Senate. In both cases the yes vote was about 80 per cent.
On the proposals dealing with Senate appointments more concentration on Private Members' Business, and the question of provinces and territories submitting names for appointments to the Supreme Court, the support was between 50 and 70 per cent. When asked to comment, respondents clearly demanded reform of the House of Commons and the Senate.
The Constitution
Respondents also approved of proposals dealing with the Canadian economic union. Almost 95 per cent supported the elimination of trade barriers within Canada.
Around 75 per cent supported the proposals dealing with federal power to make laws for the economic union and harmonization of the government budget process.
Fifty-five per cent of the people supported the distinct society clause for Quebec.
Constituents were less supportive of the devolution of power to the provinces. Only the proposals dealing with culture, immigration and broadcasting issues received more than 60 per cent support.
The level of support for other proposals was somewhere between 30 and 50 per cent. For example only 30 per cent supported the elimination of the declaratory power.
It is clear to me from these results that many Ottawa Centre residents want to make the country work. They also have a good idea of what they want Canada to look like.
The referendum is not the only constitutional initiative underway in Ottawa Centre. Something different is happening in my riding. I have been working closely with several Ottawa Centre residents who have set up a constituency assembly process.
They are trying to bring the constitutional discussion down to the grassroots level. The organizers are convinced that there is a need for a fresh approach to the constitutional debate in this country. They believe Canadians are ready to contribute fresh ideas and are looking for channels to do so.
The constituency assembly process is designed to provide such channels. It is a non-partisan citizens' initiative that, by definition, includes everyone in the constituency. The structure stimulates informed discussion and allows for a wide variety of input and perspectives. The intention is not to build a consensus, but to express ideas.
The assembly involves organizing and sharing the results of work study projects on the Constitution. So far, it consists of several workshops and an open house.

February 13, 1992
As far as I am aware, Ottawa Centre is the first constituency to organize a creative democratic process of this nature.
Of course, the assembly was not created in a vacuum. It follows an information session on the Constitution that I hosted last spring, a discussion meeting on the Constitution convened in June, and a workshop series offered through the summer on Parliament Hill. It was all at the initiative of the constituents.
The whole process has been assisted by the creation of an open register to record study projects. The register facilitates communication between Ottawa Centre constituents concerned about the Constitution. Currently over 30 projects have been registered. It is our hope that the register will eventually aid networking between constituencies.
The assembly organizers recognize that citizens are responsible for their Constitution and government. They are hoping the assembly process will deepen the democratic basis of constitutional discussion.
By encouraging Canadians to participate directly in the political process, they believe their approach will show that Canadians have more things in common than the differences that divide them.
They see the constitutional issue not as a crisis for Canada, but a remarkable opportunity to preserve and develop common sense assets such as goodwill, peace and mobility.
I feel tremendously privileged to have constituents who take the concept of self-government so seriously. There are so many of them. I wish to especially acknowledge Gail Stewart, Nancy Doubleday and Dianne Corke. They are actively involved in the political process and they are encouraging others to contribute as well. Such input can only benefit Canadian politicians and make the process of governing richer.
The constituency assembly will likely continue regardless of government deadlines. Ottawa Centre residents still have a lot to say about the Constitution. The process is also flexible enough to include issues of national interest other than the Constitution. I think it is a model that could be adopted in other ridings.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, first 9 I would like to thank the Sarnia-Lambton	Committee	9
for Canada's Future for taking the constitutional propos- 9 als as presented by our government to my community for 9 discussion.	9
This committee is a constituent assembly formed to	9
collect views and write a report on the federal govern-	9
ment's constitutional reform proposals.	Citizens	from	9our community volunteered or were approached from a 9 variety of backgrounds and societal groups	to	form	the	9constituent committee.	9
The Constitution



, fag

February 13, 1992

The committee met as a group and with the public on 13 occasions and an information booth was manned by the members at the Sarnia Eaton Centre on November 27 through 29, 1991.
Interaction with the public of our community took place at the information sessions as well as at four public meetings held at different locations throughout the federal constituency.
I met with the committee on January 24 and was presented with its report. I had already advised the special joint committee on a renewed Canada that a report from the Sarnia-Lambton Committee on Canada's Future would be reporting and I had requested that representatives of the committee personally meet and appear before the joint committee.
I am happy to report that their chairman, Mr. Mark Sutor, secretary Mrs. Shirley Latham and committee member, Mr. Peter Westfall travelled to Ottawa on this past Monday and presented their report.
Upon receipt by myself of Shaping Canada's Future Together proposals, I read and re-read them and then I decided that certainly the way for me to decide on how I should be supportive or question the proposals is that I should listen. So, I have listened either before or after to a lot of presentations.
I listened last summer to 250 high school students in Toronto at a student forum, who talked about keeping our country together. I read the Group of 22 report, I read what the Spicer commission reported on what they heard, I read about what the Group of 15 said, and the Sarnia-Lambton Constituent Assembly Committee told me what our community was saying. I have also watched and read about the constitutional conferences, four or five which have been held as of this date.
As far as the area of Senate reform, this is one of the very important aspects of the institutional reform within the constitutional proposals. The concept has sparked widespread discussions; clearly Canadians have expressed a desire for the old place of privilege to be replaced by a Senate which is more useful, more democratic and more effective.
The divergence of opinions has come as to what form of structure best meets these principles. The Sarnia- Lambton Constituent Assembly supported reform of the
The Constitution
upper House, as with the Group of 15 and the Group of 22. They all called for an elected Senate.
Two further guiding conditions expressed where the powers of the Senate must be carefully delineated and not be broader than those of the House of Commons. The latter should retain their pre-eminent legislative role and that aboriginal people should be guaranteed representation in the Senate.
I myself would like an elected Senate, one based on the principle of proportional representation. In the spirit though of consultation and negotiation I doubt that this will happen. More equitable regional representation may be more likely the outcome.
As an Ontarian what we will lose in seats we will gain in institutional legitimacy and a forum for truer regional representation. In my mind, the Group of 22 may have put it best: "The country needs an institution that will express the national dimension of provincial responsibilities as well as an institution that will express the provincial dimension of national responsibilities."
In the area of distinct society, the Sarnia-Lambton Constituent Assembly Committee interpreted the clause as reasonable, provided that Quebec gains no additional powers which will either affect the other provinces or weaken the federation. It was sympathetic to Quebec's concern for the continuance of its society and its culture.
Distinct society has prompted much debate, as we all know. Clearly, many of the people appearing before the constituent assembly blurred the difference between recognizing Quebec as a distinct society and the federal official languages policy. We all must be careful that the two subjects are not confused.
It seems to me that the country is no longer stuck, as I would call it, on the distinct society proposal. English Canada, it seems to me, from what I have observed and have been told, wants a strong central government, while at the same time English Canada has no problems with the notion that Quebec might exercise powers which the other provinces choose not to exercise.
At the Toronto constitutional conference Montreal lawyer Eric Maldoff pleaded for Canadians to understand the linguistic and cultural fears of French speaking Quebecers. He said: "The question of a survival strategy is a dominant issue in my province. We must be prepared

February 13, 1992
The Constitution
to open our arms to the survival of French speaking Quebecers".
Mr. Maldoff is an English speaking Quebecer and the founding president of the English language rights group called Alliance Quebec.
The students' commission last summer recognized that Quebec should enjoy jurisdiction over its culture, civil code and immigration.
Recently The Toronto Star reported: "As we approach the home stretch we accept the distinct society clause as something we could live with".
What I have observed in recent months is that the people of Ontario believe that the clearest translation of distinct is different, a different society in which one may choose to strike a different balance between the rights of individuals and cultural groups from that may exist in other provinces.
The Group of 15 acknowledged that Quebecers might choose to favour collective rights over individual rights in order to preserve their heritage. The forum members continued: "The distinctiveness of Quebec is an historical fact and a current reality that enriches the lives of all Canadians".
Again, in view of what I have heard and seen, I can endorse the constitutional proposal to recognize Quebec as a distinct society. This recognition is very much in the tradition of flexible constitutional arrangements that have been part of Canada for 124 years. The distinctiveness of Quebec is an historical fact and a cultural reality that enriches the lives of all Canadians.
It allows Quebecers to make their own decisions about the balance that they would like to have in their particular province.
Property rights are part of the proposal, and I would like to touch upon them very briefly.
The charter does not guarantee a right to property and therefore it is the view of the government of Canada that the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms should be amended to guarantee property rights. I recommend the reading of an evaluation done by Mr. David Stratas of the law firm of Osier, Hoskin and Harcourt in Toronto entitled Property Rights and the Canadian Constitution:
Scenario I: After twenty years of effort and sacrifice in meeting mortgage payments, you unexpectedly receive a notice by registered
mail. "Your house shall be expropriated for a new freeway next month," the notice reads. The finer print of the notice indicates that the notice is issued pursuant to the Freeway Act which was just enacted. After further investigation, you discover that owing to "the needs of the motorists of the province" no hearings are to be held in order to determine fair value of property being expropriated -
You find you are getting only 50 per cent of the current market value.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: Maybe the hon. member could file the rest of his documents with the Clerk.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
I would like to end up by saying that I endorse property rights and certainly I commend this evaluation for reading.
Later I will touch on native rights, the economic union, the barriers to trade, and many other areas that should be touched upon in this important debate.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: The list of speakers is as follows: the hon. members for Ottawa-Vanier, Essex-Windsor, and Joliette.

Mr. Speaker, I welcome this opportunity to take part in this special debate on the Constitution and to read into the record some of my own initiatives and those suggested by my constituents. The order was made for the sole purpose of allowing members to make presentations on the results of discussions that they have had with their constituents on the constitutional issue and to table all relevant documents. That is the clear and very specific purpose of this debate.
I started consulting constituents in Ottawa-Vanier last spring. I held a public meeting on June 26, which was set up as a forum on the Constitution, with Jean-Luc Pepin, Professor at the University of Ottawa, Dr. Robert Jackson, Professor at Carleton University, Ms. Caroline Chretien, Liberal researcher for the Liberal caucus, and about 200 people with an interest in these issues.
The survey I conducted at that time concerned the nine recommendations or proposals presented by my leader, Jean Chretien, to the Canadian public on April 21, 1991. His nine point plan was based on a statement on the nature of Canada, a commitment to the Charter
February 13, 1992

of Rights and Freedoms, strengthening the Canadian economic union, institutional reform, the division of powers, including spending power, immigration, the Supreme Court of Canada, aboriginal nations, the amending formula and, finally, a national referendum.
This provided a fairly broad range of items to discuss with our constituents, which I did all last summer. The constitutional forum I mentioned earlier, which was held on June 26, was televised throughout my riding and watched by thousands of constituents. I would like to thank Skyline Cablevision, which agreed to televise the proceedings.
Today the situation is no longer the same. Since last September we have been discussing the government's proposals. I distributed the document in my riding and I am glad to say it was given a rather favourable reception. It was widely discussed by various groups and was the subject of both oral and written comments at my office and in the community in general.
Last summer I went from door to door and I actually knocked on more than 5,000 doors, which is quite something when the temperature is in the nineties, or should I say the thirties. I noticed that people are concerned about the constitutional question. They are wondering whether we politicians will be able to find a solution to this particular problem, whether we will be able to reconcile Canada's duality with a common respect for Canada's regions which are the two pillars, as it were, of this country. What I remember particularly from my meetings with constituents is their concern for respecting the distinctiveness of our regions as well as Canada's duality in a country that has two official languages.
I was left with a great deal to think about after my consultations with the people in Ottawa-Vanier. If we get rid of Canada's duality or if we remove the concept of Canadian regionalism, we destroy this country. In discussions I had with a number of constituents, I tried to make them understand how important it is to respect differences-what we call tolerance-and the importance of respect for duality, for the other person's right to speak the language of his choice, and respect for regional differences, a Canadian concept.
The Constitution
I had a team of volunteers, consisting of public servants, students, unemployed workers, professionals, pensioners and people working in the home, who accompanied me on my walks last summer, and I found that very encouraging. I also sent out two householders. One was on the Constitution and constitutional amendments, a document I will table with the Clerk later on, and one is a questionnaire on how my constituents view the issues, how the division of powers should be changed, and how we could solve the Canadian question.
I would like to inform the House of the results of these surveys.

There were 1,778 respondents. These were voluntary responses given by people who did not have to return the questionnaire but did.
I want to take a few minutes to present a resume or highlights of the results.
To the first question of a constitutional declaration on the future of Canada, 69 per cent of my constituents believe that the constitutional declaration will have to include our commitment to two official languages; 64 per cent want to include cultural diversity; 76 per cent want recognition of the aboriginal people; 43 per cent recognized Quebec as a distinct society, 36 per cent are against and 21 per cent expressed no opinion.
On lowering the barriers between the provinces, a strong majority of respondents, 91 per cent, favoured the free circulation of goods, people and capital in Canada.
On a reformed Senate, 79 per cent of respondents favoured an elected Senate, but one with a right to review rather than a right to veto. The review condition is supported by 65 per cent, with 33 per cent supporting the right to veto. The majority of the people also favoured giving the Senate the right to amend laws proposed by the House rather than a right to reject or to delay.
Concerning the power to the provinces for nominations to the Supreme Court of Canada, 71 per cent of respondents believed the provinces and territories should participate in the nomination of judges to the Supreme Court of Canada.

February 13, 1992
The Constitution
On the constitutional process, the majority of respondents favoured a referendum; 35 per cent favoured a direct participation in discussions rather than leaving decision-making exclusively to elected representatives.
As for the adoption of a constitutional amendment, the majority of respondents prefer a referendum in each province rather than a provincial legislative approval, or two-thirds of provinces representing 50 per cent of the population, which is the present amendment before us.
On the sharing of powers, in the two questionnaires the majority of respondents preferred to give provincial governments the responsibility for education, housing and training, while giving the federal government communications, immigration and unemployment insurance.
In the second questionnaire, the majority favoured federal-provincial co-operation in fields which have been contentious in the past, such as the environment, language and health care.
Those are the results of two questionnaires. Those are the messages I get from the constituents of Ottawa- Vanier. As for myself, I will get a chance to debate these questions whenever the government tables its proposals formally in the House in the months to come.

And now the proposals my constituents came up with. One was for a constitutional log book. One of my constituents suggested setting up a constitutional log book that would contain proposals by people in the riding and where various suggestions could be entered. I have here a copy of this log book, which I will table with the Clerk. It contains documents that reflect the aspirations of my constituents and may have some impact on the committee.
Mr. Speaker, you are signalling that my time is almost up. In concluding, I want to urge the people of Ottawa- Vanier and Canadians in general to continue their participation in this constitutional debate. It is extremely important for us to know where people stand. Personally,
I appreciated the experience of meeting the many people in my riding and discussing these issues with them. I know they are interested, because after all, without a Constitution, we don't have a country.

Mr. Speaker, throughout the country we have seen Canadians trying to come to terms with the very difficult constitutional challenges that face this country and our future. This is certainly true in Essex-Windsor, as it is in other parts of this country.
In the case of Essex-Windsor I have consulted my constituents through talk-back forms, which I have asked members of my constituency to send back, and also through community meetings which I hold regularly. They have focused in more recent months on some of the issues which the Constitution has brought before us.
I could go through a whole list of subjects, as various members have, but I want to focus on five which have been stressed in our meetings and in the responses that I have received. I want to say first that one new element which has emerged in this round of constitutional discussions, as compared with the past round, is the notion of a social charter and putting into the Constitution some commitment, hard or soft.
Suggestions vary, but there should be some commitment nevertheless to the social rights which Canadians believe they have, such as the right of access to medicare, the right of access to a good educational system, the right of access to social services and the right of access to employment or to unemployment insurance in the absence of such, and a right of access to environmental protection.
This is a notion which our party has particularly emphasized and which the premier of my province, Bob Rae, has particularly stressed. Also it is something about which constituents in Essex-Windsor have been especially enthusiastic. Constituents in Essex-Windsor have had to make use of the right to access to unemployment insurance because of the ups and downs in the auto industry.
They have had to make their past history of building access to medical care through community institutions, turning that into a national system. When the national medical care scheme came into effect in this country, they came to see it as something crucial to their lives, especially as they compare themselves to people across the river in Detroit who have to bankrupt themselves and their families in order to provide medical care.
The social charter and a commitment to a social charter is something for which my constituents have stressed their strong support.
February 13, 1992

I was very pleased today to see the premier of Ontario bring out in more detail the notion of a social charter, to outline the particular elements which the Ontario government would like to see included in section 36 of the Constitution as principles to which governments in Canada are committed.
They are principles such as comprehensive, universal and accessible health care, social services and welfare based on need, high quality public, primary and secondary education and the emphasis on preserving and improving the quality of the environment within a sustainable economy.
