I am also pleased to see the commitment which has been suggested by the province of Ontario that agreements reached by governments in areas covered by these social charter rights in the future would be made constitutionally binding.
In other words, it would not be possible for a government to renounce an agreement which it had reached with provinces as, for instance, this government has done in the case of the Canada Assistance Plan in renouncing its commitment to provide support through the Canada Assistance Plan to the various provinces that have been affected by the 5 per cent cap in that plan.
The second area which my constituents have expressed themselves very strongly on is the question of the rights of aboriginal Canadians. People in Essex-Windsor feel strongly that aboriginal Canadians have been left out of the opportunities in our society. They have expressed, in community meetings, their agreement with aboriginal Canadians who emphasize their inherent rights to selfgovernment. They have emphasized that these inherent rights to self-government, in order to become real to aboriginal people, must include significant assistance from the federal government for economic development for aboriginal communities.
The third area which my constituents have expressed their concerns about is the proposals in the federal constitutional package for economic union. There are some parts of this package which are unobjectionable, such as an emphasis on mobility of goods across the country. But there are other parts of that package which
The Constitution
are extremely dangerous, such as removing from the mandate of the Bank of Canada the idea that it should take into account the impact of monetary policy on employment levels. I think that is important. It is also important to see to it that the Bank of Canada maintains a recognition of employment considerations in its policy decisions.
There has also been grave concern among my constituents with respect to the idea that companies might be able to take either provincial or federal governments to court and have laws declared unconstitutional because they run counter to some judicially established notion of economic union. I will have a chance to say more about this in future debates. I just want to report the views of the community meetings that have taken place on that subject.
The other subject I want to deal with which has come out in community meetings is the question of Quebec as a distinct society. I have to say that both in responses to questionnaires to my constituents and in community meetings there have been some serious concerns expressed about the notion of Quebec as a distinct society. This has reflected the fear that many of my constituents have expressed, that if you recognize Quebec as distinct that means giving Quebec special powers.
I think that we can recognize Quebec as distinct in the sense of different without recognizing special powers or special status, but my constituents are concerned that that distinction between a difference and a special status be maintained in the constitutional structure.
The final point which I want to make is something which has come to me in meeting after meeting across my constituency as I have spoken at banquets, as I have met with groups. It has come not just in community meetings or in pamphlet returns, it has come everywhere, and that is a commitment to this country as one Canada, a commitment to national unity, a commitment to the maintenance of a magnificent country. That is the most powerful sentiment which has been expressed by the people of Essex-Windsor. It is a sentiment which I would want to leave with this House as we face the challenge and the future of dealing with the constitutional concerns which the government will bring back to

February 13, 1992
The Constitution
us in the form of its response to the special committee's report when it comes forward.

Mr. Speaker, I have to tell you that I am delighted to avail myself of the little time granted to us by the House to express the feelings of my constituents, the people from the riding of Joliette.
We cannot say much about the future without looking back on the past. In the context of the constitutional debate, two major events have taken place these past few years, say 10 years, that have had a great impact on the people of Joliette. I am talking about the repatriation of the Constitution in 1982, from which Quebec was left out, and, more recently, the failure of the Meech Lake Accord in 1990. I think that these two events have dampened the enthusiasm of those who had believed in a strong and united Canada and have also motivated the proponents of separation.
Of course, our present economic situation must also be taken into account, with our huge debt leaving government with very little room to manoeuvre. I must point out that I was given a very clear mandate when I was elected in 1988. The Meech Lake Accord, by which Quebec could have reintegrated the Canadian family, was being negotiated at the time and I think that it was clear that the people of Joliette were contemplating the future of their riding, and their province of course, as part of a united Canada.
But they lost confidence first in 1982 and then in 1990. They lost confidence in our institutions for not making the Meech Lake Accord possible and having it ratified. They lost confidence also in the people, the elected people, who went back on their word. That is a fact. At any rate I have come to realize from my contacts with my constituents that they still have a faint ray of hope. They may lack confidence, but they still have some hope that, through its proposals, the federal Parliament will manage to develop a constitution that will come up to the expectations of the people in all the provinces concerned.
In order to keep the people of my riding informed, shortly before Christmas I distributed a survey questionnaire because people hear all kinds of things about the
Constitution, but cannot always make sense of it all. I tried to lay it out in the simplest terms, as I feel the people want it, these people who want me to go on looking out for them and fighting to maintain Quebec within the federation, in a united Canada.
I was pleasantly surprised, but it only confirmed my perception. The surveys that MPs usually take of their constituents are to find out what the people expect. My survey told me that even though we have been talking about the Constitution for a very long time, interest is now very high in my riding. Most of the people who answered this survey, I would say about three quarters, expressed great interest in the discussion and the proposals and I would like to thank them for their interest.
Of course, as I said, the survey also showed some loss of confidence. They hope that Parliament will be able to propose a Constitution whereby Quebec can work well within Canada. But they have lost some confidence in their elected officials, and that is understandable, for the reasons I mentioned earlier.
My fellow citizens also showed me their interest in being well informed on everything that is going on and in receiving plenty of documentation. They also said that they would like their MP to be more available so that he can keep them informed. We know very well that it is a problem for a federal member of Parliament, especially a backbencher in Ottawa, who must always be in the House, which sits very often.
As for the options, because the survey gave people a chance to take a position on the Constitution, many respondents told me that they saw their future within the federal system. Many told me that they considered themselves nationalists, but always within a federal system and a united Canada. Some, not a majority, told me that they were for an independent Quebec.
Mr. Speaker, you are indicating to me that my time is up. I find that the time went by very quickly, but in conclusion, I would just assure my fellow citizens that I will continue to respect the mandate that they gave me to bring Quebec back into the Constitution, in line with Quebec's wishes. I think that it would be hard for Canada to exist without Quebec, but I think that Quebec can bring much to the rest of Canada. This whole process must be done with us parliamentarians here in a climate
February 13, 1992

of respect, of course, and especially of tolerance and generosity, with a firm resolve to build a strong, prosperous country for future generations.

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, let me begin by thanking you for the opportunity to speak on this important issue in the House this evening.
I want to report on a series of four public meetings held in the riding of Guelph-Wellington on the constitutional proposals put forward by the right hon. Prime Minister on Tuesday, September 23, 1991.
The meetings were held in November and December. While the meeting were chaired by me, the critical part was the panel of three respected University of Guelph political scientists: Professor Bill Christian, Professor Patrick Kyba and Professor Fred Vaughan. I hope that they will agree with me tonight that my summary of the summary is adequate to the task.
The subject of the first of the four meetings was property rights and the Canada clause, followed by reform of Parliament and federal institutions. The third meeting dealt with economic union and distribution of power. The final meeting looked at the issues of a distinct society and native peoples.
The three professors opened each meeting by giving the historical perspective and some analysis of the issues, and that presentation usually took from 15 to 20 minutes. A simple show of hands was used to indicate the position of the meeting on the various issues. There was only one predetermined rule to the whole session. We were where we were and we were not going to ascribe blame to anyone or revisit the past.
The following is a very brief synopsis of the content of the four meetings with the general comments and the positions developed. I will have an opportunity to express my own views in this House in the days to come. The full report has been tabled with the constitutional committee.
On property rights there was at the meeting little enthusiasm for the inclusion of a constitutionally protected right to own property. The audience did not believe that the courts had used the existing charter of rights to threaten property. It was concerned that if the
The Constitution
right to own property were constitutionalized it would unnecessarily hamper future governments in pursuing socially desirable policies.
On the Canada clause there was no consensus on all of the proposed elements. The audience believed that the Constitution was best kept simple, and that meant not constitutionalizing certain current concerns however worthy they were.
On the reform of the House of Commons there was considerable frustration with the way the House functions today. Members of Parliament, it was felt, no longer represented the constituents wishes. The power had been taken out of the hands of the people. Party leaders wielded too much power over their backbenchers and so on. The group wanted reform but noted that these reforms could be carried out by the House of Commons itself and did not need a change in the Constitution.
There was agreement that the Senate should be reformed. There was support voiced for the house of the provinces model which would do away with the concept of the proposed council of the federation and lessen the need for more federal-provincial ministers conferences. There was also support for an elected Senate, especially a true triple-E Senate with equal representation from all provinces, and for special provision to ensure the representation of minorities. In general there was little discussion about the powers of the Senate as proposed in the document.
On the Supreme Court and amending formula there was no general discussion of these items, although the panellists commented upon them. Those who did mention the amending formula cautioned against a formula that would make amending the Constitution more difficult than it is today.
On the economic union and the distribution of powers there was cautious support for a national free trade scheme. The elimination of preferential procurement practices was thought desirable. The view was expressed that a co-ordinated national economic strategy was desirable in view of the new global order. There was concern that the proposals attempted to do too much across too wide a spectre.
The proposed amendment to the Bank of Canada Act to restrict the bank's mandate to price stability was perceived as unduly narrow.

February 13, 1992
The Constitution
The transfer of responsibility for job retraining to provincial governments was thought likely to reduce the amount of capital spent on such programs and therefore did not receive endorsement.
A suggestion to include in the proposals a provision requiring a balanced budget received a lukewarm reception. A proposal to establish a council of the federation and an independent monitoring agency was challenged on the grounds that a renewed Senate might more properly exercise these functions. Canada did not need another level of government.
There was general agreement that federal spending power should be restricted, but it was noted that if such restrictions had been in place in the 1960s Canada might not have in place its much valued national health scheme.
Concerning immigration, it was noted that under section 95 of the Constitution Act of 1867, the Parliament of Canada had all the authority necessary to accommodate any provincial aspirations in this area.
On aboriginal rights there was consensus that constitutional recognition of aboriginal rights is long overdue. Given the complexity of the problem, the fact that the government is only offering a process, is perhaps all that can reasonably be expected at this time.
With respect to the distinct society, the panellists observed that Quebec had always enjoyed a special status with respect to its civil law and rights of religious observation. However, there was concern that the distinct society concept, unless carefully worded, might entail allowing Quebec privileges of special access to the federal treasury that would be unacceptable in the kind of Canada that we are tiying to build.
With respect to the general question of Quebec separation, the most accurate summary would be simply to note that there was no consensus. Opinion toward Quebec ranged from actively hostile to a passionate and eloquent statement by a woman who said it would break her heart to see Quebec leave. There was widespread concern that separation would cause financial harm to both Quebec and the rest of Canada, and that in an age in which economic units are becoming larger it would certainly prove to be a retrograde step.
We had between 25 and 80 people at these meetings. I believe the results represent the kind of thing we would get in any cross-section of my riding. I express once again my thanks to all the people who turned out and my special thanks to my three friends, political studies professors at the University of Guelph, for agreeing to hold these conferences and to do that hard work. It was theirs and I am very grateful.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext:
I must say to the
minister that the hon. member for Nipissing gave up his spot for you to speak. Perhaps you could thank him also.
I am very grateful to the member for Nipissing.

Mr. Speaker, I thank the minister for that recognition.
I appreciate very much the opportunity to participate in this discussion, one which perhaps will be one of the most important that this House is going to engage in for quite some time.
We are here today to talk about the Constitution, the document which defines who we are and how we relate to one another as citizens of this great country. We are here to exchange views and to listen, to tell this House what our constituents think and what they told us as their representatives. We are here today to try to reach an understanding and an empathy for people's views and concerns, and to do so in a sincere and honest way without any partisanship or any other antics that this House has been recently characterized by.
It truly is an honour for me to present the views of my constituents on an issue of such magnitude. My riding of Nipissing in many ways is a microcosm of the larger Canadian society. Demographically it consists of many different cultural groups with a significant native population. The proportion of anglophones to francophones is approximately 70:30. In economic terms the entire sphere of private and public employers can be found, ranging from military bases and government services to resource based agricultural, manufacturing and service industries.
Geographically the riding is comprised of both rural and urban communities, with our biggest centre of North Bay consisting of roughly 52,000 people. In Nipissing one can find a sample of most facets of Canadian life.
February 13, 1992

As we all know, this past September the government unveiled its list of 28 proposals for constitutional renewal. It was decided that to solicit people's opinions on them a joint Senate and House committee would be formed to travel the country and listen to what people had to say. When the work of this committee began to flounder, people's cynicism was fuelled. It was ironic that a committee trying to put Canada together could not get itself together.
It became clear that the committee would not be visiting many communities it originally planned to. The prospect of not being included in those deliberations was disheartening for many, including myself. It was against this background that I decided to organize and host my own constitutional forums for the people in my riding.
On November 18, 19 and 20 I held three such forums in the communities of Sturgeon Falls, North Bay and Mattawa. These meetings were advertised in advance as non-partisan avenues for people to come and participate in and share their views on whatever issues or topics were of concern to them. There would be no huge committee or travelling entourage, no public relations people or any such advisers. It was just myself, listening and taking notes without rebutting any participant regardless of my own opinions.
These forums turned out to be an overwhelming success. They were well attended and constituents got a chance to speak frankly without feeling intimidated on issues important to them. I must say I was very surprised with the amount of media coverage we received. It struck me as odd that a member of Parliament, basically doing his job in gathering the views of the people he represents, would obtain publicity from coast to coast. I could not believe the good wishes and praise I received from all quarters, regardless of political affiliation, for doing what I thought was a fairly simple exercise in democracy.
I say this to the House not to seek praise but rather to illustrate how detached many people feel from the political process; to demonstrate that we as politicians, and perhaps even the political process we symbolize, are quite literally out of touch with the people we claim to represent; to show that cynicism and negative attitudes can be overcome if parliamentarians do their jobs and
The Constitution
ensure that people are an integral part of the process. Moreover, in spite of what many people say, people are not so apathetic and indifferent as we are led to believe.
On the contrary, if given the opportunity, people are responsive and willing to take part in the process. I am left with the impression that to some degree it has been the almost paternalistic-like attitude in which politicians know best that has turned many off.
Now that I have stated my observations, I want to share with all members of the House the views of my constituents on the constitutional proposals. As I promised them, they would be presented in a non-partisan way and they would be forwarded to the joint committee for consideration, which I have done.
I want to begin with the issue of distinct society for Quebec. In the Meech Lake round this was the contentious issue. Now that the government has defined what it means, it appears to be less controversial and more acceptable. In Nipissing, a slim majority favours distinct society on the condition that it would not subordinate anyone else's rights. Perhaps the following statement from a constituent best summarizes this view: "The Charter of Rights and Freedoms should be interpreted in a manner consistent with the preservation and promotion of a vibrant French speaking society in Quebec that protects the quality and influence of French as the expression of its culture and as the primary but not sole language of work, instruction, communication, commerce and business".
There were two issues for which people were nearly unanimous in their support: Senate reform and parliamentary reform. On the question of Senate reform, the vast majority favoured the concept of a triple-E Senate, noting that some kind of counterbalance to representation by population was sorely needed. People were sensitive to and aware of the feeling of regional inequality on the part of the west and the maritimes.
However, there were some stipulations put on this support. A few felt that some seats should be reserved for women and natives. Others stated that an elected Senate should have a full range of powers and not just the limited scope the government is proposing.
Additionally the issue of the six-month suspensive veto came up several times. Everyone who commented felt that a three-month veto would be more appropriate

February 13, 1992
The Constitution
and would not unduly interfere with the workings of the House.
On the matter of the Senate's role in appointments, people did not want to see a ratification process similar to that in the U.S. They stated that they did not want them to become a media show or vindictive character assassinations.
Parliamentary reform was another interesting area. Practically everyone was in favour of the concept. Constituents stated that they wanted to see more referenda on issues of national importance and more free votes in the House to reflect the wishes of the people and not of party discipline. This last point was reflective of most people's concerns. We must ensure that our elected officials represent us as was promised by them on election day. They must be accountable for their actions and represent our feelings and not what their leaders want, stated one constituent.
Another comment was: "There has to be a more equitable line drawn between party politics and what people want". Citizens are asking that their representatives speak for them and not for their party.
It is clear that we have to change the way this House operates if we are to have any credibility in the eyes of our constituents. The statement that best summarizes this sentiment came from one participant who said that politicians are asking people to be reasonable and yet politicians behave like children in the House.
The general feeling was that although people support a strong central role in economic affairs, the powers necessary to fulfil this objective must not be given away. We cannot claim to want labour mobility and yet have no national training and educational standards. We cannot hope to compete in a global economy with such an unorganized, inefficient and uneven approach.
On the question of native self-government there is not much that needs to be said. My riding of Nipissing has a thriving native community and people there have been living in relative harmony for quite some time. As a result most, if not all, participants agree that self-government must be recognized and entrenched.
I have presented the views of my constituents on the main issues but I want to share with the House a few other comments and observations of a myriad of others I received. I heard from young people who felt they had
been neglected by the entire process. I heard from disabled persons who told me that disabled people should be recognized for their abilities. I heard about women's issues that were also very important and mentioned on several occasions.
In concluding, I want to thank the people of Nipissing for reaffirming my faith in this nation and the electorate. The constitutional forums proved to me that people care deeply about this country and are more than willing to keep it together.
I believe that a solution to our constitutional difficulties is within our grasp. All that is needed is for all politicians and decision-makers to park their egos at the door, stop the grandstanding, put the country first, and work out a compromise. We should not fear compromise for our country was built on it, not confrontation.
I would like to leave the House with one thought and one last statement from one of my constituents who said: "In the summer when I paddle down Trout Lake and the Mattawa River on the trade routes of our ancestors I am awed by our history and our culture. When I walk on a winter night and hear the frozen silence and see the moon break through the unpolluted skies I revel in the vastness and texture of our country. When I talk with Canadians from all cultures I am renewed by the opportunity to share their experience and yet strengthen their commonalities as Canadians".
This is Canada, Mr. Speaker.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to start by quoting the renowned astronaut, Roberta Bondar, when she said as she spoke to the Prime Minister just a few weeks ago: "I would like to walk across every mile of our country Canada". She said this as she looked down on Canada from space.
Indeed, this is an important time for Canada. We are at a critical watershed in our history. We have always maintained that the constitutional choices we must face in the coming weeks and months are not about phrases, wording, or jargon but rather they are about people.
Canada is a diverse mix of many different and unique people. Our particular brilliance is in our accommodation of these differences, everyone is enriched.
February 13, 1992

In Scarborough we were privileged last fall to have the right hon. Joe Clark, Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs visit and participate in the very first community meeting in Canada to launch the government's proposals concerning our constitutional renewal. Over 600 people turned up for this exciting event at the Armenian Cultural Centre in Scarborough. There were numerous Canadian flags in evidence. There were Girl Guides and Boy Scouts who handed out flags to everyone. The Sea Cadets assisted. The Agincourt Collegiate Institute band played. There was applause, there were speeches and most of all there was this heartfelt dialogue about the future of our magnificent country of Canada. The concerned citizens shared their views with Mr. Clark and myself.
During the discussion in that first meeting there was a question from a young student from the Woburn Collegiate, Gary Pirtam. He did not ask a question about legal jargon, about an asymmetry arrangement or distinctiveness, but he asked one simple question: "Will you come back, Mr. Clark, and speak to the students, the young people of Scarborough?"
On January 15 a Unity Festival was held at Woburn Collegiate in Scarborough, sponsored by the Scarborough Board of Education. It was organized largely by students and staff and under the direct leadership of John Volpe, the principal of the school. Special thanks need to go to Earl Campbell, the director of education for Scarborough and the chairman of the board of education, Dianne Williams, for their work.
No less than 25 schools were represented, with over
1,000	students jamming into Woburn Collegiate for that event. The festival began with a choir that sang "Bridge Over Troubled Waters". It was a moving experience. Students from different schools and different backgrounds described what Canada was to each of them.
If our current dialogue is about our future as a country, then I say who better to listen to than the young men and women who are our collective future? Let me share with you some of the excerpts from the students' comments:
Bogart Quinn, who is a student at Alternate Scarborough Education, spoke:
The Constitution
One hundred and twenty years ago, a man named John A. Macdonald envisioned a society based on the precepts of tolerance, diversity and good will.
Inevitably, our future must lie in the hands of each and every Canadian, or fate will take its course. I only hope that the children of my generation will have a country to call a home, a country called Canada, that weathered its darkest storm and came out all the stronger.
Barbara Warner of Stephen Leacock Collegiate Institute said:
We must come to terms as to what Canada means to us, and what we see as Canada's future. For myself, I see a country whose economic troubles can only be overcome if unified. I see a country that treats all its citizens with respect. I see a country whose native peoples are self-governed, and whose traditions are preserved. I see a country that finds its strength in its diversity. I see Canada entering the twenty-first century united, and all Canadians looking forward together to a bright future.
Marcus Sharaput of Woburn Collegiate Institute added some prose:
As I grew up, I was told by the media, by my teachers and by society that my country does not have an identity. I will not and I cannot agree with this statement. Canada does have an identity, we simply do not brag about it. Canada is a country without rhetoric. Our past is not based on wars or great speeches, but on compromise and on consensus. Canada has heroes, we simply do not glorify them. Canada is a mature country, far more so than many nations who consider themselves our political elders and as such we must make a mature decision regarding the upcoming crisis. There are radicals on both sides of the unity question. But moderates on both sides realize that if Quebec separates the loss to Canada's economy, culture and identity would be irreplaceable.
There are people who wish to see the world in terms of black and white. Life is not that simple. We exist in a world of grey. No one side can be completely satisfied, we must reach a consensus, we must find a compromise.
On the question of Canadian unity and the question of black and white, it is our duty as citizens of this country to become involved. We must do whatever we can to help our leaders find a suitable shade of grey.
These are good words and advice for all of us from the students of Scarborough.
It was a thrilling day, ending with a unity march for Canada to the Scarborough city hall by hundreds of Scarborough students. They were led by the Lieutenant-Governor of Ontario Horse Guards. It was a demonstration of love for Canada, a reaching out to other citizens, other students across Canada. As a follow-up 25 members of the Principal's Association of Scarborough will be travelling to Quebec on March 5 and 6 to meet with their counterparts in Montreal.

February 13, 1992
The Constitution
I am proud of the enthusiasm and initiative the Scarborough students demonstrated. In fact, Scarborough hosts the largest Canada Day celebrations in metro Toronto. The planning is already under way for the festivities on July 1 toward a meaningful celebration to mark our 125th birthday.
Since being elected to the House of Commons, I have had the opportunity to serve on three parliamentary constitutional committees: the Committee of Equality Rights, Committee on the Companion Resolution to the Meech Lake Accord, as well as the Special Joint Committee on the Process of Amending the Constitution. Indeed, from these opportunities, I have learned a great deal about the country and about Canadians and I have heard of the love and respect that Canadians have for this country.
Let me turn to one of the specific proposals within the constitutional package. Someone said that our Constitution should be a mirror in which Canadians could see themselves reflected. Nowhere is this better exemplified than in the proposals of the Canada clause. It sets out the values and the ideals which unite us as Canadians, concepts like equality, fairness, openness, diversity, tolerance and, of course, freedom. The Canada clause makes us proud to be Canadians.
One section of the Canada clause is that part which sets out our commitment to sustainable development, our unique responsibility to preserve and protect the environment which we share for future generations.
We have heard much talk over the past few months about the economy on one hand and the Constitution on the other. Some have argued that the two are separate and unrelated issues. A strong economy and a healthy environment are two of the pillars upon which we have built this magnificent nation. These two concepts are not themselves separate: a healthy environment and a strong resource base are both fundamental elements of a strong economy. Further, economic growth and prosperity are required to support wise resource and environmental management.
We are aware of the linkages between the environment and the economy. It is the basis of our commitment in the Canada clause to sustainable development. The government has proposed that sustainable development be entrenched into the Constitution itself. This is not just symbolism. Canada's green plan makes it very clear
that we are firmly on the path of sustainable development. It is a long-term and comprehensive plan of action that addresses Canadians three basic environmental desires: clean air, clean soil and clean water.
The constitutional proposals include additional measures for co-operation and co-ordination. They will allow governments to co-operate in establishing national objectives and standards and harmonizing policies and programs.
The young people of Scarborough, our young people of Canada, understand the importance of environmental protection and a united and strong Canada as the best way of making this happen.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to be able to participate in this discussion tonight.
I would like to start by referring to a quotation by Sir Wilfrid Laurier that is contained in the booklet Shaping Canada's Future Together. The quotation reads as follows:
Canada has been the inspiration of my life. I have had before me-a policy of true Canadianism, of moderation, of conciliation. I have followed it consistently since 1896, and I now appeal with confidence to the whole Canadian people to uphold me in this policy of sound Canadianism which makes for the greatness of our country-
I talk about the Constitution and try to reflect the views of my constituents with some degree of apprehension. I do so for a reason. I speak tonight very frankly and very honestly. I think that is the purpose of these special sittings of the House.
Very frankly, my constituents are tired of listening to talk about the Constitution. They are tired of seeing politicians and others, some elected politicians and many non-elected politicians, rolling up their sleeves and intervening in the nuts and bolts of how our country works because they have a great fear that we are going to mess it up.
My constituents believe that much of what we have in Canada is worth preserving, that it is very good, that it has worked well, that it has made us a safe and prosperous land, one of the most blessed nations on earth.
At all costs, what we do in changing it must be a change for the better rather than a change for the worse. I think that part of their frustration about hearing us continuously talk about the Constitution is the fear that
February 13, 1992

somehow or other we are actually going to make matters much worse than they already are.
Part of it, as some of my colleagues have mentioned, is because they have reached the point where they mistrust political leaders at all levels. They start, of course, with the Prime Minister. All of us know that on both sides of the House of Commons, but it is not limited to him in particular. It extends to each member of Parliament as well as elected officials at the provincial and the municipal levels. There is a very great mistrust of the provincial premiers.
There are many other concerns that my constituents are more anxious to discuss with me than the Constitution. I suggest to you the first at the moment is the economy, and very close to that particularly in recent days with the news of the depletion of the ozone layer is the environment.
The message that I bring from my constituents is: For goodness sake, get this out of the way and get on to the issues that are really, truly important to us. That being said, I wish to override everything that follows with those comments. Indeed, what my constituents think are most important are not constitutional matters.
I have endeavoured to obtain their opinions on constitutional issues first of all by circulating a survey door-to-door within my constituency .This was done before the government's 28 proposals were made public. I gained, in response to that, about 1,400 individual answers from constituents to this series of questions.
In addition, I have held public discussions. We held a televised phone-in program on the Constitution to give people the opportunity to discuss it. On top of that, there were many calls, letters, and conversations with people throughout the constituency.
Ottawa South, Mr. Speaker, as you might not be surprised to hear is a constituency very in tune with federal politics. People in my constituency and in the national capital region have more at stake in this discussion than those in any other part of Canada. They follow it closely, they are well informed and they are very anxious to participate.
I have learned a number of things from my consultations. I would like to just summarize some of the messages. First of all, I think that there is a clear
The Constitution
identification with a Canada that is bilingual and multicultural. That message was revealed in my question about what the nature of Canada statement in the Constitution should include.
Fifty-four per cent said yes to an attachment to two official languages and 37 per cent said no. Sixty-six per cent believed that the diversity of our cultural heritage should be noted. I think this is very important: 77 per cent wanted a recognition of the role of our aboriginal people. I think that that is a particularly strong sentiment in Ottawa South.
There is also a great desire to see some changes to the institutions of our government, particularly reform of the Senate. A very large percentage wish to see the Senate elected and on reflection rather than from the survey but by subsequent discussions, a very strong reform of the House of Commons is desired as well.
The people of Ottawa South exhibit a very great attachment to the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. This has come out consistently in discussions that we have had. For that reason, people are very concerned about what goes into the charter and how it is given effect in our system of law.
It would be fair to say that many object to the use of the notwithstanding clause by any level of government. They would like to see it removed from the Constitution.
While we do not like to pre-judge the results of a referendum in Quebec, I would be failing to reflect the views of my constituents clearly if I did not say to those who wish to advocate an independent Quebec, particularly a sovereignist Quebec, that the people in my constituency do not consider sovereignty association to be an option available to the sovereignist movement in Quebec.
If they vote in that province to go apart from Canada, people will want to look very closely at the kind of negotiations that would occur. The option of saying they can have it both ways, that they can have a strong economic union with Canada and independence on the other hand, is simply not available in the views of the majority of my constituents. I must say to the members of the Bloc Quebecois that I share those views.
There is concern about the economic union. We are united on the need for strong social programs. Whether

February 13, 1992
The Constitution
it is put in the context of a social charter or whether it is simply said, Canadians are united in their desire to share nationally the kind of programs we have become so attached to, particularly our health care system and our educational system.
There is also a recognition that in order to successfully maintain that social network, we are going to have to have a strong economic union. That includes the reduction and eventual elimination of trade barriers between and among our provinces.
About 500 of those trade barriers do a few things. First of all, they limit our prosperity because they limit our ability to trade freely with one another.
Second, they make us much more vulnerable than we would otherwise be to the pressures of internationalization that are occurring despite our best efforts.
Instead of being 10 little markets as we economically are at the moment, we should be one little market which is all that Canada can be. At least it would be much bigger than any of our provinces are on their own so that we can in preserving our national identity resist as much as possible those global pressures.
Finally, I would like to note the value that our people see in Canada. We offer to the world something that truly is unique. We offer a country which has a view of the world that says that bigger and stronger is not always better. We offer a view that says we need to look after our poor, our weak, our sick while rewarding talent, skill and enterprise. We need to continue to put forward on the world stage a view that says it is no shame to seek compromise where others see only conflict. This is what has made Canada great.
I conclude by one last comment on my own fears. Two days ago, two young Canadians, Lloyd Eisler and Isabelle Brasseur, distinguished Canada by winning the bronze medal in the Olympic Games.
As I watched our national newscast that night, what did I see? Not a celebration that these young Canadians were the third best in the world. I saw clips of Isabelle falling as she did perhaps once or twice in a long program.
Why is it that instead of focusing on the few things that maybe do not go perfectly in our country, why do we not focus on the things that make us so great.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I stand here tonight as a Canadian, someone of Scottish descent whose family landed on the shores of Canada some 160 years ago in Broad Cove in Cape Breton. This makes me a fifth generation Canadian of Scottish heritage. I had a great uncle who represented the riding of Inverness County in Cape Breton in the early 1920s. I am very pleased to now represent a riding in northern Ontario, the riding of Timiskaming.
Over the last number of weeks and months I have had the opportunity to travel in my riding. I have had constituents come into my office. I have had letters and phone calls, talking not only about the Constitution. Quite frankly, in my riding the number one concern within the hearts and livelihoods of my constituents is the economy. We are going through some very difficult times. We know that if we as a country are divided, we are never going to be able to ensure stability or a future for those of us who are living in parts of the regions today and our families of tomorrow.
When talking with my constituents, one concern came out very loud and very clear from veterans who have served in three wars and individuals who have immigrated from other parts of the world to Timiskaming, whether it was in the 1940s, 1950s, 1960s, 1970s, or into the 1980s, or our francophone community which makes up 27 per cent of my riding. Every one of them made it very clear to me that they are not a hyphenated Canadian, they are Canadian.
Those who fought in those wars fought for the security and the future of Canada from coast to coast and to ensure that our young people would have the opportunity for the freedom that everyone in this room here tonight has and what all Canadians have been able to enjoy.
I would just like to take one moment and quote a few lines out of just one of the many letters I have received from my constituents. "We Canadians should show more of what we believe in. We do not show that we are proud of our country and I am always surprised at the July 1 celebrations how few Canadian flags are flying in our town. Hardly any. We have to be more outgoing to tell
February 13, 1992

others that we love our country and to tell our friends in Quebec that they are part of a lovely country and we love them very much. What is wrong with our country right now is that we listen only to minorities. We are a melting pot, but there should be standards which are Canadian. I came to Canada 25 years ago and 20 years later I became a Canadian citizen. When I decided to become a Canadian I also made a decision to be part of the community and fit in. I never thought of imposing some things as a minority to the rest of the country. The Lord's Prayer is no longer said in public schools because it hurts a minority. The Mounties can wear turbans and youths are allowed to wear daggers because of religious beliefs. We give in to all minority rights because of the Charter of Rights. This Charter of Rights clause can be misused and it is misused. It is impossible to please everyone".
That is just one of many comments I have received from my constituents.
Canadians have always been noted as being builders of a country. We go back to Sir John A. Macdonald and the rail system that tied this country together from coast to coast, John Diefenbaker and the Roads to Resources, visions of tying this country together. Today our present Prime Minister has a vision of what the future should be. Whether we are talking about the Constitution, the future of this country or looking at the free trade agreement, some will think today that we may be wrong, but history will certainly indicate that it was the right decision.
Consider how we have been able to build together in the past 30 years. Within the lifetime of most of us in this room tonight, since 1961, we have had the second highest rate of growth among the G-7 nations, the second highest rate of investment growth, the highest rate of job creation in the OECD countries. We never hear about that. We never hear about the positive response that is taking place in this country.
I think as Canadians that one of the biggest problems we face is that we have a tendency to live within our own little area and be ones to complain about, discouraged about but not looking at, the over-all approach of what this country is all about. The fact is that one of the greatest problems we face in this country is we really do not understand and know more about each other, about those of us in northern Ontario who may know more
The Constitution
about those in B.C. or in the province of Quebec or in Newfoundland.
I think that is one of the reasons why this country is having difficulties, a combination within our educational system and a combination that maybe sometimes we should be looking at spending more time in our own country, talking with each other, understanding the differences between urban and rural Canada, between the north and the south and the east and the west.
Last year, in fact on this day, the Prime Minister was in Quebec City. He warned Canadians about the damaging effects the focus of disunity will have if we allow them to dominate the national unity debate. The Prime Minister told us at that point: "Watch out for the dream merchants, those who say it is no problem to destroy a great country and to rebuild it later, those who claim that they alone can change the course of history". Truer words have not been spoken.
No one can question the commitment of this government, the commitment of ensuring that this country remains together, grows together and becomes stronger with a more collective effort. In Toronto last February the Prime Minister made a clear heartfelt statement that all Canadians should be proud.
Let me make it clear, Canada is not up for grabs. Either we have a country or we do not. We cannot have it both ways. My country is Canada and I intend to strengthen it and I intend to keep it.
There are two last comments I would like to make. John Diefenbaker said in 1967: "Canada needs a renewed sense of national purpose. We need to maintain and to strengthen the basic foundations of the Constitution. We need to instil in every Canadian the spirit of Sir George Cartier. Before all, let's be Canadians".
I was born a Canadian and I plan to die a Canadian.

Mr. Speaker, I have in my hands some 38 photocopies of posters, letters, some of the letters hand written, some printed, all of them with a common theme. They are from a group of grade 5 elementary students at Mountain View Elementary in Nanaimo. They are addressed to any group of grade 5 students in the province of Quebec which believes in the future of Canada, which wants to, as they put it, save Canada.

February 13, 1992
The Constitution
I could not help but think as I was reading these letters and waiting for my opportunity to speak that had Canada spent a great deal more money on student exchanges between English speaking communities anywhere in Canada and French speaking communities anywhere in Canada and a lot less money on commissions that travelled this country from one end to the other, perhaps we would not have the problem that we have today. I wish that that program were pushed and that we quit examining ourselves as much as we have done.
I sent the letters on. These are photocopies. I never heard whether they were answered. As I say, they were all written in English because those students on Vancouver Island could not write in our other language, the other official language of Canada.
Those letters were sent to me in May of last year. In June the Nanaimo NDP organization organized a public meeting and invited people to come to talk about the Constitution. It started at ten o'clock on a Saturday morning, adjourned for lunch but the discussion at lunch was all about the morning's agenda, carried on in the afternoon until 5 p.m. There were some 60 people present. There was an MP there. It was not myself. I was there to greet them in the morning, but I had other duties. One of the members of the joint committee, the hon. member for Port Moody-Coquitlam, was there. He told me afterward what a great meeting it was and how positive the feeling was in my community, at least as represented by the people who attended that meeting on a Saturday. I was encouraged by that.
In October, I believe it was, one of the local newspapers, the Nanaimo Bulletin, printed a ballot on the front page and the paper went to almost everybody in the community. The person who did the ballot, Merv Unger who worked for the paper then, told me how surprised and pleased he was with the volume of the response. I was not so pleased with the content. A lot of negative feelings were expressed.
By that time there were negative feelings being expressed. Whether it was because these people were associated with the Reform Party or not I do not know. They were expressing their concerns that one province in Canada was trying to lead us to destruction and their
attitude was: "Why not let them go?". That feeling was prevalent but was not the majority. The majority of the people in that ballot, at least as quickly as I could determine from going through the ballots, wanted Canada to be saved, wanted us to stay together as one country.
In November my office sent out a householder. It was not a large effort. It took five sheets of 8.5 x 11 paper, including the cover. It talked briefly about the issues before us in considering the Constitution. In each case it raised a couple of questions about each one of these issues. It ended up inviting the people receiving it to write in and ask for a much more extensive paper on the subject of the Constitution and a ballot that they could fill in and mail back to me. Some 45,000 of these went out to the riding. It is a large riding; it took that many to cover all of the households. Some 1,205 wrote in asking for a copy of the background paper that was offered, a 38-page document. They also wanted the 29-page ballot that was offered along with it.
I was encouraged by the response. A high proportion of the people who got the householder did ask for the background paper because they were interested in the subject. They did ask for the ballot because they wanted to let me know how they felt about the issues. Some of them in their letters, expressed concerns wondering whether I would pay any attention to the answers.
It is not too hard because I agree with the majority vote from my constituency as represented by the people who have spoken to me, by the people who have written to me, and by the people who have submitted the ballots. I wish more ballots had come in, but I am pleased with the response as indicated by the ones who did submit the ballots so far, and they are still coming in.
I do not intend to go into any great detail on the content of this. It is one of the things that I will be submitting to the committee this evening. I could read from the conclusion of a six-page document that has been prepared reporting on the ballots that have been received. This will go along with the ballots to the committee. Part of the conclusion states: "The results indicate thoughtfulness and intelligence on the part of the constituents of Nanaimo-Cowichan, along with a very sincere desire to be informed on the issues and to offer a contribution. Perhaps the clearest observation
February 13, 1992

from this survey is that we need not fear the knowledge and opinions of Canadian people".
I heartily endorse that report as well.
In July 1990 Canada Day was on a Sunday. I received a letter. The same letter went to the mayor of Nanaimo and to the MLA. All three of us were asked to come to church, the Evangelical Church, on Sunday and to tell the congregation how we felt about Canada. It is the only organization that I know of that has done something like that, the only church organization. I am sure they all feel that way, but nevertheless that church invited the three of us.
On Canada Day in 1991 the same three people were invited back once again to tell the same stoiy. I was asked to speak first and I told the congregation how I felt about Canada. The member of the legislative assembly told the meeting how he felt and the mayor did as well. Mayor Frank Ney said something in his concluding remarks that I wish I had said. He said that looking at the group reminded him of elementary school students, for there was a preponderance of young people in that church congregation. He said that we have to save Canada, we have to keep Canada together for the sake of the young people in this congregation, in this community, and in this country. I wish I had said something like that.
I am speaking for the majority of my constituents, even the students, when I say that I want Canada to survive. I am prepared to sit down and talk with anyone who comes to me and says that yes, Canada is our home. We are sharing it with some 28 million inhabitants, some of whom are descendants of people who have been here for thousands of years, perhaps. Others have come from all parts of the world more recently. We are sharing it together, the best place in the world, the best home in the world for its 28 million inhabitants.
Those people say that we can make it better, that we should sit down and work together and discuss how we might make it a better place for all of us. With that person I will sit down and talk. I will listen. Together I hope we can work something out for the benefit of all of us.
If someone came to me and said that this home of ours might be good but it could be better if we split it asunder, divided it, and some of us might be better off than we are
The Constitution
right now, I would not be prepared to discuss anything with that person.
There are others who will say that we have to break it apart to make it a better place, that after we have broken it apart perhaps everybody may be better off. I am not prepared to sit down and discuss anything with that person.
Canada is the best place in the world.
A letter was read much earlier this evening that probably went to everyone expressing better than most of us can just how we feel about Canada. It is my home. I was bom here. No one has the right to destroy my home. They have the right to share it. They have the right with me to try to make it better, but they have no right to gamble on destroying it to make it better or to make it better for a few.
That is the voice from my community. We are not prepared to be threatened. We are not prepared to offer ourselves up to the possibility of blackmail, but we are prepared to sit down and talk with anyone who wants to work with us to make it a better place in which we can all live.
That is the kind of Canada I want.

Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to participate in the debate this evening because it is important that sovereignists from Quebec explain to the rest of Canada what is really going on in our province.
The members of Parliament from Quebec, most of which are Conservatives, have nothing to gain by explaining to Canadians what is going on in Quebec because it would harm their respective parties in the rest of Canada. Therefore, this evening I wish to inform Canada of the opinions of our constituents.
Some members have talked about surveys or have expressed their opinions following discussions in their ridings. I will talk about the best possible survey, which is an election.
I was elected under the Bloc Quebecois banner, whose program is open, frankly and clearly geared toward sovereignty. The results left no doubt in anyone's mind. The Bloc Quebecois got 68 per cent of the votes; the Liberal party 19 per cent; the NDP 8 per cent; and the Conservatives, who form the government, 3.9 per cent. In my opinion, this is very telling. Why did we get those

February 13, 1992
The Constitution
results? I believe it is essentially because Quebec is not a distinct society but a distinct nation which, for decades now, has been defining, organizing and developing itself. The failure of Meech Lake was a turning point in this long process.
Following the failure of the Meech Lake Accord, the Government of Quebec set up the Belanger-Campeau commission which, with utmost rigour, towed the province of Quebec and arrived at some conclusions: we must put an end to the political uncertainty because it affects the development of Quebec. The commission proposed the holding of a referendum on sovereignty in 1992, and that recommendation was included in Bill 150 by the Government of Quebec. In this bill, the Government of Quebec specifies that sovereignty simply means that Quebec will be the only jurisdiction to raise taxes, legislate on its territory and sign international treaties.
This project of a sovereign Quebec is both modern and democratic, and it is aimed at creating a society without racism, sexism and violence. A sovereign Quebec will recognize four groups: the francophone majority, of course, but also the anglophone minority, the aboriginal peoples and the ethnic and cultural minorities. The collective rights of each of these groups will be enshrined in the constitution of a sovereign Quebec.
This is a modern project which does not go against history, in spite of what some may say. If you look at the situation in the world right now, you will notice that there are two main trends: one is the birth of countries- that was the case in eastern Europe where nations finally created their countries-and the other is the creation of economic groups, such as the common market in Europe and the free trade agreement between the United States and Canada. Even if that agreement was badly drafted, the fact remains that it follows the current trend. There will be more and more of these economic concentrations.
Mr. Francois Mitterrand, who surely knows about these issues, was quite right when he said that to fully participate in an organization, you must first be yourself.

Mr. Speaker, I rise on a point of relevance. The hon. member, if I follow his remarks, seems to be discussing the history of the evolution of the common market in Europe. I understood the purpose of the debate was to report to the House on the views of each of our constituencies relative to the constitutional debate. Perhaps the member could take that into account.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: Although he is a fairly new member, I know that he is going to get to the point. I appreciate the fact that the hon. member has drawn that to his attention.

There is no problem, Mr. Speaker. After all the detours I heard tonight, I suppose I am getting right to the point.
Given these two major trends, we must realize that Canada cannot develop as a country now, nor can Quebec, because each prevents the other from doing so. Canadians want a strong central government, national standards, a country in their image. And Quebecers too want a country in their image.
To take the example that Brian Mulroney and the Liberal leader Jean Chretien often use when they talk to us about the European Economic Community, they should first of all realize that the strength of the common market is that it is made up of sovereign countries which all freely agree to cooperate with one another in the economic sphere. That is realistic.
We must be careful and beware of people who get away from realism. I am thinking of those who talk about violence, about partitioning the territory of Quebec; among them are some university professors. It is strange to see these people hail the birth of countries in eastern Europe and talk about violence here. Those countries were oppressed, their situation was very different from Quebec's, I admit, but is it logical to say that the democratic will of Quebecers could not be recognized unless there were violence beforehand? That seems dishonest and undemocratic to me.
We must also beware of the inconsistency of some arguments. Many people, including Ovide Mercredi, tell us that Quebec is not a people, not a nation. In English, "distinct" means "superior". And yet, I heard all of
February 13, 1992

Canada applaud the agreement made between Premier Rae of Ontario and the First Nations. This agreement says at the beginning:

Whereas the First Nations represented by the Chiefs in Assembly, hereafter, the First Nations exist in Ontario as a distinct nation.

You see, aboriginal people can be nations and no one makes a fuss. They can be distinct nations, but for some reason, Quebec is different. I must say the logic escapes me.
Some more false premises. They say Quebec gets more from the federal government than it pays out. The Belanger-Campeau commission proved that over a long period of time, we receive as much as we give, except that we receive it in the form of unemployment insurance. Ontario gets it in the form of research and development and industrial grants. This produces countries and economies that are totally different.
Let's assume, for the sake of argument, that Quebec gives more. Once Quebec is independent, I don't think its economy would be in any great danger, if we give more than we receive. And assuming that Quebec receives more than it gives, is Quebec so popular that Canadians would be prepared to pay us to stay in Canada? I doubt it Mr. Speaker. I doubt it very much.
Finally, I want to respond to a statement by a member of this House who said there would no more negotiations once Quebec was sovereign. Let's be realistic. I wish members who say that would go to Oshawa and explain to workers in the automobile industry that they will have to go on unemployment insurance out of patriotism, because Canada cannot sell any more cars to those poor Quebecers who will have to make them themselves or buy them in the United States. That doesn't make sense. I would like to see that same member tell western farmers they will have to eat all their beef or watch the carcasses rot, instead of selling them to Quebec. This does not make sense.
I submit there are mutual interests. There are 100,000 jobs in Ontario that depend on the Quebec market. In
The Constitution
Ontario, when workers at de Havilland saw Bombardier would save their jobs, they didn't care whether the money came from Quebec, Taiwan, Japan or Ontario.
I hope we will end this uncertainty. I hope we will stop preventing each other from having the kind of country we want. Build the kind of country you want. Build a great country. We will build the Quebec that Quebecers want, and then we will have the kind of normal relationship that exists between two sovereign, modem and democratic countries that will probably get along better than we do today.

Mr. Speaker, to preface my remarks, I just listened carefully to the remarks of the hon. member preceding me.
I cannot doubt, nor should Canadians doubt, the sincerity of his remarks and his pride in the history of French Canada, its heritage and its feeling of being a nation.
This time slot here has been allocated to permit us time, as MPs, to report to Parliament on the views of our constituents on the subject of constitutional reform.
The means in Scarborough-Rouge River have been the fairly routine; letters, phone calls and discussions held in various parts of the riding and one survey some months ago. That survey was not necessarily the most scientific of surveys but it was indeed a survey. Maybe it is not perfectly representative of everyone's view in the riding-no survey can be-but it was very real. It was very true, and the results will accurately reflect the views of the individuals who reported. The first thing I want to do is report very briefly on the results of that survey.
Relative to the issue of the constitutional statement on the nature of Canada, sometimes called the Canada clause, on attachment to the two official languages, there was substantial majority in favour of that.
On diversity of Canadian heritage, on the role of aboriginals, there were substantial majorities in favour of those two.
On the issue of the distinct character of Quebec's society, there was division.

February 13, 1992
The Constitution
On the elimination of provincial barriers to trade and commerce and the movement of capital, there was a substantial majority in favour.
In relation to the election of a Senate, there was a substantial majority in favour. On the actual role, function and powers of a Senate, there was less agreement; in fact, there was division, but there was clearly a tendency among the electors of Scarborough-Rouge River to have a Senate with more oversight powers, oversight over government, review powers and to ensure that the Senate had the effective power to deal with those types of initiatives.
On the role of the provinces or territories, in a decision as to whether or not there would be a new province in a particular territory, there was substantial support for the decision to be made jointly by the federal government and the territory, and there was little support for the role of other provinces in that decision.
On the role of the provinces and territories in the selection or appointment of Supreme Court judges, there was a substantial majority supporting a role for the provinces in that selection or appointment.
Last, on provincial or regional constitutional vetoes on constitutional matters outside of the existing section 41 veto, there was division. There was clear division and uncertainty as to which entity, which region, which provinces should have a veto.
That is a quick summary of the survey.
Scarborough-Rouge River is an urban southern Ontario riding. It contains a balance, and I use the word advisedly, a true balance between new Canadians and not-so-new Canadians. It is clear, with virtually no exceptions, that every single one of us is proud to be a Canadian. We are proud of our history, we are excited by our country's future prospects, even in the middle of this very cruel and damaging recession.
My constituents want a strong Canada with a national government that works. They definitely believe that they are over-governed. As citizens of the city of Scarborough, they feel they are over-governed. We have a city government, we have a metropolitan Toronto government, we have a provincial government and we have our federal government. We know that very well because every nickel that it takes to run and operate each of
those governments is going to come out of our pockets as taxpayers.
There is frustration out there that the reform and the cost efficiencies which they would like to see happen may be eluding them as an electorate, and eluding us as elected. They are frustrated by that and they clearly wish to see more.
The constituents of Scarborough-Rouge River are demanding that all levels of government take up the challenge to limit the growth of government, reduce the cost of government and purge government of duplication and redundancy.
On the constitutional reform agenda, as proposed by the government, there is one school of thought that says: "Stop the nonsense, stop the exercise. We do not want to deal with the Constitution now. The big issue, the only issue is the economy". I suppose if you are out of a job that would be a very natural predisposition.
There is the other school of thought that says: "Legislators please, get right to the task of constitutional reform. Don't delay it. Deal with it quickly and then let us get on to all of the other important issues which we must deal with, including the economy, crime and violence, health care costs, education and training our youth and all of the very many other issues".
To close this perspective on the views of the constituents of Scarborough-Rouge River, to refer to the upcoming national government negotiations with the provincial governments on constitutional reform, including the Quebec government, the residents of Scarborough-Rouge River want a country that is whole. They want a country that has a modem viable constitution. They do not want a constitution at any cost.
We want one that all Canadians can join in confidence and continue to build our futures, a country that is home for our French speaking Canadians and the great French Canadian heritage that is there and a home for all others, each of us with a heritage of which we are proud.
The constituents of Scarborough-Rouge River are ready for the constitutional challenges of the next few months. They challenge all of their elected representatives on the related matters that I have spoken to earlier in my remarks.

Mr. Speaker, I too am absolutely delighted to be able to rise in this House tonight and speak on the Constitution, and with all
February 13, 1992

others in the House of Commons, to speak to the issues that the residents of my constituency, which is Nepean, have presented to me on issues of constitutional matters.
In April of last year, I sent a questionnaire to all of my constituents, asking them for their thoughts, ideas, suggestions and concerns regarding the constitutional debate and the future of Canada. The overwhelming response that I received was compiled into a report entitled "Canada: A Phoenix Rising" and a copy was sent to the Spicer commission and to all members of Parliament and senators.
Since then the residents of Nepean have continued to demonstrate a keen interest and a strong desire to play a role in the constitutional debate. Many have called my office to request copies of the government proposals and summaries of the recent constitutional conferences. They have expressed frustration at the inability of the government to give straight answers about the proposals and they have expressed anger at the seemingly endless string of committees, whether it is the Spicer, Beaudoin-Edwards, Dobbie-Castonguay and now the Beaudoin-Dobbie. They are most anxious to get to the real issues that are facing the country, such as the economy, jobs and unemployment.
Last month I again compiled the views of some constituents and submitted these views as a brief to the special joint committee. Half a year after they had first had an opportunity to air their views, the most marked change that I noticed was in the frustration that they felt. Did all of these committees and forums mean anything? Were their views really being listened to? Or was the special joint committee just another exercise in smoke and mirrors, another attempt by the government to fool the people of Canada into thinking that their opinions really mattered?
Today I once again put forward the opinions of the constituents in the hope that this government will listen to their hopes for this country and will heed their concerns when the final report of the special joint committee for a renewed Canada is submitted.
Perhaps the most frequent comment about the package of proposals as a whole was the vagueness and ambiguity of the wording. The Constitution as a document that will shape Canada into the 21st century must be clear and it must be precise.
The Constitution
A second point which many agreed on was the need for all Canadians to have the last word on whether the final document was acceptable, the need for a referendum where people could give or withhold their consent specifically to the constitutional document.
The economy was foremost in many minds, especially now in these difficult times.
A clear distinction between federal and provincial jurisdiction is needed to ensure that adequate responsibility is taken for matters such as education and health care.
Also, Canadians in all parts of the country should have equal opportunity for prosperity and advancement.
Many Nepean residents were worried that by designating Quebec as a distinct group other equally distinct groups will be neglected. Residents of Nepean for the most part are proud to live in a country that is both multicultural and bilingual.
However, they did feel that a review of how we are implementing both of those concepts should be undertaken and that the Government of Canada must ensure the rights of all Canadians within a multicultural and bilingual framework, the majority as well as the minority.
Although only a very small number of my constituents are aboriginal, many are concerned that the First Nations of this country, people who have contributed so much to making Canada what it is, have been neglected.
In September, my provincial colleagues and I held a forum entitled "Shaping Our Future-Canada's Aboriginals Speak Out".
Interesting questions about a variety of issues were raised including self-government and education. The many people who attended came away with a clear understanding of who the First Nations of Canada are and what it is that they want to gain from the constitutional debate.
The inclusion of a Canada clause was generally approved of and affirmation of the Canadian identity is crucial to growth and prosperity. Identification with Canada as one strong united country should be a priority for all Canadians. However, as with all parts of a package, the wording must be very carefully developed

February 13, 1992
The Constitution
to ensure that the inherent nature of our country is protected.
Finally, the stronger leadership and more responsive and responsible government topped many agendas. Nepean residents want a House of Commons that is less partisan and a Senate that is elected and effective.
I would like to share with you some specific recommendations that were made by several residents of the city of Nepean.
One is a recommendation for Senate reform that was suggested by Mr. Tony Colven of Nepean. He recommends a Senate that would be elected from the entire national electorate with candidates standing for constituencies that represent concerns rather than places.
Any legitimate group able to assemble a specific minimum membership could put forward a slate of senatorial candidates arranged in order of popularity. All Canadians could then vote according to major concerns.
Although such a process would be unlikely to produce a dominant group, it would be capable of providing a broad base of opinion that would increase the effectiveness and the responsibility of the Senate.
Mr. Malcolm Smith says: "The Charter of Rights and Freedoms has not protected the English minority in Quebec from the repressive language laws, nor has the Parliament of Canada".
Mr. Jacques Roy says: "Canada must be a global economic power to secure and maintain a good standard of living. All Canadians must identify with Canada first. As long as we will endeavour to cultivate two or more different cultures without the vision of a united and strong Canada, and as long as we continue to ensure that they are different and separate, we will not develop a Canadian identity".
Mr. Jim Rennie says: "Let's try to analyse the reasons why some of the residents of Quebec support separation and let us come up with a strategy to undo all of the adverse rhetoric and get this country pulling together".
Mr. Paul Bender says: "We can and should learn from the native peoples of Canada who identify more with the environment than with possessions and monetary wealth".
I want to thank my constituents who responded. I had in the area of 700 responses. I do not wish to indicate that they are representative of all of the people of Nepean because they certainly are not.
I want to thank them for taking the time and making so many valuable contributions to this debate which is so crucial to Canada's future through "Canada-A Phoenix Rising" and through my more recent report to the special joint committee on a renewed Canada. I have tried to represent these views as accurately as possible here in the House of Commons.
Now I ask the government: Please listen to the voices of the people of Canada. Please consider carefully all viewpoints and perspectives including those of my constituents of Nepean. Please when the final report is tabled make sure that it will help a united Canada to grow and to prosper into the future.

Mr. Speaker, I am grateful for the opportunity afforded members in the House to speak on the Constitution and for these special sittings which afford us that opportunity.
Each of us has received letters from our constituents and indeed from people from across the country on their thoughts on the Constitution. I want to read just a couple of paragraphs from one letter that I received.
"For me, Canada is more than a country and more than a nation. Canada, for me, is the idea of the ideal society of the future and an example for the rest of the world to follow. Canada, for me, is tolerance, open channels of communication and peaceful means of solving differences of opinion and disagreements. Canada, for me, is a great open society in which everyone is equal and at the same time can be unique and distinct while an integral part of it. For me, Canada is a ray of hope, shining in the sky of humanity and the greatest country on earth."
I felt that I should include that in my speech tonight because those are words that I perhaps wish I had penned. I want to quote from Sir John A. Macdonald who said: "Let us be English or let us be French, but above all, let us be Canadians."
