Being Canadian is infinitely more important than being Liberal, Conservative or NDP, whether we are from the right or from the left, labour or business, or
February 13, 1992

whether we are from the east or the west or from the north.
An excellent speech came across my desk from Mr. Allan Taylor, chairman and chief executive officer of the Royal Bank of Canada. I want to read a part of his speech into the record tonight.
"What Canadians should be asking themselves first and very explicitly is whether disunity is the answer to the challenges we face.
Do we really need to blow Canada apart to meet Quebec's historic concerns? Quebec is a unique cultural island of six million French-speaking people in an ocean of 270 million people working and living in English. Quebec is a distinct society.
Do we really need to destroy Canada to recognize and protect that reality? I say no. Do we really need to blow Canada apart to understand and address the deep alienation in the west where many people believe that our national institutions are dominated by a deaf and unfeeling eastern majority? Do we really need to destroy Canada to recognize and correct that concern? I say no. Do we really need to blow Canada apart to meet the deep felt concerns of people in Atlantic Canada?
Do we have to destroy Canada to solve the very real structural economic problems? I say no.
Do we really need to blow Canada apart to give the First Nations the power to participate directly in determining their own destiny within Canada? Rights they have been denied for too long? Again I say no.
Do we really need to blow Canada apart to address the vital need for greater harmonization of federal and provincial policies and cutting the wasteful duplication of cost?
Do we really need to blow Canada apart to make us understand Canada is already part of a much larger international economic union and so must have a strong domestic economic union to survive? Again I say no.
That separation would be relatively easy and without cost is not just a dangerous delusion. It is a real world impossibility."
I want to take a look at our early history, the Quebec Act. This was an act which was legislated in 1774. It was an act for making more effective provision for the government of the province of Quebec in North
The Constitution
America. It was a British statute which received Royal Assent on June 22, 1774 and became effective May 1, 1775.
Religious freedom was guaranteed for the colony's Roman Catholic majority and a simplified test oath which omitted references to religion enabled them to enter public office conscientiously.
The act established French civil law and British criminal law, and provided for continued use of the seigniorial system. It effectively guaranteed the survival of the ancien regime society in North America.
Territorial expansion was a recognition of Montreal's role in the continental economy and the act returned to the Quebec economy its traditional links with the fisheries and interior fur trade.
Then in the spring of 1791, over 200 years ago, the House of Commons at Westminster passed an act. After being consented to by the House of Lords that act received the assent of King George III on June 10. From that time on, it would be known as the Constitution Act, 1791.
What the act did was it created two provinces, Lower and Upper Canada. It set their boundaries and laid down their powers, privileges and prerogatives. It also authorized the establishment of electoral ridings and the holding of elections to Parliament.
Upper Canada, what we call today Ontario, which is my province, lived its first democratic experiences in 1791. The creation of that province's parliamentary institutions followed the same chronology as Quebec's. Geography then has made us neighbours. Reality on day to day business make us partners.
This may come as a surprise to many of my constituents and people throughout the country, but there have been exchanges between the members of Ontario's Legislative Assembly and those of the Quebec National Assembly.
During the summer of 1991, members of the National Assembly and members from Queen's Park recalled the days of the travelling Parliament and of the first sittings in 1792. They visited the sights of the first sessions in Quebec City, in Montreal, in Kingston, Niagara-on-the-Lake and Toronto.

The Constitution
This, I think, is an excellent example of getting to know our country. The year 1867 brought us the British North America Act and Confederation. But it was three years earlier when the proposition was put forward, that the maritime provinces should form a union.
Prince Edward Island, the smallest, fearful that it could be swallowed up in the union insisted the meetings be held in Charlottetown. The Canadians, that is those people from Ontario and Quebec, their leaders heard about it and asked to be invited.
Discussions were held over the divisions of powers, an upper chamber and the judiciary. Then in 1867, the union was formed and the rest is history.
I suggest that we do not know each other as Canadians.
Sadly, my own example may reflect the experience of others in this Chamber or certainly some of my readers. Before I was elected in 1979, I travelled overseas to 12 countries. I visited the United States many times and travelled through to the south to Florida and had yet to go to the province of Quebec before I was elected in 1979 here in my own country.
People of my generation had travel patterns that were north and south rather than an east and west pattern, south into the United States, including the vacation land of Florida.
Perhaps that, too, has been the pattern of residents in some of our other provinces, for example the Atlantic provinces. Perhaps they have travelled into the New England states rather than visiting the rest of Canada.
People in Ontario and Quebec travelled to Florida. Western Canadians travelled down to the states of Washington and California into Oregon and the Dakotas.
Sadly, we do not know our fellow Canadians and do not have an appreciation for the beautiful country that we live in.
I hope that will change. I hope that will change because of the debates that we are having and the turmoil that we are in at the present time regarding our Constitution, and the fearful thought that Quebec might separate.
I hope that the teachers in our schools will spark the imagination of students with our wonderful Canadian history that we have.
In conclusion, Cartier said of Confederation in 1867: "We sealed our pact without bloodshed and without exploitation of the weak by the strong. All it took was fairness, justice, and some compromises on both sides. I hope that if it must be amended it will not be to the narrow principles of fairness on which it was founded but rather to enlarge them even more".
I am grateful for the opportunity tonight to speak to this issue.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: I will recognize the hon. member for York South-Weston, followed by the hon. member for St. Catharines, the hon. member for Edmonton-Strathcona and the hon. member for Madapedia-Matane,.

Mr. Speaker, I wish I could say how grateful or pleased I am to be able to have the opportunity to speak to this matter this evening, but I have to ask myself whether this Parliament has its priorities straight.
We just came back from a rather extended leave. Most MPs had the opportunity to spend a lot of time in their constituencies, to speak to their constituents, and to ask them what was concerning them, what the important issues are. It is abundantly clear and obvious that as far as the Constitution goes Canadians just are not that concerned about the Constitution in terms of it being a priority.
Here we are having a special sitting of the House and I am probably competing with Murphy Brown, Cheers or the Olympics. This is not the only evening; we have had other evenings set aside to talk about the Constitution.
Here we are talking about the Constitution when 1.5 million Canadians are unemployed, when over 2 million Canadians are on welfare. We have set aside parliamentary time to talk about the Constitution when the most important issues in this country are jobs and the economy. Do not think the unemployed in this country are panting, listening to parliamentarians talking about the Constitution, asymmetrical federalism and a distinct society.
Do you think they are concerned about distinct societies when they do not even know where the next rent cheque is going to come from, when they do not know
February 13, 1992

where the next mortgage payment is going to come from? I think we should put this in perspective. This is not the burning issue in the streets of Toronto, Vancouver, Halifax, Edmonton, or Saskatoon. The burning issue is the economy. When is this Parliament going to get serious and relevant in terms of what is important to the people of Canada? We should be setting aside parliamentary time to talk about the ways and the ideas we have to put Canadians back to work, to put the country back to work, in order to ensure that we can continue to afford and support medicare, post-secondary education and to ensure a prosperous future for our children and grandchildren.
We should be debating the economy. We should be debating all weekend. This Chamber should be filled with MPs. The Senate should be sitting all weekend to find ways, to talk about ideas or methods to get people back to work. Here we are talking about asymmetric federalism, distinct societies, entrenchment of this, entrenchment of that. Yes, it is important, but Canadians are fed up to here. They are fed up listening to politicians, people in the media, intellectuals, law professors, the elite, the snobs.
When I speak, I speak of the views of my constituents as well. They want this Parliament to deal with the real issues that are of importance to Canadians. Last spring, like many other members of Parliament, I sent out a survey. There were 40 questions in the survey that I sent out in the riding of York South-Weston and question 36 was: Please rank in order of importance how you think the federal government's agenda should be prioritized. This was last spring, last May. I should point out that over 1,500 constituents took the time to respond to this particular survey. It is not a scientific survey-and hundreds of others wrote letters-but 1,500 people took the 15 or 20 or 30 minutes that it took to complete it.
What did they think were the issues of importance? I listed five issues: defence, Constitution, environment, economy and social programs. The number one issue, you are right, the economy. The second issue of concern was the environment; the third, social programs; the fourth, the Constitution and fifth, defence. That is what is of concern to the people of York South-Weston.
The Constitution
I asked them general questions. I asked people how they felt about the future. Remember, this is almost a year ago. A lot has happened in the year, the recession has deepened, more Canadians have become unemployed. The mood out there is not any better; if anything, it has become a little worse. I asked people: "How do you feel about your future?" Seven per cent felt very positive, 27 per cent felt positive, 48 per cent felt uncertain, 11 per cent felt negative and 7 per cent felt very negative. I asked: "How do you feel about the future of your children?" Thirty-three per cent either felt very positive or positive, 53 per cent felt uncertain or negative about the future of their children.
In this particular survey I asked 40 questions on the economy, defence and external affairs, the Constitution, the environment, immigration, police and security and several general questions. I would like to go over the questions on the Constitution because that is what we are supposed to be talking about here tonight, although I would rather talk about ways of employing people. I should point out before I go over the questions that on December 3,1990,1 had a citizens' forum in the riding of York South-Weston at the Nelson A. Boylen Collegiate Institute. It was the York South-Weston citizens' forum on the future of Canada.
Again, on Monday, April 29, 1991 I organized a town hall meeting at Archbishop Romero Secondary School, again to talk about the Constitution and other issues of concern to the people of York South-Weston.
Then, as I indicated, last spring I sent out the survey. Every constituent in the riding had the opportunity to express his or her point of view through this particular survey. I understand I just have a couple of minutes to go. I would like to quickly go over the questions and the results.
"Did you agree with the Meech Lake Accord?" Seventy per cent said no, 9 per cent yes. "Do you believe the Citizens' Forum on the Future of Canada chaired by Keith Spicer is an effective means of gauging public opinion?" Fifty-five per cent said no, 19 per cent said yes. "Do you support the entrenchment of aboriginal rights in the Constitution?" Sixty-seven per cent said yes, 18 per cent said no.

The Constitution
"In your opinion is the government taking sufficient steps to resolve the underlying causes of native discontent?" Ten per cent said yes, 75 per cent said no.
"Do you believe that the recognition of Canada as a multicultural nation should be entrenched in the Constitution?" Thirty-four per cent said yes, 56 per cent said no.
"Do you support the current policy of bilingualism in Canada?" Thirty-two per cent said yes, 61 per cent said no.
"Is Canada's policy of bilingualism an essential element in maintaining a Canadian identity that is distinct from that of the United States?" Thirty-two per cent said yes, 62 per cent said no.
"Do you believe a sovereign Quebec can survive and prosper economically, socially and politically if it were to separate from Canada?" Seventeen per cent said yes, 69 per cent said no.
Those were the results of the questions that were put in a survey that was sent to the residents of York South-Weston. That was last spring. If one were to resurvey I am sure the views would still be similar.
In closing, I urge the Parliament of Canada to set its priorities straight. Start talking about the economy and jobs and get relevant and come up with ideas, methods and ways of putting Canada back to work.

Mr. Speaker, I welcome the opportunity to present my constituents' concerns with regard to the Constitution. Before that, I have to agree with the previous speaker, the hon. member for York South-Weston and also other people who have taken part in this debate.
In the city of St. Catharines the primary concern is the economic situation. When I asked people about the government's proposals, they would usually answer that they were more concerned about their jobs. The announcement by General Motors prior to Christmas that it was going to be closing 21 plants in North America, with a potential job loss to about 70,000 people, added another devastating impact to my community. Obviously, with General Motors being the major employer and this taking place, this is the matter that is most on peoples' minds.
But where my friend, the previous speaker, indicated that it is a concern and, obviously a primary concern, it cannot help but be linked with the constitutional problem. I think we all realize that without unity in our country and without a united and strong Canada there cannot be any great economic progress made.
We could not do without a quarter of our population if the province of Quebec left Confederation, and what would be left would have a great deal of difficulty as well. Therefore, we are faced with a constitutional problem along with our economic woes at the present time and we have to deal with both those matters.
The people of St. Catharines are interested in the constitutional debate. That was shown this past Monday evening when there was a debate at Brock University in St. Catharines between David Peterson, the former premier of the province of Ontario, and the hon. member for Lac-Saint-Jean of this particular body.
They managed to fill up the theatre at the university as well as an overflow into the gymnasium which watched the debate by closed circuit television. The questions that were asked indicated that people are concerned about the future of our country and they are concerned about the constitutional questions that are before us.
One of the points that Mr. Peterson made was interesting. He indicated that we have been almost cursed with this constitutional question for more than 125 years and that we may be cursed to continue on with this because of the diversity of our country. It is a point that has been made before and I think we have to realize that.
In talking to the people of St. Catharines, they wanted to get back to the basics. The Constitution comes from the people and the basic power rests with them. They are the ones who give us the opportunity to govern, to decide on taxation and the other matters that are in the realms of the federal, provincial and municipal governments. They are the ones who set the parameter of the Constitution. That is something that we have to remember and we have to pay attention to when the Constitution is formed. The people of St. Catharines want to see the country remain united. They are fiercely proud of our country.
February 13, 1992

It is interesting that there is this linkage between the economy and the constitutional question. In that regard, the people would like to see a true economic union across the country. The original intent of the British North America Act was to form a common market in British North America. Now, we have the proposal in front of us that indicates there will be a free flow of goods, services, people and capital across the country. This can only help our country. Artificial trade barriers have to be brought down. I know that the First Ministers have tried to do that and they must continue to do it.
The Senate is a matter that you will not get too much comment on. People realize that there are regional differences and that regional alienation must be dealt with. If the Senate is the correct way to deal with that regional alienation, that is what they would like to see happen.
I think they are concerned about the parliamentary system. Giving the Senate equal powers, an elected Senate, and possibly as was indicated an equal Senate, may cause some withering of our parliamentary system if we have another body that will compete with the House of Commons and possibly replicate it. That is something that we have to avoid.
It is interesting that one group of high school students in my riding, a combined class of Denis Morris High School and Holy Cross High School in St. Catharines, a grade nine enriched program, studied the 28 proposals and came up with a report that they presented to me before Christmas. It is called Shared Citizenship and Diversity: A Student Response. They dealt with three of the beginning proposals of their government. They looked at the Canadian identity and said: "We, the students of Lincoln County Catholic School Board in St. Catharines, believe that the most important qualities of a Canadian are equality and fair play. We believe that a Canadian is someone who is willing to include everyone, regardless of ethnic, cultural, religious or racial background, as friends and neighbours in the Canadian story".
They went on to look at the various proposals that have been made. Along with what people who have discussed this with me would say, they indicate that the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms is something
The Constitution
that should be reaffirmed and strengthened. They felt that the proposal to increase the override provision or the notwithstanding clause to 60 per cent of the House of Commons was good. They also felt that in addition to including it for 60 per cent for this body and for the provincial legislatures in order to invoke the notwithstanding clause that an elected Senate should deal with it as well, that there should be approval by 50 per cent of that body, and that the override provision should only last for three years.
I thought that was an interesting concept, coming from a group of grade nine high school students.
They also went on to deal with aboriginal matters. They felt that aboriginal peoples should also be considered as a founding people along with the people from Quebec, that we should treat them in the same manner and that we should remember that they were the founding peoples along with the French and the English as well.
One other matter that I would like to speak to in the time remaining to me is the concept in the proposals that training has to be given exclusively to the provinces. I believe in training. I know that the training programs that go on in my community are most important at this time. With the restructuring that is going on in the Canadian economy and the world economy, we have to realize that this is a matter that is going to go on, that people are going to retrain and retrain maybe three and four and five times during their lifetimes.
The people I talked to indicated that they want federal funds to remain in these training programs. They want a federal presence. It may be that the provinces would take the lead. We have difficulty now in the province of Ontario. We have labour training boards that have been established for the entire country and we also have them for the provinces. There is an agreement that has been reached between the federal government and the Ontario government.
The Ontario government is currently pulling out its training and skills development from about 10 different departments. That is going to take them time and there are going to be inevitable turf wars that go along with that. In the meantime, the Canada Employment Centres seem to be standing by, not being allowed to participate in this process that is going on.

February 13, 1992
The Constitution
If this is what is going to happen, I see dire consequences. Individual communities need to priorize their various training programs and they need to do it in a manner where they all get together. It seems to take the province a great deal of time in order to get into the training. The federal government is already there. Why are we going to lose that particular aspect? That is something that I definitely want to see worked on.
It may mean that there is a shared jurisdiction between the provincial and the federal government with perhaps provincial paramountcy. Training, and this has been told to me by many of the people who are involved in the training area, many of the people are my constituents, that they do not want to see training exclusively go to the province. That is something that I hope will be looked at and taken into consideration in the report of the special joint committee.
One other matter was property rights. The indication of the students was that property rights should be included. They felt that it would be taken into account by section 1 of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, clearly demonstrated in a free and democratic society.
Having said that, I think that we can look forward to the coming time to the report of the joint committee. I look forward to participating in what I am sure will be a debate in this Chamber.

Mr. Speaker, it is with great pride that I rise this evening and present here in the House of Commons a report from the citizens of Edmonton-Strathcona.
Over the past months many people in my riding have expressed to me their views on Canada's Constitution. I have spent hours reading surveys, responding to letters, talking to people on the street and in my office. I have listened to people who have attended my town hall meetings. I hold one town hall meeting a month as I have done for three years and we have been talking at these town hall meetings about the Constitution for at least a year, if not more.
My constituents have told me that it is time for a change. They told me that regions must be better represented in our Constitution. They told me our House of Commons and our Senate must be reformed. They told me that it is time that governments consult more with Canadians. They told me our Constitution
must also protect our environment. They have told me that our Constitution should be modified to allow Canada to remain prosperous into the next century.
From the people who have contacted me I have learned many things. What has impressed me the most was that the people in my riding are proud to live in Edmonton, Alberta. They have told me that they will always be Canadians first and Albertans second.
The people of Edmonton-Strathcona are proud of their citizenship. They feel they want to keep the country that they love united and strong. But they have told me it is time for change.
In the summer of 1991 I mailed a questionnaire to every household in my riding, to 40,000 homes representing 80,000 constituents in Edmonton-Strathcona. The response was impressive. I received over 1,000 replies. I want to thank those who responded to my questionnaire. I also want to thank the many people who have written and telephoned me on this very issue.
In many different ways my constituents told me that they want equality for all people, all provinces and all regions in Canada. My constituents do not feel equal to Ontario or Quebec in our present system of representation by population. Eighty-three per cent of my constituents told me that it is important to them that we reform our Constitution so that regional representation can be increased.
Seventy-six per cent of my constituents said that they would like regional representation to be increased through Senate reform. I must emphasize that the strong demand for Senate reform in Edmonton-Strathcona cannot and must not be ignored.
However, interestingly enough, only 32 per cent of my constituents demanded that all provinces be equally represented in the Senate. This means that while the people in my riding demand and expect Senate reform, they do not demand and expect a Triple-E Senate.
Sixty-one per cent of my constituents feel that to increase the regional representation in our Constitution, we must also reform the House of Commons. They want a House of Commons which is less partisan so that members will be free to speak on behalf of the regions



February 13, 1992

that they represent. A little bit later on, I will touch more on House of Commons reform.
I have also asked my constituents how they feel about giving one province the right to a constitutional veto that is not shared by other provinces. Not surprisingly, 76 per cent of my constituents say no to this idea. Once again, my constituents have told me that they want all provinces to be equal partners in a strong and united Canada.
I have received a strong message that my constituents expect to play a more involved role in amending our Constitution than they have in the past. I have asked my constituents their opinion on constituent assemblies, national referenda and public hearings as methods to involve citizens in constitutional reform.
My constituents have made it clear to me that they would like to have the right to be involved in national referenda or constituent assemblies if the government decides to amend the Constitution. I very much support the idea of a national referendum.
However, I would like to note that the most popular response was that people wished to be involved in constitutional hearings on proposed constitutional amendments. There is 66 per cent of my riding that would like to have a constituent assembly to propose or to review constitutional amendments.
Sixty-three per cent of my riding would like a national referendum to approve constitutional amendments. Yet, 82 per cent feel that it is very important to have constitutional hearings on proposed constitutional amendments.
I applaud the government for consulting Canadians as extensively as it has through the Beaudoin-Edwards commission, the Spicer commission and the recent Dobbie commission.
Constitutional hearings will ensure that in future, Canadians will have the right to participate in amending our Constitution as they did with these other committees.
I have also asked my constituents how they feel about involving aboriginal people in the constitutional process. Seventy-two per cent felt it was very important for aboriginal people to be involved in the process. In fact, quite consistent with my constituents' demands for
The Constitution
equality, I was reprimanded by one constituent who told me that this was indeed a silly question as everyone in Canada has the right and should be involved in the constitutional process.
On the issue of our Constitution reflecting Canada's multicultural and bilingual nature, 49 per cent of my constituents feel that this is important, that our Constitution reflect multiculturalism as a strong principle of Canadian society.
On the subject of giving the provinces control over language, only 22 per cent favoured giving the provinces more control and 46 per cent were strongly opposed to this idea.
My constituents also told me that they considered environmental protection to be a critical issue. Eighty-six per cent felt that each level of government should have the power it needs to protect the environment. Fifty-eight per cent of my constituents felt it was important that they had an environmental charter that would acknowledge the rights of Canadians to environmental protection and that this would allow them to go to court when these rights were not protected.
Edmonton-Strathcona is divided on the issue of our Constitution reflecting the unique cultural characteristics of Quebec. Forty-three per cent felt that it is important that the Constitution recognize Quebec as a distinct society and 39 per cent were opposed to this idea.
Many of my constituents have said that if the government does acknowledge Quebec as a distinct society, they would like to be informed on how this would be defined. My constituents would like to know what distinct society is, what it means and if it provides Quebec with extra rights.
My constituents told me that they want our Constitution to be able to enhance our ability to remain competitive in world markets and to direct national economic policies.
Seventy-five per cent feel it is very important that the federal government should provide the direction for our country on the major economic policies as opposed to this being a provincial responsibility. Seventy-seven per cent feel that it is important that the government set national standards so all Canadians can work together for excellence.

February 13, 1992
The Constitution
In conclusion, the people of Edmonton-Strathcona are asking for change. They want a new Constitution that will reflect the needs of Canadians in the 1990s. However, they did not tell me that our government should throw out the baby with the bath water. Most of my constituents want a Constitution that is basically like the one we have today, yet increasing the influence and powers of the regions.
The constituents of Edmonton-Strathcona believe in a strong, united and prosperous Canada. I am very grateful for having this opportunity to share with you the views expressed by my constituents and I hope that all members will carefully consider these views.

Mr. Speaker, I have the privilege in this House to represent the wonderful riding of Matapedia-Matane, where people worked and still work very hard to build a heritage with which they can identify for themselves and their children.
I urge those who have never visited this region to go and see it. They will be surprised when they get there by its rich and diverse natural and man-made environment, with a 120-kilometre shoreline along the majestic St. Lawrence and extending 150 kilometres into the Matapedia Valley. Human activities have developed sometimes along opposite lines, sometimes along complementary ones.
What a fisherman needs for his living is not the same as what a farmer or a forester needs. Nevertheless, the feeling of belonging to their region arises from this diversity. What would seem at first glance to disunite them in fact brings them together, since they complement one another and raise their common standard of living. What is true for a region like mine is also true for a country like Canada.
We all agree, I believe, that the unity and prosperity of Canada are both essential for its survival. One does not go without the other. Our prosperity and our prestige throughout the world come from Canada's unity. In today's world, political stability is essential to a country's economic health; it is far too precious to be simply dismissed out of hand.
Yet this is what we are preparing to do if we let Canada disappear. For many, the last recession hurt a lot and continues to hurt. At home, in my own riding, we experienced closings that we are not about to forget, whether it was Donohue-Matane, Radio-Canada or VIA Rail. There were very few ridings, in Canada and in Quebec, that were able to escape the negative effects of that recession.
That being said, it is pretty easy to see that the scenarios on the break-up of our country, even the most reassuring ones, anticipate a serious deterioration of that economic context. Common sense tells us that the break-up of a country, combined with an already fragile economy, will result in a dramatic drop of our standard of living, which is presently the second highest in the world, just after Japan. Many obstacles looming up on the horizon threaten our quality of life, and it is not by dividing the country that we will overcome those.
One of the first such obstacles is our accumulated debt of more than $400 billion; that amount represents $15,000 for each man, woman and child in this country, and it does not include provincial, municipal and personal debts. In spite of that, thanks to our sound budget policies, we enjoy a top triple A credit rating. That rating guarantees the solvency of each province, as well as each public and commercial business in the country.
What happens when that credit rating goes down? The lenders simply demand higher interest rates. Given our present debt, an increase of 1 per cent translates into costs of over $2,500 million, which means less money for services, regional development and social programs.
Competition is another obstacle. We cannot escape the constraints of a world economy. We need to trade with other countries. Canada now exports 25 per cent of its production and, in the last five years, its share of the international trade has dropped from 5 to 4 per cent, which is one of the biggest drops among the Group of Seven members. In that context, we must, in my opinion, remain strong and united to make up the lost ground, rather than divide our country.
Despite all of this, we are told that once Canada has broken up, it would be easy for the two smaller and less
February 13, 1992

viable countries that would result to negotiate the economic structures that made our prosperity in the past. Some people say that could be achieved in a spirit of generosity and serenity and that it would be easy to convince other provinces, the United States and other countries to kindly take our new needs into account. That is what they would have us believe. Quite frankly, would it be easier for an independent Quebec of six million to negotiate a new GATT agreement, for example? Would Quebec or a new fragmented Canada be in a better position to deal with giants like the United States or the European Community? The answer is quite obvious.
We should understand that those simplistic arguments and that reassuring nonsense are part of that senseless logic that often destroys nations. At the risk of not sounding too original, let me say that if we fail to learn from the past, we will always repeat the same mistakes. And what can we learn from history? We learn that the break-up of a country is both costly and painful, that it may have serious consequences in the short term and in the longer run and that it can leave deep economic and social scars.
We find evidence of that everywhere around us. You just have to brush up on your history and look at what is happening in the world. You will soon realize that in the hopeless number of countries falling apart, the people are on the verge of losing peace, stability and prosperity, if that is not already the case.
If our country breaks up, what will happen to our education system with less money? What will happen to our labour training program, our health program, and our currency? The uncertainty created by this whole debate is already hurting us a lot. The fact that we have to compete with other countries requires that we settle, as soon as possible, this issue which has been lingering for more than 30 years so that we can proceed with what all Canadians expect from us, that is to create jobs, to create wealth and to guarantee our social programs.
Mr. Taylor, chairman of the board at the Royal Bank, said on January 23, and I quote: "I have to travel all over the world to meet with business people who have billions of dollars to invest and, whether they are from London, Tokyo or Stockholm, they all ask me what is happening in Canada and if our country is safe enough for them to come and invest their clients' savings. I reassure them and I keep faith that we stay together as a country".
The Constitution
Closer to home, our investors postpone their decision to invest, which delays the economic recovery, and that is nothing compared to the permanent costs that await us if our country were to break up.
Some people say that an independent Quebec could share the Canadian dollar without having any official influence on decisions made by the Bank of Canada.
It would mean then that Quebec, as a minor partner in this monetary union, would have much less of a say than it does now in the development of monetary policies. Many factors affect currency, and no self-respecting country can tolerate for any length of time that someone else be in charge of such major policies. No sovereign nation can and will tolerate this form of neocolonialism for very long. That is basic common sense. As for the European monetary union, I can assure you it will pull off this amazing feat when the necessary elements, which are already present in Canada, will exist in Europe, namely a single central bank as well as integrated tax systems and national financial policies.
Why then would we relinquish what the Europeans want so much to get and as soon as possible? Our Constitution is 125 years old. A constitution is a bit like a mirror. When you look at it, or read it, you must be able to recognize yourself in it and be proud of what you see. As our mirror, the Canadian Constitution needs to be updated so as to be a reflection of the Canadian people as they are today, for the future generations to see.
Granted, this is no small task, but none is too big for men and women who like to take up a challenge and who genuinely want to keep this nation united, a nation which is the envy of so many others around the world.
Some people will say that the separation of Quebecers from the rest of Canada is a response to the challenges we face, but is it really necessary to break up Canada in order to satisfy Quebec's historical aspirations, the aspirations of the west, the Atlantic provinces and aboriginal peoples? My answer is no. Do we really have to break-up Canada to further harmonize federal and provincial policies and avoid wasteful duplication? The answer is, again, no. To prevent this break up, we must be guided by reason and a sense of equity. As Cartier said in 1867, to seal the federal pact did not require bloodshed or domination by the strong over the weak. It took equity, justice and a few mutual concessions.

February 13, 1992
The Constitution

Mr. Speaker, from my office I listened to the words said in this House on this subject by the hon. member for York South- Weston. My constituents feel the same as his.
Really they cannot understand why we are spending this time in the House on the Constitution when the number one issue facing the country is the state and crisis of our economy.
I am sure if you canvassed most of the 295 members in this House, they are probably getting the same feedback from their ridings. Let us address the economy.
I also believe that as leaders in this country we have a duty to address the constitutional issues because if we do not preserve this country, Canada as we know it today, then debates on the economy will fall on deaf ears.
Like the other members who spoke over these three evenings, I too did an extensive survey sending through my householder a questionnaire to every household in the riding of Parkdale-High Park.
The results that came back were very revealing. They gave me a reading of how my constituents think on amendments to the Constitution.
To sum it all up, I can safely say that my constituents feel that we as Canadians want a united Canada with a strong central government. That is the bottom line.
I was very pleased that over 80 per cent of my constituents felt that the aboriginal people have an inherent right to self-government.
I was also pleased from the survey to see that there is a change in attitude from Meech Lake days to the present. During the Meech Lake debate, I would say the majority of my constituents were against any distinct society clause in the Constitution.
Now over 60 per cent are accepting the distinct society clause as long as it does not give Quebec additional powers over other provinces. The way it is being interpreted now, most of my constituents feel that Quebec should be designated as a distinct society. They have no problems with that.
I would like to take the remainder of the time to present in this House for historical record the submissions made to the Constitution committee by the Canadian Polish Congress. The Canadian Polish Congress represents 240 different organizations across Canada. They represent the Canadians of Polish origin residing coast to coast in this country. The congress represents the thoughts and aspirations of the majority of the Canadian Polish community. The well-being, the future and the unity of Canada are matters of foremost importance to the congress. The congress has always taken a stand on issues of importance to Canada including unity, constitutional reform, multiculturalism, tolerance, cooperation and understanding among all citizens of our country regardless of their background, race or religion.
I am quoting from the introduction to their brief. The Canadian Polish Congress-

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: The hon. member knows he can table the brief after along with his notes.

Mr. Speaker, thank you for that advice. I shall do that because these are two very important documents.
I was very impressed with the way the congress presented it in a non-partisan fashion. They came before Christmas to Ottawa. They met with the deputy leader of the Conservative Party. They presented the brief to the Conservative Party with explanations. Then they met with the Leader of the Official Opposition and they went to meet with the Leader of the New Democratic Party and made the same presentation there. It was presented in a truly Canadian fashion in a non-partisan way.
To go through all of it would take me about two hours.
I will just quote a few things that might be of interest to the members of this House and to Canadians at large. I would like to share with you what they said under the section: Freedoms, Rights and Responsibilities of Canadians. "We must realize that we cannot emphasize our rights without addressing the corresponding responsibilities. Even a cursory look at our society reveals the fact that increasingly Canadians are asking not what they can do for their country, but rather what their country can do
February 13, 1992

for them. The prevalent attitude seems to be 'to get more for less' and 'to look after No. T.
Trade unions demand more pay for fewer hours of work claiming that their members have the right to earn such inflated wages. In addition job security appears to be a well entrenched right. Artists create obscene art in the name of the right of self-expression and artistic freedom. Our insatiable propensity for instant gratification leads to rampant consumerism with its egotistical implications.
In the name of freedom of speech, untrue and falsified history is circulated with sad and unpleasant results.
In view of these, we the Canadian Polish Congress believe that the time has come to address the other side of the individual rights and freedom equation, namely the individual duties and responsibilities."
Mr. Speaker, you have heard me speak on that issue in this House many times. I am pleased that an organization the size of the Canadian Polish Congress is backing many members who believe that this should be entrenched in the Constitution.
The other section which I would like to share, and again it affects the members directly, is the section under: Response of Institutions for a Modem Canada. The brief says they "agree with the proposals that the government has made under part II, proposal 8, the House of Commons". They want to share this comment with us. "It appears that at the present time the deciding factor in the law making is the party vote and not the individual vote of the member who is representing the will and aspirations of his constituents. It is proper to give individual members as much of free votes as possible so that they could reflect the aspirations of their electors more closely". This is something we have been talking about, but we are not implementing.
Another proposal is: "We would also suggest that the decorum of the discussions in the House be improved, especially during the Question Period. Also the participation of members at other times in the House should be improved". I see, Mr. Speaker, you nodding with that proposal also.
The third proposal to make under that section is that representation in the House of Commons should reflect more closely the actual distribution of the population in the provinces. The present disparities between urban
The Constitution
and rural ridings are too great, they say. The urban vote is consequently less valuable than that of the rural elector. Also some form of proportional representation should be considered and they suggest here the French model.
I was very pleased that they made these recommendations. On the title page of their presentation they quote from Thomas Carlyle who said: "Men's hearts ought not be set against one another, but set with one another".
I think we can maybe bring that up to date to 1992 and say that Canadians' hearts ought not to be set against one another, but set with one another. Canadian minds ought not be set against one another but set with one another. The hon. minister has been given this heavy responsibility to monitor the constitutional debates across this country. If everyone remembers that saying and helps that hon. minister, I am sure that we will come up with a document that all Canadians will be proud of.
I want to take this opportunity to say the government could not have chosen a better minister to try to put this constitutional package together.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: The hon. member will file that with the Clerk. The hon. member for Carleton-Charlotte.

Mr. Speaker, it is indeed an honour to take part in this very special debate this evening.
I have just returned within the hour from my home province of New Brunswick. Time is veiy short and as you have told me, I only have about four minutes. Hopefully we will continue this special debate or this process next week and I will have time to finish my remarks. In the short time that I do have, I want to point out a number of things that have happened in my riding in the past number of months.
It really began on September 29, 1991 when the Prime Minister unveiled the government's proposals for a renewed Confederation. I took those 28 proposals, which were quite complicated, quite long and involved and boiled them down, if you will, to a citizen's guide to the proposals. It was a four pager, back to back. I mailed that to all of my constituents in the hope that they would read it and after reading it would respond with the mail-in on that citizen's guide. Many of my constituents did that.

The Constitution
Aside from doing that, we also set in process a series of meetings throughout my riding. As you know, my riding is a very large rural riding, in fact the largest riding in maritime Canada. We had a series of 20 constitutional meetings throughout my riding over the course of those few months. I also had 20 speaking engagements at service clubs, schools and other interested organizations.
It was a very healthy process. It was a learning process not only for my constituents but for myself. I had a chance to hear them and get a sense of what they wanted from this country of ours.
To sum up, I am going to have to quote the Mexican ambassador to Canada. He says it best: "Canada is a success looking for a problem". What he means by that is almost what my constituents were telling me. We have a great country here, the second largest country in the world in terms of geography, the seventh largest economy in the world, a country that has been recognized by
the United Nations as having the second best standard of living across the social scale of any country in the world, only exceeded by Japan. Those are the types of things my constituents are telling me. They are also telling me: "Let's not throw it away". Indeed we have problems, but we are a sophisticated country. We are an educated country. We are a thoughtful country, a reflective country, and we have it within our grasp to make it better. That is what this process is all about.
I know you are signalling me, Mr. Speaker. I guess I have less than 60 seconds left. Hopefully we can continue at least my portion of the debate next week. I thank you for your courtesy, for allowing me to get on at this late date, and hopefully we will continue this next week.
